Borat is a comedy whose lengthy title is difficult to remember, and whose incendiary humor is impossible to forget. It is the most insanely funny movie of this, or any other, year.

movie_review_blurb: An adventure that -- in both its breathtaking ingenuity and breathless excitement -- exceeds Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit and Chicken Run, the two previous collaborations between DreamWorks Animation and Aardman Features.

If you've never seen a yurt taken down, I highly recommend it. Otherwise, not so much.

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie of such consummate good cheer that it's difficult to walk away without feeling happier than when it began.

movie_review_blurb: Even the editing betrays a sense of desperation about the material. It's cut so tight that no one ever breathes, they just talk.

For decades swashbucklers have buckled under at the box office, and Sinbad lacks the magic to reverse their fortune.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Bristling with brash leaps and thrilling spills, Pirates is a stunt fan's heaven.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: How to Deal is a 'dramady' of a film, with first-time director Clare Kilner fighting valiantly to balance its heaviness with humor. Though it's no Terms of Endearment, she pulls it off.
The wildly successful Austin Powers films are a hard act to follow, and Johnny English feels like a Johnny -come-lately to the same silly party.
BBII ripples and rumbles with remarkable stunts.
Disney's new Freaky Friday may be a remake, but it ripples with far more creative zeal than this summer's slew of uninventive sequels, which are basically remakes in themselves.
With eloquent dialogue but scant smoldering passions, the mushy machinations nicely nudge director Tim Fywell's gentle little film.
Nicely balancing mayhem and mirth, Yu keeps his film kicking. The action is lovingly lurid, and the laughs keep coming.
Lives up to Pixar's high standards for wildly creative visuals, clever comedy, solid characters and an involving story.
It hits easy targets with broad swipes, and its simple message is the same as Disney kiddie fare: Be yourself.
Even those who have read King's hybrid of horror and sci-fi may be left in the lurch. The story flowed on the book's 620 pages. It drunkenly stumbles on the screen.
A mundane, kid-empowerment fantasy distinguished only by Frankie Muniz's agreeable blend of haplessness and heroics.
Though Murphy is radiant, and her laughs are infectious, her free-spiritedness is thrust in our face like a pointy object in a 3-D movie.
It's leaden and predictable, and laughs are lacking.
Packed with strange beings amid painterly settings, Spirited Away delivers one of the most colorful fantasy worlds since the similarly surreal Yellow Submarine.
Beautifully shot and scored, and its pensive pace is a throwback to Disney's past.
[Moore's] better at fingering problems than finding solutions. But though he only scratches the surface, at least he provides a strong itch to explore more.
Even in its darkest moments, a heartening defiance underlies gut-wrenching calamity.
As an actor, [Chan] does stretch a bit.
If you watch movies chiefly for stunts and special effects, this Bond is for you. If you watch to see a beloved formula regurgitated, make tracks.
Treasure Planet is the rousing action-adventure Disney tried and failed to produce in last year's Atlantis: Legend of the Lost Empire.
Your response to its new sequel, Analyze That, may hinge on what you thought of the first film.
Between its brisk start and explosive finish, Nemesis dawdles in talky, jargon-filled explanations.
Though Frodo's quest remains unfulfilled, a hardy group of determined New Zealanders has proved its creative mettle.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Intelligent and moving.
When taken as an old-fashioned adventure with a comic-book plot, The Core works well. But at 130 minutes it wears out its welcome, and like Earth's balky core, it sputters and stalls.
With few respites, Marshall keeps the energy humming, and his edits, unlike those in Moulin Rouge, are crisp and purposeful without overdoing it.
Mired in the inertia of Charlie's writer's block, as if the real Kaufman never found his own passion for the material.
With Dickens' words and writer-director Douglas McGrath's even-toned direction, a ripping good yarn is told.
With its heavy-handed approach to light material, it falls on its face as often as Lee's hapless character.
Though the bikes are fast, the drama idles, with corny characters taking themselves more seriously than heads of state negotiating arms treaties.
Except for some doubles, Chan performs his fight scenes in this film live on camera while doing his most creative choreography in years.
After a frothy start, How to Lose (an apt abbreviation) becomes a one-joke comedy of slapstick suffering.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The best Marvel movie to date.
Most mirth is as feeble and pointless as the plot, from the thin shock value of inappropriate cursing to a routine array of hedonistic hijinks.
Offers a persuasive look at a defeated but defiant nation in flux.
It's inspired comic casting with rare feel-good chemistry.
Largely this sad story is handled with a morbidity and monotony that go nowhere -- certainly not toward understanding.
If you've ever heard gnawing in your attic, Willard will creep you out.
Although it is a rough ride, The Hunted is also an exciting one. But no tracking skills were needed to follow its well-traveled cinematic road.
For a teen-geared trifle, this is feel-good fun with its heart in the right place.
Unlike Chan's better action-comedies, such as Rush Hour and Shanghai Noon, this one is undercut by off-key humor.
Nair navigates narrative waters littered by a shipwreck's worth of detritus; too many characters bob and sink.
A sweetly winning domestic comedy.
A predictable exercise in boy-girl mush amid royalty's seductions.
[Hancock's] Alamo may be flawed, but it tells a tale that still has the power to stir our souls.
You're better off listening to the album than watching this almost unwatchable movie.
It's persuasively performed by a potent ensemble and artfully directed by Jean-Paul Rappeneau.
A spirited comedy of complications whose derivative plot is bolstered by worthy messages, quaint '80s nostalgia and agreeable mush.
With colorful characters and snappy performances, Mean Girls is a rare laugh-out-loud film.
A labored misfire.
It's a charming, zestful romp.
[Hudson] melds her radiance to a budding maternal soulfulness.
Blessed by a potent cast, Saved! lets its teens be teens -- pimples, if not warts, and all.
Though their selfishness is repellent, the characters feel strikingly real.

The premise veers wildly from its fertile setup, thanks to acting that isn't broad so much as grotesque, humor that's isn't smart so much as witlessly vulgar, and preposterous plotting that insults the intelligence.

Two Brothers is an odd crossbreed: documentary-style nature film, broad comedy, environmental sermon and Disney wannabe. But the awesome aww-power of its irresistible tiger cubs smooths its unevenness.
Hellboy can be a kick -- even if you're not a devotee of the comics.
Sensational enough for power-fantasy fans, it also tells a strong story that tugs agreeably on our heartstrings.
The movie is uneven, but it has scored well during previews, and there's a reason: Sleepover fills a niche-audience void.

Hawke and Delpy are credited with writing some of the dialogue, presumably as improvisations. They manage to be both natural and intense, and their characters feel real, even if the situation does not.
Thanks to a soulful performance by Giovanna Mezzogiorno, it's also eminently watchable, even as we resist its machinations.
Duff plays off her Lizzie Maguire persona as a cute but unassuming girl, but also conveys soulfulness and earnest longing.
This gonzo ganja comedy is propelled more by sly charm, sharp wit and stinging social satire than by mere smoke jokes.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Starts as the playful romantic comedy, then veers into an ensemble piece about ruthless careerism before settling for melodramatic self-obsession.
A low-budget indie film whose tension and realism are augmented by unknown actors who fully inhabit their roles.
Though sometimes marred by murky lighting and quick-cut incoherence, the action is sudden and sensational.
Seeing Hollywood as a business indifferent to dreamers with no cash flow isn't a revelation, but a given. If you're going to hold a mirror up to Tinseltown, at least try tilting it at a new angle.
The Beginning surpasses both sequels, yet it still feels like a potboiler that regurgitates reliable jolts as if it were sticking to its own rites.
Winterbottom and screenwriter Frank Cottrell Boyce sell the sci-fi but botch the interpersonal.
The Four Feathers has rewards, from the exoticism of its seas of sand to the fierce grandeur of its sweeping battle scenes.
What's most revealing and human about Festival Express are its candid looks at artists bonding aboard the choo-choo.
Overly broad humor with little on its mind.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Becker ably milks the premise for irony and amusement.
A galvanizing experience in terms of sight and sound.
A harrowing look at a disturbingly recent time that seems more rooted in a barbaric, distant past.

Thirteen, a disturbing look at rebellious teens, is galvanized by emotional extremes and wrenching performances. But this gritty indie film also presumes a profundity that its edgy shocks and drama-queen histrionics don't deliver.
It's a mean-spirited, drunken stumble of a movie unspooling in an endless loop of panicky foolishness.
An engaging spin on the reliable crime subgenre of lovable thieves.
A vampire film for the new millennium -- bold, galvanizing and darkly stylish.

The Rundown wants to stand out in a movie market gorged with action. But it regurgitates commercial dictates rather than carving a new path. At least it relies on a diverse, charismatic cast, rather than on spectacular carnage.
Linklater strikes just the right power chords here. He respects rock enough to keep it real, and he has enough rein on Black to ground his wildness in warmth while avoiding easy sentiment.
It's just as guilty as Blair Witch 2 for smothering bare-bones fright with ladles of gore.
Despite one of the year's best trailers, this horror-film spoof is as laugh-challenged as the woeful first sequel.
A monster movie with class.
The film grows on you, thanks to strong characters and the shrewd observational humor of writer-director Peter Hedges.
Curtis shows the same eccentric humanism and charm that gave him Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill.
As an original family film for the holidays, it's fresh, timely and quite funny.
It's a barrel of lunatic laughs.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Where are the Knights Who Say 'Ni!' when we need them?
Like The Ref, the best previous film in this vein, Bad Santa redeems itself with rounds of riotous outrageousness.
This film is everything a fan could want and possibly more. For three-plus hours, it entertains, enthralls and awes.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: From playful mugging to tender affection, Martin exudes a strong star persona, and he and Hunt share romantic warmth despite a dearth of alone time.
Wincer delivers a gentle yet vibrant tale of natural splendor, a horse's valor and a young girl's plucky determination.
Chasing Liberty is fine (if empty) fun, and much credit for that should go to feisty Moore.
Though Polly packs ample comic punch, it also demonstrates that life isn't about the safe past or the uncertain future but the journeys we make each day.
Formulaic, predictable and skimpy on characters, it succeeds, thanks to a lively, fresh cast and a director who sidesteps cornball sweetness.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Bounce feels as dated and condescending as Blue Hawaii.
A worthy ride, especially if you're into sports.
An inert sociopolitical thriller mired in moralizing.
Riddled with contradictions, preachiness, implausibilities, false starts and wrong turns, it tells a choppy, incoherent tale without an ounce of charm or wit.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to buy this minor melding of Rocky and Erin Brockovich as anything but a punched-up star vehicle for an actress in a slump.
The film's chief problem is that Garai and Luna lack the sparks of Grey and Swayze.
Hard-hitting police thrillers need a smidgen of authenticity, but Sarah Thorp's script is riddled with implausible events, inconsistent characters and head-scratching twists that don't add up.
As sheer popcorn-munching fun, it's an often-rousing action-adventure that confirms Mortensen as a star.
Like Freddy vs. Jason, it's just another boogeyman movie, but being only a first sequel, its gore lore still smells fresh.
Gedeck is mostly marvelous.
The most audacious pop-cultural amalgam since Star Wars.
It's Hollywood navel-gazing at its best.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Some scenes are truly, inventively bizarre.
Road Trip rides the wave of popularity for base, politically incorrect, outrageous humor.
From electric cattle prods to human infernos, it's an tough, rough ride.
movie_title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Its premise is flimsy, but its payoff is riotously funny.
Has ... meaning and truth, not to mention scarred humanity.
A fun and warm children's fantasy.
It's a film X-Men fans can embrace and action fans in general can appreciate.
Sinks in a sea of cheesy effects, cheap clichés, dispiriting narrative and the one thing an action fantasy can't afford: boredom.
Any new vampire film needs fresh blood, and this one is clotted with clichés, including its Matrix-style acrobatics.
An admirably heartfelt story with more on its mind than the glory of self-expression.
A setup stretched as thinly over feature length as the average movie-bound Saturday Night Live sketch.
The standard stalker stuff that Scream satirized.
Most of the movie is grotesque and creepy in the worst way.
Judge's mirth translates surprisingly well to an 80-minute length, and he exploits the movies' greater scope without sacrificing the show's cheesy charm.
See Spot Run not only exceeds low expectations, but it's also even a pleasant surprise.
For all its coarse humor, The Brothers has moments of tenderness and depth.
Of course, we expect such films to be tasteless. That's their job. But that doesn't forgive them for being more abusive than bawdy or more sleazy than kinky.
A warmly human story marked by humor, drama, a little romance and an ending that's preordained (though crises arise), yet also moving.
A cautionary, almost sci-fi stab at how hollow our consumerist society can become.
Doesn't push the limits of taste so much as the limits of how bad a movie can be.
As hard as it tries, this film is no Near Dark -- not nearly.
We suggest you forget coherence and just enjoy the ride.
DreamWorks' first animated film to blow Disney out of the water.
A silly, stupid story with a one-joke comic premise.
It's got solid performances by a strong cast.

Its visuals are executed skillfully, it takes time to develop characters, and its voice cast has personality. But in today's context of broadened animation appeals, Atlantis seems as stale as uncirculated submarine air.
Chopper plays like a nonfuturistic A Clockwork Orange.
These gear-heads may spout car-talk like know-it-alls, but they sound no less nerdy than trivia-obsessed Trekkers.
A breath of fresh air.
Though BW2 eschews the first film's jumpy visuals, its erraticism as a narrative is even worse.
The film's gluttonous overkill of food is matched only by its overacting.
Aardman delivers the most consistently entertaining animated film in years.
Its plot is hackneyed and banal.
In basketball terms, Space Jam is more akin to the 'garbage time' that concludes lopsided games, when reckless playing is no substitute for the real thing.
Can be surprisingly smart and lively in its early going, thanks to some cheeky, well-written humor, a genuine sense of excitement and topical ties to the Internet.
The plot couldn't be more stale if it wafted from a sarcophagus.
It's a pity the film doesn't respect the art of acting as much as that of music.
A landslide winner as an emotionally rewarding drama.
Jedi may not be George Lucas's crown jewel, but his trilogy as a whole is as good as film fantasy gets.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: In terms of story and characters, this film pirouettes into the orchestra pit.
This tale of ultimate evil is a maddeningly inert drama.
Though its tale of gold is not untarnished, The Road to El Dorado hits the buddy-movie mark.
Spending 95 minutes with the slight antics of Pikachu, Ash and the gang may seem like an eternity.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The wow-factor action is irresistible, and Lloyd is no less appealing than '60s Disney star Kevin Corcoran.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever you do, don't close your mind to such an inventive concoction. One last time, despite all your better instincts, go ahead -- open that theater door.
Another SNL misfire.
Among today's rude, crude and gleefully non-PC comedies, Scary Movie can be so funny it's scary.
Action flicks should be fun, and this one is a bloody bore.
As in The Haunting, they eventually surrender characters and story to computer-generated spectacle, squandering any creepy immediacy and trampling the human element.
The real fun of Scream 2, like Scream, isn't seeing people slaughtered. It's the smart-mouth dialogue and in-joke ironies.
As good as [Close] is, she's simply Cruella revisited.
Stretched far too thin for its meager plot, broad characters and lame running jokes.
The key to appreciating The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas is low expectations.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining lark that's often spry and even radiant, with an end-credit wrap-up that's a hoot.
This film stands out -- not as an original (its focus on fierce competition is nothing new), but as a well-executed story with likable characters and fresh flourishes.
You're bound to scream -- perhaps real loud -- but it may be out of impatient dismay as much as Pavlovian reaction.
A lovably amusing foray into vapid plotting, bad dubbing and men in rubber suits trashing miniature sets.
In a summer driven by wow factors, Titan A.E. has a galaxy's worth.
Its sentiment is rote, its truths are culled from a trip down the aisles of a greeting-card shop.
A highly entertaining romantic comedy that is so sweet, funny and charming.
The Watcher is a numbingly familiar exercise in fear, disgorging regular doses of grisly violence buoyed by precious little plot and pitifully thin character development.
A rare teen film that spends less time pandering to wish-fulfilling fantasies than baring honest interpersonal realities.
Repellent yet intriguing, brutal yet funny, wicked yet strangely compassionate, The Salton Sea is more about mixing genres and styles than illuminating a credible reality.
As it is, it's one of Burton's lesser works -- above the goofy Mars Attacks!, but below Sleepy Hollow and his Batman films when it comes to earnest adventure.
If anything, it's the filmmakers who seem insulated, working cluelessly within the plastic bubble of Hollywood.
A fresh hybrid of zombie horror, high-tech sci-fi and butt-kicking thrill ride.
When it's not glorifying baseball and Texas myths, The Rookie zips like a good fastball.
Frailty isn't as gory or explicit. But in its child-centered, claustrophobic context, it can be just as frightening and disturbing -- even punishing.
In its ragged, cheap and unassuming way, the movie works.
If you're a fan of the Friday the 13th series, its 10th and latest entry, Jason X, should not disappoint.
With Hollywood Ending, he's made three solid comedies in a row, each a light lark with no hint of morose self-reflection.
In the end there is one word that best describes this film: honest.
For a film about action, Ultimate X is the gabbiest giant-screen movie ever, bogging down in a barrage of hype.
In short, a film dependent on deception relies on the Clark Kent school of disguise, and it doesn't work.
For decades we've marveled at Disney's rendering of water, snow, flames and shadows in a hand-drawn animated world. Prepare to marvel again.
Parker keeps things light and lively, and the cast never trips over Wilde's eloquence.
Toward the end Sum of All Fears morphs into a mundane '70s disaster flick.
while [Roman Coppola] scores points for style, he staggers in terms of story.
For a film by a photographer, it's awfully unfocused.
While dutifully pulling on heartstrings, directors Dean Deblois and Chris Sanders valiantly keep punching up the mix.
An artful yet depressing film that makes a melodramatic mountain out of the molehill of a missing bike.
MIB II is faithful to its source film, which in turn sprang from a comic book. But this feels more like submission to formula than devotion to inspiration.
A more enjoyable neo-dragon flick than 1981's Dragonslayer, with its lesser effects, or 1996's Dragonheart, with its soft heart for the monsters.
This new spin on the old switcheroo plot is intriguing, warmly human and gently funny.
Freaks is yet another case of plot and characters playing second fiddles to an orchestra of visuals.
It reminds us that Nathan Lane is the best show stealer in show business.
If you enjoy the tense claustrophobia of submarine thrillers, K-19 fills the bill.
Performances are potent, and the women's stories are ably intercut and involving.
[T]hose same extremes prevent us from taking its message seriously, and the Stepford Wives mentality doesn't work in a modern context.
An honest, sensitive story from a Vietnamese point of view.
Tadpole is emblematic of the witless ageism afflicting films: Young is cool, and too young is too cool.
Spy Kids 2 is loose and lively and appeals to the kid in all of us.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: For all its alleged youthful fire, XXX is no less subservient to Bond's tired formula of guns, girls and gadgets while brandishing a new action hero.
Mr. Deeds isn't bad for an Adam Sandler film, which is as backhanded as a compliment can get.
The far future may be awesome to consider, but from period detail to matters of the heart, this film is most transporting when it stays put in the past.
A base guy flick that's clueless about women, relationships and emotion, and even flirts with sacrilege.

As the story of heroic response to tragic illness, Iris is the kind of film often cynically pegged a 'disease of the week' movie. But unlike such formulaic TV productions, Iris' heroine is denied the capacity to be inspiring.
Summer Catch is supposed to be end-of -summer fun, but it's about as fun as learning to eat your spinach.
Jeepers Creepers gets down and dirty, respecting its genre enough to make it seem vibrant, fresh and, in a warped way, real.
This may be a slow film, but there are worse settings for aimlessness.
It works well in narrative terms, thanks to strong characters and surprising respect for the music.
For an exploitation flick, Soul Survivors also is woefully slow.
Hardball is an unpleasant tale of questionable redemption for a guy who rightly says, 'I'm just a loser.'
have risen above screenwriter Kate Lanier's mundane show-biz saga.
Put simply, the movie drags.
Children may enjoy its food fights, barf gags, slimy gross-outs, kid-power fantasies and adults' comic discomfiture, but there's not much here for anyone over 12.
This isn't just bad. It's an abject failure whose lame nuttiness evokes bad dinner theater more than a major studio movie.
Too much of its reality involves joyless response to circumstantial failure, and instead of being ironic or bittersweet, it's mostly bitter.
An affectionate, familial documentary giving credit to an unsung music hero.
A moody, mysterious fright film with a painterly beauty.
More bark than creepy bite.
It's an 800-pound gorilla of a movie, and now PDI has the challenge of answering back.
A martial-arts flick that transcends its genre with surprisingly strong sci-fi concepts.
Shows not how far we've come since '76, but how low comic standards have sunk.
As a romantic comedy on your film menu, Sidewalks of New York holds the romance and serves comedy on the side.
If you can tolerate its predictability, you may fall for Iron Ladies' lighthearted spirit and affectionate humor.
A breath of fresh, frisky air, even if it does hinge on cliches.
The infectious high spirits amid its cartoonish chaos compensate for the film's bald deficiencies and gag-inducing gags.
[Anderson] makes us laugh, he makes us think, and he does it in a distinctive screwball style.
There's still room in this world for innocent love stories -- and tales as old as time.
The pace is so lethargic and the focus so diffuse that it's hard to get a fix on Charlotte beyond needless glamorization.
The movie's magic is that we feel more rewarded than manipulated.
Unlike Rushmore, Slackers sends subtlety and cleverness to the back of the class, while labored lunacy wears its dunce cap front row, center.
For all its failings, Wet Hot maintains energy and high spirits over most of its length. The trouble is, such energy and spirits are not infectious, and the movies it mocks were better.
Teetering toward preaching, the film says much about courage, honor, duty and sacrifice, traits common enough in many World War II stories.
Preceded by a 1957 Pluto short, Never Land is a warmly nostalgic throwback.
Unlike most such sex comedies, it's not mean-spirited. Instead, like the original, it's an odd mix of ribaldry and innocence, titillation and tenderness, lasciviousness and love.
Newcomer Land is a find, performing with guileless naturalism and resilient dignity.
This lame sports comedy is deflated by clichés, from a save-the-farm plot to sadism disguised as slapstick.
Portentous and pretentious, Shell 2 crawls along like a machine on low batteries.
As is typical of many weddings, the planning drags, and so does the movie.
Though lovely and scenic, it drones for thousands of miles.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Valor does emerge in The Guardian, but often is eclipsed by an effects-driven star vehicle.
The film's first half has zero to do with its title, and its second half digs up familiar turf.
Even fantasies need a nod or a wink to assure viewers, 'Yes, it's ludicrous -- but isn't it fun?'
Perhaps indoctrination is in the eye of the beholder. But one thing is certain: All Christians aren't the same. I'm one, and I found this film to be saddening, not heartening.
Despite the buzz about its hard-core hanky-panky, writer-director John Cameron Mitchell paints a bland, bleak portrait of navel-gazing New Yorkers driven by carnal pleasures -- or lack of them.
It's more confusing than absorbing.
It's one of the most clear-headed -- and twistedly entertaining -- views of drug dependency and insanity I've ever seen.
We see not only the inner corridors of power, but also sense the inner workings of the royal mind. Stephen Frears' deft direction also gives the film insight and even humor.
Instead of an insightful look at disaffected youths finding an outlet for angry energy in rock rages, American Hardcore is a slanted history lesson coming solely from its subjects.
A Good Year builds so much fairy-tale contrivance with such boisterous high spirits that it's exhausting to keep feeling good about feeling good.
It's an ugly, brutal picture, and it's not about 'times' but rather timeless macho posturing run amok.
Too often it seems to be just another action fantasy that teaches pacifism while indulging in brutality.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Forget Scarface and Miami Vice. Cocaine Cowboys is the real deal -- a down-and-dirty look at the high living and illegal drugs that dominated south Florida in the 1980s.

With so much brandishing of name actors in small roles, Bobby feels like a '70s disaster flick, with the disaster in the final minutes. While waiting, viewers must content themselves with playing spot-the-star.
Consider it a modern spin on Deliverance, with no squealing like a pig -- just squeals of frightful excitement.
The film is brief, thin and anecdotal. Yet at its heart is a loving look at an artist at work, and that artist is Morgan Freeman.
It's a good gimmick, but still a gimmick, and we're left with more confusion than tension.
Charlotte's Web adapts a classic, which is not to say it is one.
This is no heart-tugging family drama; rather it's a contemplative, compassionate portrait of a hardy people. Offered as a borderline documentary, it proceeds in long, uncluttered takes.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Just as the French may overrate our cinema (Jerry Lewis, anyone?), we may overrate theirs. Take Le Petit Lieutenant -- please.
A dramatic crisis erupts in bloodbaths that are filled with flash but little meaning. As armies clash, the cast also yields to histronic extremes.
The film becomes a sermonette on tolerance. But with its one-sidedness, it fails to practice what it preaches.
This film fails to earn what Erin Gruwell earned in real life: credibility.

Known in the United States for her whimsical books, Potter was an ecological champion in the United Kingdom. The film touches on this, but mostly it's a tender tale about yearning hearts and courageous idealism.
Harris, who adapted the screenplay, and director Peter Webber are faithful to his book. Strong production values, a lush score and scenic locations work seal the deal.
When Sedgwick's whirl of liberation turns into addiction, clichés stall the plot.
Linklater and Schlosser have plenty to say. They just fail to say it cohesively.
Dahlia seethes with atmosphere, and Hollywood's underbelly is always worth an ogle.
Iraq for Sale isn't balanced or objective. It carries the torch for the families of civilians who died while driving unprotected trucks on unsafe routes.
movie_title: Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film's focus shouldn't be Dot (Camilla Belle), a deaf, mute and orphaned teen. It should be her new family of suburbanites sliding into hell.
This listless biopic of the famed 1950s model is as timid and tame as her photos seem today.
As is evident by the film's strong start and faltering finale, the trouble with any promise is failing to keep it.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Below its surface, Water isn't about religion, politics or even India. It's about timeless and universal divides between people, when humanity is eclipsed by self-serving subjugation.

Instead of a laudable ecological crusade, the film feels more like a futile Captain Ahab obsession, with patrol leader Ri Tai (Duobujie) vainly chasing a poaching kingpin through the harsh, windy wilderness.

Through it all, Jentsch is a beacon of bravery and resolve in the darkness of a totalitarian machine. If any actor in an English-language film has given a better performance in the past year, I'd like to see it.
It's a predictable and preachy stab at a comedy with heart, and its subversive silliness is eclipsed by an overwrought humanity.
Its coming-of-age yarn goes nowhere beyond inevitably out of a closet.
Like too many films, Down in the Valley turns on its viewers.
You're not getting the whole picture in Ocean Oasis, just the critter-cute ones. But at least the film is well shot, showing striking vistas and images both above and beneath the waves.
District B-13 is bad sci-fi, but it succeeds as mindless action.
Nondevotees also should find a home in this agreeable, accessible Companion.
Assayas tells her tale sympathetically, but this sad saga lacks substance. He sells the wretch but not the redemption.
The bottom line is that none of this goes anywhere beyond a droning funeral procession.
The web gets more tangled until, midway through, the drama drops and the film becomes yet another bloody horror show.
More disturbing than thrilling, Lemming, like Alice, overstays its welcome, but does get around to a finishing kick.
It's handsome and heartfelt but mired in murky politics, plot inertia, musical montages and painfully pointed symbolism.
Squanders plot impetus, and even with constant crosscutting it's lethargically paced, slogging through soap-operatic back stories and maddening irrelevancies.
It's often unclear what's going on, beyond a zillion dollars of splashy effects washing over the screen.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Steeped in urban-youth woes but gets a bounce from Clark's sense of humor and hope.
We hardly get to know Cohen from the biographical shorthand melded to a worshipful tribute show in which the Canadian singer-songwriter never even appears.
Some things were meant to be seen in small doses or on small screens. For all its subversive perks and quirks, Strangers is one of them.
Director Ivan Reitman, who's been busting our guts since Ghost Busters, stirs a high-concept stew of Fatal Attraction meets The Incredibles.
Scoop, an amiable romp of lighthearted fun.
More intriguing than enthralling, more creepy than disturbing, The Night Listener runs a tidy 80 minutes yet still feels stretched.
The Descent seems less about female empowerment than female misery. One wonders if Marshall has issues. No males suffer here, just women who, even if they survive, won't ever be the same again.

For a film about magic, The Illusionist doesn't depend on tricks up its sleeve. It's more about artfulness, from handsome period details and Philip Glass' urgent score to an intriguing and vibrant plot.
Sometimes, keeping it real is all we ask, and this film gets the job done.
I felt some of its heroine's pain. She's spent her life waiting for an orgasm. I spent the movie waiting for a plot.
More a series of anecdotes than an insightful dramedy and relies too much on absurd coincidences and needless sitcom-style lying.
Their journey isn't over -- many in Africa still desperately need help -- but the hope and opportunities America offers are a grand place to start.
How do we loathe thee, The Number 23? Let us count the ways.
The fragmented tale is a tangled mess, and the actors have no characterizations to play, apart from shrieking cowardice.
Milking sympathy for parentless children is no stretch in The Italian. More impressive is its affecting look at their reeling mother country.
Some offbeat humor shines through the clouds of this glum domestic drama, especially when fun friends shift the focus from Jean's grating histrionics. But it never lasts long.
On sci-fi's crowded table Boyle serves a fresh feast for our eyes, minds and hearts.
The film seduces. Beautifully produced, from production design and costumes to music and performances, it's also faithful to the genteel spirit and repressed passions for which she's known.
As an alleged witty comedy of humanistic charm, it sags in both, thanks to unfunny predicaments and a phony plot.
I'll just say that Buscemi, who also directed and co-wrote, knows a lot about making movies but little about journalism.
A punishing misfire.
This lurid lunacy from New Zealand is a horror-humor cross-breed of animal lore and giddy gore.
Perhaps the Bible needs an 11th Commandment: Thou Shalt Not Bore. That might stem misfires such as The Ten.
Resistance is futile -- unless your screenplay can offer pat, absurd plot turns.
Borrowing from too many movies to count, Rocket Science botches that brew in an unwieldy slew of adolescent-angst clichés.
It may be the most depressing action movie ever made. Its calamities are well staged, and its acting, beyond some histrionics, is fine. But you don't enjoy this film; you endure it.
If you want dangerous schemes to be light-hearted entertainment, you've got to make allowances. Besides, the payoffs are worth it - in any language.

The best Western since Unforgiven, 3:10 to Yuma is both cathartic and intelligent. While a wildly eventful action-adventure and outlaw shoot-'em-up, it's also a vibrant story of heroism, villainy and hard-earned redemption.
A drama that's so potent and persuasive yet also natural and intimate that it almost has the heft of a documentary.
What it's really about, more than sensitivity for displaced people or social analyses, is violence -- hideous, gruesome, over-the-top violence.
Although the period-piece film has all the trappings, from beautiful people to an obligatory sense of tragedy, it never follows through. In fact, its love story needs a shove -- it just lies there.
Nerds rule.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For this gripping and amazing documentary, such truth emerges not just from the facts, but also the poetry of men who redefine themselves in a risky race on small sailboats.
Sea of Dreams purports to be a film of 'magic realism,' but it's neither magical nor realistic.
[Haggis'] self-serious tone becomes wearisome, and he fails to explore how the military failed its men while clumsily laying a guilt trip at its feet.
Though Shadow could use a bit more confessionals and a bit less history, it still succeeds as a reminder of America's can-do spirit at its best.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A buoyant coming-of-age adventure welded to an amiable wealth fantasy.
Director Robert Benton and screenwriter Allison Burnett tell a sobering, adult-geared tale of love's highs, lows and maddening twists and turns.
It's simply product for a pre-conditioned marketplace, pushing familiar buttons without doing anything remotely creative.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Mike Cahill explores Charlie's foolishness with funny-sad fondness.
An eye-popping tribute to the European range that's heaved heavenward since bulging from the Earth eons ago during continental drift.
A quietly compelling drama of hidden desperation and fierce passions.
A love-tolerate valentine to the city, it feels more real than the gangster-gorged mean streets of Martin Scorsese's The Departed, and just as tortured as Clint Eastwood's Mystic River.
A fascinating documentary.
Cassavetes supplies no easy answers or easy laughs, forgoing romantic-comedy beats in respect for Nora's desperation. Call this confection a romantic-dramedy with humor on wry.
... a documentary whose superficial image belies its profound impact.
I've been among the unbelievers, but Hollywood Dreams turned me around -- to a point. Perhaps it's because the film is among Jaglom's best, love him or leave him.
Its minutiae don't bring a lump in the throat -- just a drumming of the fingers.
Wild Hogs isn't wild so much as a mild evocation of better fish-out-of-water flicks.

The most perverse thing about Zodiac isn't that its Hollywood's umpteenth serial-killer flick, when such crimes are rare in reality. It's that Zodiac, though based on actual crimes, is one of the dullest of these films to date.
It's a steamy, searing saga of rigorous redemption confronting creepy Southern seediness. But it's not nearly the wake-up call it could have been.

Monster movies tend to be as misunderstood as their creatures, but dating back to 1931's Frankenstein, some haven't been about scaring us so much as enlightening us. The Host does this while disgorging a lizardlike carnivore.
Somber but soulful, Premonition has a strong dramatic performance by Sandra Bullock and a gimmicky plot that doesn't grate until the end.
My Brother is a brave little film, with the emphasis on little. Shot on a shoestring, it lacks the polish of many indie efforts but compensates with bold casting and a big heart.

One problem is that Malkovich gets free rein to be Malkovich, the often showy actor, rather than Conway, a humble London travel agent. It's a grandstanding performance that's more about hamminess than substance.
For such a gritty indie film, it's galling that [Arquette] and his family are so handsomely photogenic in a generic Hollywood way. Where's the rebellious truth in that?
There's more love and heart in The Namesake than in many Hollywood dramas. I just wish the filmmakers had spread it around. Cross-cultural understanding should be a two-way street.
Flannel Pajamas is so gorged with gab it feels like a filibuster.
Its sad story is ultimately humane and compelling, thanks to some special faces placed in the saga.
Firehouse Dog is a wholesome throwback to a time before computer animators made animals talk and penguins hogged the glory.
A mixed-bag of a popcorn flick where more proves to be less.
Dialogue is a low priority in this film, which has less plot than most video games.
In my book it's high camp -- a thrill ride for emotion junkies.
It'll do nicely, thanks not only to sophisticated amusement but also to a gentlemanly hero who earns a place in our hearts.
Like a perm that won't grow away, it's stuck in the race-comedy mold of Barbershop, Barbershop 2 and Beauty Shop. Been there, done that hair.
It's not preachy or weepy. Instead, it's a lively yet meaningful romantic comedy that doesn't lose sight of its central mission: to entertain.
Offside is a slow slog through bloated scenes with little happening. Framed and shot like a crude documentary, it proceeds in long, clunky takes, as if an editor couldn't be bothered.
Gracie, a tale about a teen girl blazing trails in soccer, is worthy, but it's also formulaic to a fault.
For a voyeuristic medium, this tale of a voyeur does a poor job of prying into its own protagonist's life.
Given Luke Wilson's affability, it's also irresistibly charming. You may not buy the film's plot, but you'll invest in him as a man whose heart is always in the right place.
The cast shows spark and gusto, especially Laura Harris as a vulnerable yet intrepid survivor type and Danny Dyer as a bent druggie who straightens out long enough to fight back.
Even the least tales here flit by quickly enough to leave little bad aftertaste, and the best are savored like the last small bites of exquisite soufflés.
A noisy, incoherent, droning spectacle.
[The] plot is warmed-over Capra, and it's no wonderful-life yarn.
... though Crazy Love remains a far cry from heartening, it is more amusing than disturbing, especially given the cranky yet symbiotic couple of today.
Compelling but punishing -- an artful ordeal. The best way to process it may be as unintended camp, rolling your eyes in amazement at its litany of misery and heaps of histrionics.
Is it sci-fi? Fantasy? Idiocy? Mostly it's a droning mess -- pretty to look at but confounding to the point where you just don't care any more.
A film whose deft blend of action thrills and gallows humor packs a jaunty kick and a firing-range boom.
Its strong cast is loud and lively, and the bickering banter has snap and drive.
Director Michael Apted tells the story with dry devotion to parliamentary procedurals and a worshipful approach to Wilberforce. But [actor] Gruffudd lacks the intensity and charisma to pull it off.
The Sentinel's brains may be mush, but its brawn is powered by superb stunts, high-tech gizmos and a potent sense of peril.
Yet for a so-called exploitation film, Wax is slow to exploit. Its leisurely setup is a fright-challenged snooze, and at nearly two hours it's bloated for a slasher flick.
Less a faux documentary than a perversely amusing stab at the music world's harsh realities.
Revenge of the Sith is more of the same: wildly flamboyant effects serving weak characters, bad acting and obtuse plotting.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Exorcism aside, Dominion is well-acted, handsomely photographed and hauntingly scored.
Take a long, hard look at Parkhill's film, and you'll find too many i's undotted.
Brilliantly written, animated and performed, it not only bridges the child-adult divide, but also makes its kid-friendly humor smart in its own way.
The titular operation often yanks the film from big-screen sensation to a pedantic look at military procedures best suited to a TV documentary.
It's unfair to pigeonhole this meaningful human story in that genre, especially since it feels more real than some adult chick flicks. Besides, a good story is a good story.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Squinting through cardboard glasses you get at the door, you see washed-out colors, blurred images and not enough pop-out to merit the trade-off.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Green's heart, if not his head, seems in the right place. He's carrying the torch and holding it high, and his students seem to dig it.
So richly detailed and colorful that one almost aches from the beauty.
Herbie is a G -- for good, if not grand.
Land's gruesomely creative zombie atrocities stretch an R rating's limits like a bloody tendon about to snap.
An overrated mound of misery.
We knew Spielberg had action chops, but didn't know he had this in him. This anti-E.T. is so rigorously realized it makes Independence Day look like Finding Neverland.
A rousing affirmation of nature's brilliance in the face of environmental challenge.
If you can handle its unconventional approach, you won't feel as if you're seeing a film so much as witnessing a living nightmare.
Screenwriter Gina Wendkos, working from Meg Cabot's novel, resorts to monotonous movie clichés: almost uniformly cruel classmates and a callous, cacophonous mob of media jackals.
The action is handled fairly well, but it's routine, and there's no satisfaction in seeing Todd waste men who are no more bloodthirsty than he is.
Some may find such wrenching realities shocking, if not reprehensible. Others may glean meaning in their starkness -- a meaning that transcends the film's despair with the power of its truth.
This film is so not-from-the-cookie-cutter, so unaccommodating of our expectations, that we can't anticipate where Anderson's going to take us. Every scene is a discovery or sly diversion.
A genuine fright classic.
What ensues is painfully horrific and reprehensible as entertainment.

You can embrace this movie's message, which has less to do with political agendas than basic human decency and the enduring power of love. And if that's not enough to make a film worthwhile, we don't know what is.
It's no knockout, but it's fun and gets the job done in a nonmalicious way, which more of today's punishing filmmakers should emulate.
A lame duck of a movie.

Its tale was more tame and thoughtful when Steven Spielberg, having done the related Artificial Intelligence, pitched it to Bay. But Bay, being Bay, punched it up, hiring script doctors to mainline some action.
Though Crónicas starts as a stark tragedy about widespread suffering, it morphs into a preachy, languorous treatise on manipulative media.
[The writers are] so busy setting up the premise that they barely get around to exploiting it.
Win or lose, in an era of sports idols as rock stars, Yao is a breath of fresh air.
Like good drive-in fare from the '70s, this is all about sensation.
As dull as dust for much of its look at the Baja 1000.
An ambitious, if uneven, tale of passionate lovers from 1933 to 1945.

Shrilly pandering to edgy, jive-talking, hip-hopping bents of the moment, [Shark Tale] churns up a sea of offensive ethnic stereotypes, unfunny situations, unsympathetic characters and lousy plotting.
Best savored as a beautifully photographed and scored road trip and as a character study of disparate men who somehow fit together as friends.
Its preachy side can be offputting. Messages of forgiveness and spiritual awakening are slammed home like force-feeding for the soul.
A weird road-trip spin on Sam Peckinpah's Straw Dogs.
Though Team America has knee-slapping moments, too much mirth has too little on its mind.
The Grudge is all about fright. It's not about mystery, characterization or perverse amusement, all of which can turn horror into something more.
Its hellish extremes more oppressive than entertaining.
The Incredibles is so jammed with entertainment that, at two hours, it's almost too much.

There's nothing cautionary in DiG! that you couldn't learn by renting the 1986 Sex Pistols-related biopic Sid and Nancy -- or exploring the commercially still-born yet revered career of the Velvet Underground.
A wondrous, dazzling, eye-popping adventure.
Some things are worth causing a lump in your throat. Finding Neverland is one of them.
A comprehensive look at the punk pioneers that never wears out its welcome.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Zarhin has a fine ear for dialogue with refreshing directness and loud rings of truth, but he also knows when to let looks speak volumes.
Its close-ups of belted numbers command attention without truly commanding our hearts.
Good, gory fun.
Frighteningly bad cinema is the only thing scary about Alone in the Dark, which gives video-game movies an even worse name, if that's possible.
A colorful cavort in songs and saris, Bride & Prejudice has infectious high spirits, though its showmanship upstages plot and characters.
Beyond Wahlberg's deft moves, School's dancing is leaden, not charming, and the only challenge is enduring the film's lumbering progress until it finally clicks at the end.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A depressing yarn.
Though predictability runs all through this House, it works up a modest charm thanks to the emergence of likable, individualized characters.
Doug Richardson's script is as riddled with plot holes as Pollak's house is with bullets.
Refreshingly quiet and thoughtful.
Despite a pedigreed cast and crew, Ring Two might as well be Blair Witch 2.
Its emotional tone may be up and down, but its clear-headed approach has straightforward snap.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Its action couldn't have been much more thrilling if done entirely by computer or shot in costly live-action.
Makes music almost an afterthought, and as such it never truly sings.
movie_title: The Boys and Girl from County Clare (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Needs highlights and a trim.
A charming cash cow with cute twists to its tale.
Beyond mind-numbing explosions, Stealth's effects are good, especially the whooshing flight scenes. But as Eddie shows, humanity matters, and computer wizardry won't fill an empty plot.
Brutal yet meaningful, agonizing yet touching, The Brotherhood of War is a harrowing but rewarding experience.
movie_title: Tae Guk Gi: The Brotherhood of War (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An unflinching look at poverty, expedience and harsh choices in a desolate environment.
Watching paint dry would be better. At least the paint would be busy drying.
In The Matador, Pierce Brosnan plays another man with license to kill, yet he gives a performance wildly unlike his suave superspy. In fact, it may be his best role yet.
There's far more smiting than smooching -- more hewing of limbs than heaving of bosoms.
Feels as warmed over as day-old muffins in Little Red Riding Hood's basket.
Malick is so content to tell the tale through mood that he neglects its meaning.
Huffman makes it a must-see.
A simple yet oddly profound tale of banal blue-collar lives shattered by an impulsive crime.
For those in the mood for love, A Good Woman is more than good. It's one of the best films of the new year.
Though nudity will keep this from being a family film, for those who love the family of the theater, this postcard from its past is worth framing in your heart.
Behind the hype lies a banal morality tale told in needlessly jumbled flashbacks and gorged with gruesome atrocities out of a Sam Peckinpah flick.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Harrowing and heartbreaking, On the Outs is persuasively performed by fine actors, yet has the real feel of a documentary.
The faces of that movement are what sell this story -- with enthusiasm, not regret.
But even beyond its sleazy pandering and sensationalism, the film's worst transgression is its exploitation of young children.
Some defiant rockers are forever young. This one is in name only.
If you're in the mood for an edgy, raucous, music-driven gender-bender, rent Hedwig and the Angry Inch instead.
Hills' new mix of old elements somehow feels fresh.
Depp's depraved character does have twisted poignancy.
To the charge of squandering credibility despite being based on a true case: guilty.
The B-team version of the story.
After Innocence is a crusading documentary driven by DNA testing that's brought freedom for men who served years in prison for crimes they didn't commit.
Epic in scope and imagery, the film is a haunting look at mankind's capacity for inhumanity, as well as survival.
Using the same basic plot as 1992's original, BI2 feels less like a sequel than a remake whose shelf life has expired.
Of course, sentiment in such pure form is hard to embrace. Without a realistic edge, it's like a flower arrangement: lovely for a short span, then prone to wilting.
Like the recent Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang, Slevin is a real-world crime tale with no grip on reality, just an obsession for gimmicky movie-brat fantasy. Believable, it's not.
Jim's characters may grow on you after a slow setup and, like a hot plate of grits, may stick with you.
The Wild pops out of the pack with its animation. Its visuals are fluid and detailed, and its backgrounds are better than those of recent rivals.
It's galling to think American kids must go abroad for a chance to turn their lives around. But it's also inspiring to see the changes that are possible.
Nor does it sermonize at the expense of entertaining. Instead, it melds gospel and hip-hop for a music-driven tale of twin brothers who reconnect.
A lightweight fanboy valentine for ostensibly heavyweight music.
... a heartening affirmation of the spirit that helped many dancers to thrive in their heyday more than half a century ago and to survive as teachers, dance devotees and priceless raconteurs.
Wolf Creek is wicked and witless -- cruel for the sake of cruelty.
It plays almost like Terms of Endearment crossed with the feel-good yule romance Love Actually.
Silverman comes across as a racist, callous diva in Sarah Silverman: Jesus Is Magic.
A formulaic fear-fest with a bare-bones plot, The Skeleton Key is more moody than scary, and Hudson's heroine is unsympathetic.

Alone, the jokes would become a tedious, 87-minute blur. But The Aristocrats also has eloquent analyses by George Carlin, show-stealing bits by Sarah Silverman and Whoopi Goldberg, and inventive ways to keep the joke from getting stale.
Though Herzog's approach is chillingly fascinating, it makes this film less about an unusual life than about a bizarre death.
If you can sit back, buckle up and forgive the plot holes on its runway, Craven's bumpy ride is rollicking entertainment, careening from winking humor and cutting dialogue to big action payoffs.
Witnessing so much heavy breathing with little meaning, we feel like Dustin Hoffman in The Graduate when he asks bored bedmate Ann Bancroft if they can have a conversation first.
Thanks to newfangled things like TV and the Internet, small-town folks aren't as uniformly insulated as director Phil Morrison and screenwriter Angus McLachlan would have us believe.
Those who adore Terry Gilliam for his taunting French soldiers in Monty Python and the Holy Grail or his weird subversiveness in Brazil may find The Brothers Grimm to be a fairy tale gone sour.
Some directors wouldn't know a true love story if it smacked them in the face like a big sloppy kiss.
Though not meant to be taken seriously, Venom is no chucklefest but rather a harrowing ordeal in the ruthlessly violent vein of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.
Amazingly fluid and drop-dead gorgeous, Tim Burton's Corpse Bride is the best-looking, stop-motion animation film ever.
Some movies are train wrecks. This one is chum.
Brave, funny leap into the abyss of adolescence.
The cast compensates by serving steaming-hot plates of gonzo enthusiasm, kicking things along with unhinged gusto even when Waiting stalls in anecdotal nothingness.
Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit soars with comic absurdities and innocent silliness while embracing old-world quaintness and a sweet heart.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Shows the reality and tragedy of gulfs between human beings who might otherwise learn to love each other.
It's hard to imagine a film more perversely obtuse than this dark, grim exercise in cinematic sleight of hand.
Gatins is so worshipful of a child's starry-eyed aspirations that he forgets to ground them in narrative honesty.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Roost's pacing is so leaden that you long for a pregnant pause, instead of interminable nothingness.
It's as grown-up as a movie can get, with a fine cast in a strongly crafted tale about the calamities that can wreck a relationship and the love that can redeem it.
Even hard-core horror can go too far. Saw II is as punishing as it gets. It's effective, all right, but to what end? Certainly not entertainment.
It's a fully realized look at a time and place as well as a riveting study of career obsessions warring with a sense of justice.
It has three stories, and each is extreme. Yet even literalism can be an understatement.
The cast steps up, embracing the chance to exercise acting chops normally limited to live theater. Most do so resoundingly, but two stand out: Robin Wright Penn and Jason Isaacs.
More about vulgar shock value and vivid period re-creations than it is an absorbing or convincing crime story.
Brevity is, indeed, the soul of wit, and in this case, wit barely starts to describe the value of this dead-on, full-of-life motion picture.
Though it falters as a narrative, Tony Takitani sticks in the mind with its poetic contemplativeness.
Kiss Kiss may not smack of the truth or invite analysis, but in a warped way it gets the freaky job done.
Fragmented and obtuse, with characters who fail to resonate.
The Ice Harvest is like Sin City without the bold style and crooked smile, disgorging grisly bloodbaths without drawing artful things out of them.
Excruciatingly, the film disgorges its crime and variations of it again and again. We'd prefer more detective work and less of what plays out as a grisly loop.
You'd think if you made a third one, you're gonna at least try to make some progress as a filmmaker, even within this limited scope of American Pie.
As ever, Herzog leaves us as anxious and uncertain as we are thrilled.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Five Foot Two never quite shakes the feel of a longform advert for Gaga's new phase that's preaching to the converted.
The final battle is more than just a cathartic bit of movie mayhem; it may be the loudest you'll cheer in a theater all summer.
A pummeling, two hour and 45 minute assault that essentially dares the audience to keep track of what's happening.
Morgen's strange, wonderful, audio-visual assault takes an icon and makes him all too human.
A wonderful screensaver of a movie.
In many ways, Marvel has grown up and passed Whedon by - and his jocular take on the material doesn't just feel stale, it feels like a step back.
Days later I was still thinking about the weird, wild optimism that runs through the movie's veins - while the misfires were steadily fading from memory.
Jurassic World would have benefited from being just a little less clever, because when it comes to crafting action sequences director Colin Trevorrow is impeccable.
When the best parts of a movie are the ones that recreate something made 31 years ago, what does that say about the state of modern blockbuster culture?
Powered by Rudd's goofy, good-guy sentimentality, Ant-Man filled me with something that's become a rather rare commodity in superhero movies: joy.
A middle finger aimed right at the audience.
Amidst a barrage of cringe-worthy dialogue, incomprehensible action set pieces, and incoherent dramatic turns, I started thinking, "Surely, somebody could have done better than this."
While there are no grand revelations, it's a methodical assault, chipping away at the hagiography of Jobs again and again.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's wild and outrageous, stacking laughs and scares atop one another in a giant Jenga of oddball entertainment.
Stressful, unnerving, and technically impressive, even if it does end up feeling like a deflated balloon by the end.
Proof that even after all this time, audiences haven't even begun to see everything that Johnny Depp is capable of.
The highlight sequence of The Walk serves as a testament to cinema's transportive power, and a potent reminder that even generally bland gimmicks like 3D can become effective tools.
The Martian's biggest accomplishment may be that it takes near-future space exploration, and makes it look achievable with the right amount of work and creative thinking.
Guillermo del Toro has always been known for striking, creative visuals, but with Crimson Peak he's truly reached a new level in his work.
Spielberg shifts tones seamlessly, from the taut, nearly wordless opening sequence, to Coen brothers comedy, and all the way through to the kind of white-knuckle ending you'd expect.
A listless mash-up of lazy gags and storytelling shortcuts that doesn't just echo the series' Mooreian lows - it undermines all the work the franchise has done since 2006.
Krampus feels like a movie in crisis, stuck between lampooning the holiday movies it's riffing on and embracing them with earnest, open arms.
If you squint, you can almost see the layered, poignant blockbuster that Transcendence wanted to be.
Those that are able to slip under its spell will enjoy one of the most striking theatrical experiences this year.
Jettisons the primary-color innocence of the original film for a sinister tale of conspiracy and intrigue. It's exactly what the series needed.
Despite its weaknesses - or perhaps because of them - Noah delivers the one thing that is so often missing from tentpole movies: a soul.
An entertaining adventure with some truly masterful moments, but they still fail to justify the nearly three-hour running time.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In a film where the hero is constantly asking questions about his predicament, the audience may be left with the most important one of all: why?
An escapist comic-book movie, without apology.
Newcomers will likely be left wondering what all the fuss was about in the first place.
Despite an impressive turn by star Benedict Cumberbatch it fails to deliver on its initial promise.
We've seen films set in outer space before, but nothing has ever felt this real.
The best horror films stay with you, leaving you jumping at the slightest sounds. This is decidedly not that kind of movie.
Maybe the return of Xander Cage will be better.
A movie that will unexpectedly challenge your expectations in some of the funniest ways you can imagine.
Neill Blomkamp has created a beautifully designed and realized world. If only he'd spent half as much time focusing on the people that inhabit it.
A remarkable achievement that actually feels like Star Wars again, more so than any film since 1983.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the faults, it's invigorating to see a franchise take its most popular character into uncharted emotional territory
World War Z is a string of unrelenting, harrowing sequences that continually manage to top one another.
Proof that Pixar still has that intangible magic, and is able to make movies for children, adults - and the adults of tomorrow.

Bertolucci, despite his obvious affection for Lorenzo, can't help but seem out of touch, and his hero looks and sounds less like a modern-day teen than an old man's wistful idea of one.
Its concerns are deeper, and more richly psychological, than merely trendy probings of the zeitgeist.
Freedom curdles into chaos, and it's from this turbulence that the film derives much of its visceral power.
If this were the 1930s, the world would soon be clamoring for these two to star together in another picture. The least we can hope for is a sequel.
For all its specificity to the Philippines, its thematic breadth is universal. Diaz is a patient, perceptive observer of life.
We know what Segerstedt did, and Troell tries to ask why. What he ignores are the implications.

On the subject of her cultural significance the film remains oddly quiet.

movie_review_blurb: This is a deeply, patiently observational film, and the details Kiarostami emphasizes ... seem somehow profound in their banality, a mystery of ineffable beauty.
This relentless torrent of Mexican miserabilism makes for alienatingly grim and violent viewing.
Losey and Pinter locate the pain that lurks deep within complacency, and the film positively throbs with it. It's an old idea, perhaps. But in their hands it hurts anew.
The director, Nicolas Mercier, has failed to grasp how repellent his own protagonist seems to us.
Beneath exhausts the appeal of its thinly sketched characters almost as soon as they're trapped together in the mine's emergency bunker ...
It seems life is still unendurable for those who feel entitled to absolute comfort from it.
You feel as if, at any moment, anything could happen. The problem is, seemingly everything does.
Watching Mann teach is a delight for the same reason it is to watch him perform: It's because here, you sense, we are in the company of genius.
movie_title: Speak The Music: Robert Mann And The Mysteries Of Chamber Music (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is not merely a document of something extraordinary. It is something extraordinary all on its own.
You can sense the director, Sarah Smick, gearing up to make a point. It proves rather obvious: Real connections are meaningful and too much Facebook is bad.
None of the reliably irritating qualities of the social issue documentary gall quite so acutely as the tendency to venerate mere awareness.
Juno Temple is sensational in this assured psychological thriller from Sebastián Silva.
I've never seen anything like it.
You get the sense that Kanner would benefit from attending a few workshops of her own.
Surprising, challenging, and never less than thrilling.
What remains seems in some ways closer to a parody of bad thrillers than an earnest example of one - the only difference is that Nothing Without You doesn't know that it's funny.
The interiors of our likeable lovers have not been furnished substantially enough to suggest real lives beyond the hotel walls.
A vigorous and strangely compelling character study, a sustained burst of punk-rock ferocity, and one of the most original American films to emerge in some time.

Hilarious, sad, electrifying.
The film mounts a compelling case on behalf of what was, perhaps, a sort of genius - a rare gift for identifying talent in others and nurturing it, even amplifying it.
movie_title: Smiling Through the Apocalypse: Esquire in the 60s (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's so much dead air in the film that I wondered whether punchlines had been cleaved out to secure a PG-13 rating, but no: it's a hard, inexplicable R.
A debut feature of extraordinary passion and vigor.
Keyed-up and ludicrously over-the-top. Scarcely are sequels so ambitious -- or so original.
This is vigorous, frightening, electrifying stuff. Even minor Perry outclasses most contemporary majors.
What language the film does make us of, where it differs from Flaubert, is careless, littered with strange anachronisms and mistakes of usage and tone.

The Safdies observe it all with a smart, sensitive eye, and of the truth miss nothing. Holmes, meanwhile, is electrifying: she really is a star.

When your character's name is "Iam" - pronounced, you know, "I am" - even your most tasteful work begins to seem like overacting.
Just as it seems on the verge of yielding a nuanced view of the Holocaust's emotional and psychological fallout, Anita B. recedes into platitudes and cliché.
Like aging, the mystery feels both frustrating and inevitable.

Something of a masterpiece ... Electrifying.
Nowar, a smart, savvy filmmaker, keeps his focus narrow and the frame alert, eager to drink in not only action but nuances of culture and history.
It's what new films ought to strive for: to strike back against the familiar.
A dinner-party mystery so sweat-inducingly tense that I could only watch it through laced fingers.

movie_title: The Mafia Kills Only in Summer (La Mafia Uccide solo d'Estate) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Seventh Son is a very bad film, to be sure, but I'd like to think its badness would have been as evident had it been whisked at once to the frontlines of Universal's summer slate, emboldened by the confidence of a proper blockbuster premiere.
Why a movie about an unassuming cartoon sponge felt compelled to adopt the register of a summer blockbuster is beyond me.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chazelle, training a keen eye on the proceedings, seems to delight in the spectacle of relentless punishment.
Force Majeure represents what is perhaps Östlund's most sophisticated thought experiment yet, at once provocative and wise.
It takes stock of the state of contemporary cinema, impoverished by film's looming obsolescence, and draws some dire conclusions indeed.
Rigorously argued and exhaustively researched.
Despite proving thoroughly ridiculous, it remains an unabashedly self-serious film
Harrowing stuff, and Reichert and Zaman make it count: It's hard to watch and not feel galvanized.
This, as you've doubtless guessed, is all quite silly. And occasionally charming, too, in its wilfully old-fashioned way.
Violet is deft and rigorous, oblique to the point of inscrutability.
The film is concerned not only with the ways in which racism manifests itself, but the ways in which it tends to be effaced -- chiefly from the privileged who deny that race remains an issue.

The most charitable thing you can say about This Is Where I Leave You is that it is resolutely innocuous -- a nothing of a movie, neutered and sanitary.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is the closest any film has come to apprehending Roth's fiction.
Lacking the slick cinematography and taut tension of the great man's finest work, this awkward outing feels like Shutter Island remade on the cheap by mockbuster house The Asylum.
A redundant teen-horror romp which, in the space of its slender running time, actually begins to make you pine for the return of Bella and Edward.
With an unbelievable romance, huge leaps in logic and a messy narrative structure, there's little to recommend about this film.
A film that'll give you second thoughts about relocating to that country pile.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are a couple of moments here that are as marrow-freezing as anything in Blair Witch or Paranormal Activity.
"Little White Lies" is a bit too long, but has plenty of Gallic charm.
A disturbing, fact-based look at the ways in which people can be bullied into bowing to the demands of authority figures.
"The Imposter" is one of the best films of the year.
The performances are first-rate, with Lindhardt particularly moving as a guy who's in deep denial about just how much he can expect from a relationship with an addict.
"Hello I Must Be Going" is at once an intriguing character study and a refreshingly offbeat romance.
"Life of Pi" is as enchanting as it is ambitious.
"The Big Picture" ends perhaps a bit too ambiguously, but there's something refreshing about its faith in the moviegoer's intelligence.
"The Well-Digger's Daughter" is perhaps a bit too sentimental. But the performances are so heartfelt that its occasional excesses are easily forgiven.
Perhaps the best thing about "Deadfall" is the lifelike messiness of its ending. A couple of the characters have a lot of explaining to do, and this is one case where a sequel might be in order.
Unlike too many films these days, "Zero Dark Thirty" dares to embrace complexity. And that makes it not just state-of-the-art entertainment, but a great film.
"Rust and Bone" has heart and soul.

"Admission" is one film you may not want to get into.
"No" is filmmaking of the first order.

Does it deserve to be seen? Absolutely. Just be aware of what you're getting into.
McConaughey brings to the film a heartfelt and beautifully realized angst. And Witherspoon is excellent as a woman who can't help being who she is, regardless of any pain that may cause.
As one watches it, certain questions may arise. But don't worry - the answers are fascinating.
One of the best and most courageous films of the year.
One of the best films of the year.
Sparklingly entertaining.

"Beasts of the Southern Wild" is a film to get lost in.
True Kitano fans will find its title sadly ironic.
This is a smart, moving film that's also very, very funny.
Struggles heroically, but unsuccessfully, to strike a balance between whimsy and pathos.
Visually stunning but virtually indecipherable ...
Offers an inside look at Iran in all its cultural complexity.
"The Way" might have been a bit more eventful. Still, it's good company.
"The Hedgehog" sneaks up on you with its heartfelt storytelling and sophisticated wit.
Would anyone really perpetrate a scheme as complicated and risky as Isabelle's? Not likely - but that's why we go to the movies.
Doremus delivers a tightly focused film that's all the more impressive for being improvised.

"Revenge of the Electric Car" lacks the urgency of "Who Killed the Electric Car?" But Paine's thorough knowledge of his subject, and engaging way with an interview, make the follow-up film a fun ride.

It's a well-crafted film that wears its old-fashionedness with pride.

An old-fashioned romance that's easy to like even if you have no interest in German literature, illegal duels or the more romantic aspects of committing suicide.
It's an engaging love story that should appeal to moviegoers with a flair for the offbeat.
A memorable portrait of a society and the demands it makes on those caught up in it.
This is a film that's not always easy to watch, but just about impossible to forget.

movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

This is a movie whose charm sneaks up on you, like a spy in the night.
Films often fail to capture the turmoil of being a teenager - but not this one.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a premise that seems anything but cinematic, "The End of the Tour" is an offbeat and fascinating film.

Oyelowo and Mara achieve terrific chemistry. Perhaps they'll work together again - in a better film.

In Bullock, "Crisis" has a star who makes the whole thing seem better than it probably is.

Spending time with "Irrational Man" would not be an irrational choice.
"Infinitely Polar Bear" is a much-needed reminder that the realm of film is still a place to encounter something other than comic-book scenarios.
"Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" is a must-see - and one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "I'll See You in My Dreams" is at once funny and poignant - and not just for moviegoers of a certain age.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Swank, an Oscar winner for "Boys Don't Cry" and "Million Dollar Baby," is outstanding, getting to the essence of Mary Bee's pride and pain. And in the showier role, Jones impressively peels away layers of rambunctiousness to reveal George's humanity.

What threatens to be a mere exercise in style proves to be as involving as it is inventive.
"Spectre" isn't bad - just slightly disappointing.
A thoroughly engrossing tale of conflicting agendas and thwarted ambition. In its verve and verisimilitude, the film recalls such classics of political cinema as Z and The Battle of Algiers.

movie_review_blurb: Is A Serious Man funny? Absolutely - but in much the same way as the old joke about a fellow who loved to hit his own head because it felt so good when he stopped.
No doubt some people will find Antichrist repellent. The question is whether you're open to films that are as flawed as they are ambitious.

In Hollywood, it's all about the concept, and some studio executive must have thought it would be fun to watch Adams slogging around in the Irish mud. Unfortunately, there's no accounting for taste.

Claire Denis, an acclaimed French director, makes films that defy the rules of Hollywood.

Scott keeps things tense while allowing for the occasional blast of humor.

Every Little Step never rises above being a very good showbiz documentary. But it's an engaging tribute to a groundbreaking musical.
If you really want to laugh, The Original Kings of Comedy is the picture to see.
[A] perfunctory blend of cheap shocks and fashionable murkiness.
A brilliant satire on modern American life.
Taken simply as a popcorn flick, National Treasure has its pleasures.
An indelible portrait of the contradictions of power.
A film that exceeds expectations. Without skimping on the thrills and action, Déjà Vu is surprisingly thoughtful in its observations regarding the possible repercussions of tampering with the past.
Zodiac, the latest film from director David Fincher, is among his best
Winterbottom's gritty sensibility and feel for geopolitical realities is perfect for the film. There's no room for Hollywood gloss - and no need for it.
Brad Pitt as Jesse James: Seldom has an actor been so perfectly cast.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

The White Ribbon is a stark, contemplative and hauntingly brilliant film.

Diesel is still charismatic thug Dominic Toretto, Walker is still determined cop Brian O'Conner, and the story is still dumb.
