If you're a Francophile, it may be worth a look. But it's no Moulin Rouge.
Those who seek a drama as provocative as it is captivating will find much to enjoy.
A terrific film that's not just for sports fans. Written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck, it's as insightful as it is entertaining.
Working from a screenplay by Peter Harness, director John Crowley elicits strong performances and conjures a realistic atmosphere. But the story is predictable.

Goodbye Solo is the sort of film that truly defies categorization, and that may pose a challenge to some moviegoers. But there are certain works of art to which the rules do not apply. This is one of them.

The film may be ahead of its time -- or it may just be an elaborate put-on.

Egoyan's trademark quirkiness definitely makes its presence felt.
There's also little sense of what these characters were like before reality came crashing down on them.
Suspenseful, romantic and wryly funny, "The Adjustment Bureau" is the kind of film that reaffirms one's faith in Hollywood.
Skarsgard, who is perhaps best known for "Good Will Hunting" and "Breaking the Waves," makes the most of his rich role, imbuing Ulrik with a knockabout charm.

A terrific but uncompromising film that's definitely not for everyone. It's not just that the violence is graphic, but that much of it is so mean-spirited.
"Source Code" isn't as smart or adventurous as it might have been. But as popcorn entertainment, it's right on schedule.
If the late director Krzysztof Kieslowski had made a mainstream film, it might have looked a lot like this one.
If you're looking for a frothy comedy, "Potiche" definitely has its charms.
A stylish reminder of a bygone time when historical epics were very much a part of mainstream filmmaking.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "The Beaver" isn't a perfect film, but it's challenging and original.

A strange and beautiful film.

With a little help from films like this, Fischer could trade her small-screen fame for multiplex stardom.

Put aside any hang-ups you may have about subtitles. As action flicks go, "Point Blank" is right on target.

Maintains a wonderful balance between grit and grace.
"Brighton Rock" doesn't rise to classic status, but it's an intriguing mood piece.

Portman hasn't been this good since her early performances in The Professional and Heat, and is deservedly attracting intense Oscar buzz. Kunis brings to Lily a savvy sexiness, and Cassel is entertainingly smarmy.
A tough, raw drama about wounds that heal only gradually, if at all.
A Prophet is essential viewing for art-film buffs and crime-flick fans, but also for anyone who's looking for a great story, terrific acting and masterful filmmaking.
What starts out as a tale of serial killing quickly becomes even more sinister and complex.
Charming but insignificant.
When it comes to combining vulnerability and menace, nobody does it quite like Caine.
A thoughtful and provocative film about the way we live now.
Less than an hour and a half long, it seems to take forever to end.
In a Holofcener film, the usual rules of screenwriting do not apply, which lends her work a lifelike quality that's particularly refreshing in this era of formulaic remakes and sequels.
It's a smart, funny film that flirts with the edge.
Knight and Day is an action comedy that works. But it's also a surprisingly poignant romance. This is the summer flick you've been waiting for.
Jeunet remains one of the world's most imaginative directors. But Micmacs is a misfire.
What it has going for it, however, is a strong performance from Clarkson, who has become one of the more reliable character actors in independent film.
About the best thing that can be said for the film is that Portman and Kutcher have just enough chemistry to make its premise work.
Clooney turns in an intense performance that owes little to his usual roguish charm.
There's no denying its strong narrative or its emotional pull. And the film's computer-influenced visual style is very much of the moment.

Although Lebanon is to be congratulated for its bold visual strategy and strong antiwar stance, the film becomes claustrophobic after a while. When one of the characters finally emerges from the tank, you may find yourself as relieved as he is.

Fincher has made quite a few terrific films, from Se7en to the underrated Zodiac. But this time he's outdone himself. The Social Network is riveting from start to finish, and a master class in directing.

Allen has been criticized for leaving some of the plot lines up in the air and several characters in the lurch. But he seems to be making a point: Neat Hollywood endings are as phony and dangerous as Cristal's ramblings.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This unfortunately titled film has an offbeat charm that just about makes up for its short running time.
"Due Date" is pregnant with possibility; it's the delivery that disappoints.
Boyle is such a gifted filmmaker that, in his hands, 127 Hours is genuinely -- and unsentimentally -- inspirational.
Only Gugino, one of the most underrated actresses in Hollywood, displays emotional complexity - and do you really need that in an action flick? Actually, yes.
So deficient in the genre's essentials - such as witty dialogue, intriguing characters and surprising yet credible plot turns - that you're embarrassed for everyone involved.
"How Do You Know" is a bit slow to get started, and it's nowhere near as funny as "The Hangover." But it'll make you smile.
Seth Rogen is the Green Hornet. What else do you need to know?
The Extra Man is a disappointment coming from Berman and Pulcini, whose American Splendor was an imaginative biopic about the late comic-book author Harvey Pekar.
Disappointingly formulaic.
Helgeland clearly has a feel for the Krays' criminal milieu, but it's not long before repetition sets in. There's only so much brutality that even the most bloodthirsty audience can tolerate.
If you think they don't make movies like they used to, "Brooklyn" is glorious proof to the contrary.
A criminal waste of an ensemble cast that should have found something better to do than lend their names to such a pointless exercise.
This is a tough film that deals with serious issues, and that may hurt its box-office chances. But "Graduation" will probably be around long after less challenging fare is forgotten.
"Vol. 2" might have been a bit more focused. Still, it's an imaginative romp that once again reflects Gunn's unique and irreverent sensibility.
Norman may be a mere wannabe, but "Norman" is a small gem.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film of subtle beauty.
"The Wall" is merely an exercise in empty intensity. Watching it feels too much like being trapped in it.
Is romantic comedy dead? Not as long as the genre can accommodate a film as uniquely wonderful as "The Lovers."
Depp, who once was among the most risk-taking actors in film, seems to be merely going through the motions.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film of subtle humor and universal appeal. Just don't expect a carefree romp.
Working from her own screenplay, director Robin Swicord delivers a film that balances wry humor and sly introspection.
If you have a soft spot for dogs, this is a love story you'll find irresistible.
"My Cousin Rachel" is more of an exercise in style than an adventure in emotion. In the competition for the multiplex dollar, it's relatively unmemorable.
As a performer, Lister-Jones acquits herself well on both the comedic and melodramatic fronts. And the scruffily charming Pally comes across as a hybrid of Seth Rogen and Paul Rudd.
"Beatriz at Dinner" is a meal of a film, with plenty to chew on.
It's the kind of action-comedy that makes you want to see it again a second after it's over.
It's one of his finest and most memorable performances. Unfortunately, the script fails to rise to the level of Elliott's artistry.
Another big-screen adaptation of this story probably wasn't necessary. But as unnecessary films go, it's well worth a look.
"The Big Sick" has a lot of charm.
"Maudie" is a work of art.
"Valerian" has some cool visuals. But there's more to science fiction than pretty pictures.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Seldom has a film so eloquently captured the craziness, brutality and arbitrariness of war. "Dunkirk" just might be Nolan's masterpiece.
You may not understand "A Ghost Story." But you won't forget it.
"Atomic Blonde" is no James Bond adventure, but it's sure to satisfy action junkies.
If you long for a film in the tradition of such grown-up entertainments as "Lawrence of Arabia" and "The English Patient," this is one to get lost in.
Diesel and Johnson are at their testosterone-charged best. Theron, who seems to be auditioning to become the next Bond villain, is ruthlessness personified.
"Gifted" is an engaging comedy-drama that avoids becoming too much of a tearjerker.
Young children will be entertained, but for the rest of the audience, pretty colors just aren't enough.
It's a perfect vehicle for Driver, who endearingly captures the hangdog humility of his character.
This may not be Scorsese's best film, but it's unquestionably his most impassioned.
Far from being exploitative, "Patriots Day" honors the Bostonians who responded to terrorism with strength.
Not just another biopic, "The Founder" is a morality tale that raises provocative questions about consumer culture, its benefits and its consequences. You won't look at a Big Mac the same way again.
"20th Century Women" takes a while to kick in but eventually finds its groove.
"Gold" is a major disappointment - a film of admirable ambition but woefully underwhelming execution.
"Julieta" is a paean to longing, regret and the often painful experience of being human.
A film so low in energy that it's almost as if it was made to assist airline passengers in falling asleep.
Despite considerable progress, the film suggests, much work remains to be done - and Baldwin's voice remains as relevant as ever.
Reeves is thoroughly persuasive as a killer who takes pride in his expertise. The role he began with 2014's "John Wick" is tailor-made for his laconic acting style.
Hosseini is impressive as a man who feels compelled to take action, regardless of the ramifications. And Alidoosti persuasively embodies Rana's pain.
A fascinating portrait of empowerment gone awry.
Hüller is amusingly discombobulated as the uptight Ines. But the film is perhaps best appreciated as a showcase for the gifted Simonischek, whose portrayal of Winfried/Toni is one for the ages.
There's no dialogue, the pace is quite slow and the meaning of the story is subject to interpretation. Yet once you're on its wavelength, the film is a mesmerizing experience.
If being seated at Table 19 is a drag, watching the film of the same name is worse.
If this is indeed Jackman's final appearance as Logan, he's going out in style.
If you're looking for a film that offers pure escapism, "Kong: Skull Island" should definitely meet expectations.
If you thought it was a bad idea to mess with a classic, "Beauty and the Beast" will persuade you that a tale as old as time is worth retelling.
"The Sense of an Ending" does not provide easy answers. But it raises intriguing questions.
"Wilson" isn't a bad film, but it could have used less melodrama and a lot more insight.
Assayas is among France's most respected filmmakers, but just what he was attempting to do with this film is something of a mystery.
Some moviegoers will find the experience frustrating; others will be exhilarated by a film that's far afield from the usual formulas.
"The Zookeeper's Wife" is little more than an old-fashioned melodrama, but for some moviegoers that will be enough.

Caine deftly balances world-weariness and stoic resolve. Freeman virtually radiates hard-won wisdom. And Arkin, as usual, is the ultimate curmudgeon. Together, they create a dynamic not unlike that of a jazz combo in which each player is fully engaged.
Oyelowo captures Seretse's quiet dignity while also hinting at the limits of his patience. And Pike is compelling as a woman who rises to the occasion regardless of the circumstances.
It's worth seeing for Affleck's charismatic performance and for its vision of America as a land of greed, violence and political expediency that some moviegoers will find all too familiar.
Relentless in its storytelling, "Detroit" is a film of blistering impact.
An informative documentary that's certain to bolster awareness of an ongoing cause for alarm.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Most films, especially mainstream ones, are about the forces that whirl around characters. "Novitiate" grapples with what's going on inside them.
"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is entertaining in a way that's practically unheard of these days.
Neither an indictment nor an endorsement of war, "Last Flag Flying" reclaims patriotism as a uniter, not a divider.
This origin story relies far too heavily on the Dickens tale without adding much interest.
Franco delivers a comedy that's delightfully offbeat. It probably helps if you've actually seen "The Room," but you can safely spare yourself that experience.
Far from being a dry biopic, "Darkest Hour" reminds us that some things - such as honor and freedom - are worth fighting for.
"The Shape of Water" is one of the best films of the year.
In a world bursting with flashy popcorn movies, there's still nothing quite like a "Star Wars" flick.
Like the fairground ride for which it's named, "Wonder Wheel" is entertaining but not enlightening.
The film is best appreciated as a showcase for Jackman, who makes a dazzling Barnum and holds on to our sympathies even as the character proves to be something of a heel.
"Call Me By Your Name" is a visually stunning coming-of-age story that boasts a star-making performance by Chalamet.
The film then wanders into murky, puzzling territory, leaving viewers to wonder exactly what the story was all about.
This tale of an unscrupulous and egocentric billionaire couldn't possibly be timelier.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a "Game" that couldn't be more fun to watch.
"Phantom Thread" is the kind of film that's rarely made anymore - uncompromising, sophisticated and smart.
Starts off as a smart thriller in the Hitchcock tradition. Unfortunately, the film soon goes off the rails.
In an era in which journalistic outlets are increasingly accused of delivering "fake news," this film is a reminder that few things are as precious - and vital - as the truth.
Anyone interested in the ways in which diplomacy works - and how it sometimes doesn't - will find the documentary educational and perhaps even enlightening.
"12 Strong" lacks depth but fulfills its mission to entertain.
Clearly influenced by classic Westerns, particularly the films of director John Ford, "Hostiles" is a worthy addition to the genre.
Bening is outstanding as a woman who fears that her fame and beauty are slipping away, and Bell ("Billy Elliot") brings to his character a heartbreaking vulnerability.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Believe the hype: "Black Panther" transcends its comic-book origins, achieving a mythic grandeur that's nothing short of exhilarating.
"Happy End" is an art film in the classic sense - ambitious, provocative and hard to shake off.
Lots of movies are set to be popping up in multiplexes, but few as wonderful as "Lady Bird."
A film in which solid storytelling is neglected in favor of grandiose but ultimately empty special effects.
"Wonder" is a family film in the best sense.
This is the feel-bad film of the year. Recommend it to someone you hate.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You may not agree with the politics of "Whose Streets?" But its power and passion are undeniable.
Larson turns in an engaging performance as a woman uncertain about just who she wants to be. But Harrelson comes close to upstaging her, imbuing Rex with a bold and intriguing complexity.
Perhaps "Logan Lucky" is best appreciated as a stealth commentary on tough times in America. It takes a director of Soderbergh's gifts to actually make that funny.
Although "13 Minutes" is a period piece, it addresses issues that continue to resonate in society.
A stylish drama that assumes a reasonable amount of gray matter on the part of the viewer.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This film may not exactly be a "Good Time," but it's an interesting one.
Stanfield deftly balances rage and resignation, and Asomugha is impressive as a crusader who refuses to give up.
If you're looking for a film that's guaranteed to have you gripping your seat, this is "It."
This is a movie that Holden would have skipped.
"Spotlight" isn't quite as good as "All The President's Men," the gold standard of films about journalism. But it's close.
This is the rare mainstream film that addresses the complexities of real life. "Brad's Status" may motivate you to question your own.
This film will give you a new appreciation for the freedoms that are often taken for granted in a democracy.
"Stronger" could have been little more than a melodrama. Instead, it's a surprisingly gritty film about refusing to give up, regardless of the odds.
This is mainstream filmmaking at the top of its game.
"Blade Runner 2049" is not just a movie but an event. Don't be the only human on your block not to see it.
Some of the plot turns seem a bit too convenient, and the film goes on for too long. But ultimately, it's a showcase for a pair of excellent actors who elevate the material.
"Marshall" is one of the freshest and most entertaining films of the year.
"Breathe" is obvious Oscar bait, but its engaging story and appealing cast make that agenda easy to excuse.
The cast is first-rate, notably Neeson in the title role. "Mark Felt" benefits mightily from his very particular set of acting skills.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hall ... delivers an understated drama that makes its points without preachiness. If the film doesn't quite achieve greatness, it's nonetheless heartfelt.
If you're merely out for a good time at the movies, you can safely skip "Suburbicon." But true film buffs will want to peek behind the blinds of Clooney's latest directorial endeavor.
If your goal is to spend a few hours escaping from reality, "Thor: Ragnarok" is definitely for you.
Although Branagh delivers a film that's reasonably watchable, the not-so-mysterious truth is that "Murder on the Orient Express" didn't need to be remade.
Those who are merely looking for a flick that goes well with popcorn may be bored, but true cinema buffs will be in heaven.
"American Made" is a stinging critique of U.S. foreign policy disguised as a freewheeling action comedy.
"Hidden Figures" is a feel-good film of incalculable charm.
Naysayers will no doubt argue that "mother!" is an incomprehensible mess. But as sheer visceral filmmaking, it's a must-see.
Get over your subtitle phobia and check out one of the best films of the year.
This is the kind of intelligent, thought-provoking mainstream film that's in danger of becoming extinct. "Eye in the Sky" is miles above the average multiplex flick.
If you've ever been hopelessly in love - and who among us hasn't? - you'll likely recognize some part of yourself in the unrealistic but upbeat Doris.
Snyder delivers a superhero epic that's a significant improvement on his work on its predecessor, "Man of Steel."
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's not necessary to be a jazz fan to get lost in this poetic and poignant film.
If you're interested in Williams and his music, this film is better than nothing - but not by much.
Offbeat and unpredictable, "Demolition" takes a wrecking ball to audience expectations.
"Barbershop: The Next Cut" combines the broad comedy that moviegoers have come to expect from the franchise with social commentary that's surprisingly effective.
With its combination of state-of-the-art technology and old-school charm, "The Jungle Book" should thrill children and adults alike.
Psychological thrillers just don't get any better than this.
It's true that not much happens - except cinema at its finest.
At its best, "Keanu" is reminiscent of Woody Allen's early, funny films such as "Take the Money and Run" and "Bananas," which were also uneven but frequently hilarious.
With its intriguing characters and exhilarating music, "Sing Street" is the best film about being young, gifted and Irish since "The Commitments."
To the short list of superhero flicks that exceed expectations, add "Captain America: Civil War."
Much like its main character, "The Meddler" exudes an irresistible charm.
The multiplexes are full of films that promise little more than a forgettable good time. "The Man Who Knew Infinity" is just as entertaining, but far more substantial.
Does it include scenes that some may find painful to watch? You bet. Will you be entertained? Thoroughly.
"A Bigger Splash"? More like a small trickle.
"X-Men: Apocalypse" isn't a catastrophe, but you may find it lacking.
A delightful comic romp that fans of the classic English author will love.
If you're open to embracing a film that declines to pander to expectations, you should definitely make a date with "The Lobster."
"Sunset Song" is not without flaws, but it's an art film of uncommon beauty.
Although at slightly less than 90 minutes the film seems too long, it's an impressive showcase for Samberg's oddly endearing brand of comic cluelessness.
It's an old-fashioned tale of an individual overcoming the odds - only in this case, that individual happens to be a horse.
This is the kind of film that makes moviegoers long for good, old-fashioned storytelling.
"Embrace of the Serpent" is film at its most ambitious and uncompromising.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you think foreign films can't compete with Hollywood when it comes to delivering popcorn entertainment, prepare to be carried away by "The Wave."
There's a sharp comedy to be made about America's misadventures in Afghanistan. This isn't it.
"A Monster Calls" is the rare film that addresses the mysteries of childhood without succumbing to schmaltz.
Often, extending a movie franchise signifies a lack of imagination. But "Creed" is a knockout.
"Chi-Raq" doesn't always work, but it's a film that dares to take chances.
"Macbeth" takes liberties with the particulars of the Shakespeare play, but is fascinatingly true to its spirit.
The most compelling onscreen presence is the whale- who, unlike the rest of the cast, is spared the wooden dialogue.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ridley, Boyega and Isaac make equally charismatic heroes, and Driver is surprisingly effective as the sinister Ren. Star Wars: The Force Awakens is commercial American moviemaking at its best. May the Force be with it.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Only when the camera is on Vikander does the film transcend its artifice. In one of the year's best performances, she imbues Gerda with such poignancy and grace that Redmayne all but fades into the background.
Far from being a dry economics lesson, "The Big Short" is an unsparing look at corporate skullduggery and its consequences - and the rare mainstream film with political bite.

"The Hateful Eight" is a cinema buff's dream - and unlike anything else in theaters this season. But that's only to be expected from Quentin Tarantino, one of the few directors with the clout to pursue his vision wherever it takes him.
"Carol" demonstrates that a period piece can engagingly comment on modern times.
If you're looking for a film that's just about guaranteed to make you feel good, you'd be well advised to drop by "Daddy's Home."
Chu is more craftsman than poet, but the charismatic ensemble cast engages in the trickery with style.
Boldly original, "The Revenant" puts everything else playing at the multiplexes in the shade.
With spot-on vocal performances from Thewlis, Leigh and Tom Noonan, the film is nothing less than mesmerizing - and must viewing for serious cinephiles.
Ultimately, "Mojave" is little more than a B movie with pretensions.
Daringly unsentimental, "45 Years" makes a persuasive case that marriage demands not only patience, but guts.
"The Lady in the Van" doesn't pretend to be anything more than a pleasant diversion. And on that level, it succeeds.
Hollywood craziness would seem to be ideal grist for the Coen Brothers' absurdist mill. Unfortunately, "Hail, Caesar!" comes across as far less than the sum of its parts.
Smart, sexy and outrageous, "Deadpool" delivers.
Ultimately, "Where to Invade Next" questions whether America has cast aside values that the rest of the world has come to embrace.
James makes for a charismatic hero, and former "Saturday Night Live" star Sudeikis is a revelation as the steadfast Snyder.
[Eggers] proves to be an original and accomplished storyteller with much more to offer than cheap shocks.
"A War" is an emotionally complex film that doesn't play by the rules of mainstream cinema.
Although "Triple 9" was most likely just a paycheck film for all involved, its go-for-the-gut efficiency can't be denied.
As cop comedies go, "Ride Along 2" gets the job done. But this sequel to the 2014 hit comes across as a significantly less funny rehash.
Maggie's plan may or may not work out. But as a smart, perceptive commentary on modern times, "Maggie's Plan" succeeds beautifully.
A jazzy and unconventional tribute to an American icon, "Miles Ahead" is quite a ride.
Those interested in Wolfe and his enduring legacy would be better off reading one of his novels than seeing this film.
Fresh and delightfully offbeat, "The Accountant" proves that a thriller can be complex and nuanced while fulfilling its mission to entertain.
A well-crafted horror film with strong performances and a palpable sense of time and place.
"Keeping Up With the Joneses" is hardly worth the effort.
"Certain Women" requires patience from the viewer and isn't for anyone, but it's a film of quiet and lingering beauty.
In his third performance as Langdon, Hanks has little to do but look distressed, bewildered or flabbergasted. His greatest acting challenge may have been keeping a straight face.
This is as good as popcorn entertainment gets.
Working from a screenplay by Eric Heisserer, director Denis Villeneuve creates a richly imagined world in which the theme of extraterrestrial outreach is addressed with a refreshing dignity.
Basking in this "Moonlight" is one of the cinematic joys of the year.
A beautiful film about daring to love, without fear or compromise.
This halftime walk is more like a long slog.
What might have been a cynical cash grab is a delightful romp through new but equally spellbinding territory.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Some may consider "American Honey" too long and more than a bit repetitive. But Arnold's not after a mere snapshot. Her aim is nothing less than a mural of contemporary American life.
An old-fashioned film that slyly nods to contemporary sensibilities, "Allied" is an engaging showcase for Pitt and Cotillard.
The best that can be said for this film is that it's short.
Audiences should find "Dory" one of Pixar's most charming achievements.
This party is a dud.
If you've been wondering how Washington really works, this film is required viewing.
"Rogue One" spins "Star Wars" into a whole new orbit.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Collateral Beauty" is based on a premise so preposterous that the film shouldn't work. But the illusion of credibility is sustained just well enough to keep things from falling apart.
At a time when musicals seldom grace the big screen, "La La Land" is practically a miracle.
Portman is simply brilliant, getting to the essence of Jackie without resorting to a mere impersonation.
The film eventually runs out of rocket fuel, piling on the special effects but arriving at a disappointing conclusion.
"Lion" is a family film in the best sense.
"Fences" is perhaps best appreciated as a showcase for the brilliant acting of Washington and Davis. Their performances are virtually guaranteed to garner Oscar nominations.
Ford delivers a tiresomely weird drama that's pitched somewhere between the cinematic realms of directors David Lynch.
"Denial" is a flawed but impassioned film that deals in big ideas.
"Manchester by the Sea" is one of the best films of the year.
"Deepwater Horizon" is a tribute to heroism and a warning against corporate greed.
"Free State of Jones" aspires to greatness but fumbles badly.
Although the story becomes increasingly complex as it goes along, the emotional payoff is more than worth it.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cenedella may never become a household name, but "Art Bastard" argues persuasively that fame is overrated.
It's a film that casts a unique and often mesmerizing spell. But it's also a bit too talky, particularly in the early going, and Spielberg lets numerous opportunities for humor slip by.
If you've been looking for a film that puts a daringly surreal spin on "Cast Away," you'll be in paradise.
Just because a story actually happened doesn't mean it will make for compelling cinema. This is a prime example.
McCarthy, Wiig, McKinnon and Jones prove to be a relentlessly inventive comic ensemble. And Hemsworth is a revelation as a guy who's blissfully unaware of his sheer incompetence.
Lin seems most concerned with keeping things moving, and on that score he succeeds.
The film's title, suggesting a comic-book flick, will likely cause box-office confusion. But in a way, it's appropriate. "Captain Fantastic" is a truly heroic effort.
Damon is terrific as the impressively skilled yet poignantly haunted Bourne. Jones is malevolence personified as Dewey. And Vikander lends a steely confidence to Lee.
"Eat That Question" may be of most interest to Zappa fans, but newcomers to the man and his music may also find it well worth a look.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A love story drenched in nostalgia, "Café Society" is a film of rare beauty.
At a time when even niche films are virtually scrubbed clean of any traces of eccentricity, Solondz's downbeat vision of humanity is downright refreshing.
It's not necessary to be a classical-music buff to be charmed by this thoroughly entertaining film that never hits a false note.
Only when there's an opportunity to blow things up does Fuqua seem fully engaged.
"Suicide Squad" is an interminable muddle.
Gordon-Levitt turns in an Oscar-worthy performance as a man who's all too aware of what he's letting himself in for. And Woodley skillfully balances a range of emotions as Lindsay.
"Sully" is the kind of film that may be described as old-fashioned and never goes out of style.
What redeems "Queen of Katwe" is the performance of Oyelowo, who imbues Katende with an exhilarating blend of humor and humanity.
Rarely has a film more eloquently captured the universality of human experience.
"Hands of Stone" isn't a knockout of a film, but it's light on its feet and throws a lot of good punches.
Much more than a genre piece, "Hell or High Water" takes you places that you thought the big screen had forgotten.

Working from a screenplay that he co-wrote with Stephen Chin and Jason Smilovic, Phillips delivers a film that raises provocative questions about the economic imperatives of war while masquerading as a buddy comedy.
Despite its flaws, "Complete Unknown" raises provocative questions about the nature of identity and whether it's more a comfort or a trap.
Well acted, often tense and certainly atmospheric!
Miss Potter is for moviegoers who are drawn more to the delightful than the destructive. It's undeniably refreshing to see a PG-rated movie for adults done so well.
To our utter delight, these stories and messages are told with superb acting, amazing costumes that burst with color and texture, and dazzling locales.
While there are many of the right ingredients here -- a likable cast, plot potential, a dreamy English countryside setting -- I still can't say "I do" to this fluffy flick.
Romantic comedies have been a bit of a dying breed in recent years. Perhaps that's why it's so delightful to see The Holiday tucked amidst all the war and gore at the cineplex.
A fun romp of a flick that showcases the power of dance and the human spirit.
God may be tired of us, but if these men's lives are any indication, he certainly isn't finished with us.
A light and airy confection, only a bit too sweet and with a few ingredients missing.
You could see the film as the making of Crazy Dog Lady or as the story of a bereaved woman finding her true passion in life. Personally, I lean toward the former.
Not just another bratty teen movie, but one that delves into the intriguing and heartbreaking reasons behind the brattiness.
If you want a romantic comedy that's mostly charming and doesn't insult your intelligence or morals, I suggest this light, heartwarming summer fare--with just a few reservations.
One can only hope that Becoming Jane will inspire moviegoers to find out more about this beloved literary great. Or hopefully revisit one of her classic novels.
Mirren's facial expressions are the true genius. Watching disturbing realizations dance across a face that's been trained for decades to be a study in stoicism is a wonder.
Hopefully, well-crafted and moving films such as Darfur Now will inspire more people to take that small but significant first step toward ending these atrocities.
There's so much more possible than what's being offered here. In that sense, The Astronaut Farmer doesn't aim or dream nearly high enough.
Four friends on a quest to find something, only to realize that anything resembling an answer is to be found in the journey itself, in their friendships, and in themselves.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Lots of heart, eye candy, and likable characters, but its lack of more grit, believability, and substance stops it from truly inspiring.
Ironically, this therapeutic romantic comedy ultimately suffers from too many unexplored issues.
It is delightful to watch these kids dance, especially knowing the evil they've experienced. Their bright smiles are a true testament to the resiliency of the human spirit.
A fun voyeuristic peek into the world of high fashion . . . If you're looking for a light-hearted romp down the runway, The Devil Wears Prada is a perfect fit.

Throughout this fifth-grade Fear Factor, there are scattered lessons on the ills of bullying, the benefit of being true to yourself, the joy of true friendship. But really, what boy is going to remember a moral when there's an exploding worm?
The most stunning beauty comes in human connections, physical touch, unconditional acceptance, familial love - in the treacherous and tender terrain of the human heart.
Words and letters may hold all the secrets of the universe, but 104 minutes wasn't enough to hold and resolve all the secrets and mysteries of Bee Season.
The movie feels a lot like slacker brother Ben: a little sloppy, mostly predictable, some flashes of poignancy and wisdom, but ultimately doesn't live up to its potential.
The 1996 original is classier, deeper, more poignant. A Ginger Rogers to this Beyoncé.
If you enjoy the charming wit of films such as An Ideal Husband or Enchanted April, you'll probably be Wilde about A Good Woman.
In the end, lazy scriptwriting leads to a lukewarm verdict.
I wanted a moral to the story. In Finding Nemo: Don't let fear rule your life. Shrek: True beauty is on the inside. Madagascar: Don't eat your friends?
The overall effect is not so unlike Mameha's description of geisha themselves: a moving work of art.
I wouldn't call the movie a dog, but I didn't love it either. Our search for the next Great Romantic Comedy, like so many Hollywood singletons' quest for love, continues.
Though tough and heavy-handed at times, North Country is engaging -- not one of those films about an important subject matter that you feel you should watch.
Luminous visuals, subtle thematic statements, and fine acting. A lovely period piece that surely will stand the test of time.
If you had three weeks left to live, I wouldn't recommend you spend your precious time watching this.
The plot holes and formulaic feel are overcome by the superb acting. As is true in the world of debate, carefully chosen and delivered words win the day.
If you like sweet, safe tales of triumph, Secretariat is a sure bet. But if you like films with a bit more tension and complexity, this romp doesn't completely satisfy.
A cautionary tale of what unchecked ambition and lust can do to a person, a family, a nation.
I can't remember the last time I was in a movie theater audience that clapped. Twice. Even I clapped. It's that good.
This movie haunted me for days; it felt like it left an icky residue on my mind and soul, and I didn't enjoy it. Those who like being creeped out by movies will disagree.
Interesting commentary on how we deal with difficult situations, and makes a strong case for our desperate need for each other -- especially when the odds are stacked against us.
The film stayed with me for a bit, and I liked that. The movie makes you think - about what is, about what could have been, about what could be.
At the end of this intelligent romantic comedy we realize that it's people who are crazy and stupid, and love is this precious gift that's worth fighting for.
The Help's greatest strength lies in showing how the truth-no matter how difficult it is to tell at times-has the power to unite, to heal, and sometimes even to set us free.

Make no mistake, The Whistleblower isn't an easy film to watch. But the horrors aren't in your face. And Larysa Kondracki... walks a careful line between showing us the devastating realities of trafficking and then offering us hope...
It's like a cartoon root canal for your brain.
Imagine Beauty and the Beast rewritten by a pack of teen girls high on Twilight and Gossip Girl, and you get an idea of what you're in for with Beastly.
A great springboard for faith-oriented conversations about free will fate, and the role of a higher power in our lives.
A film titled Eat Pray Love should at least capture a spiritual experience and offer romance with some sizzle. This felt more like Eat Grieve Befriend.
With SATC2 we were supposed to get a peek at what's next. Instead we got a fanciful vacation and a lame and fluffy version of female power.
A fascinating documentary, a celebration of human life, a mother's love, and the wondrous world into which each of us was born.
Hopefully films like this grow our understanding and compassion as we're encouraged to offer Christ-like hope in our broken world, and emulate a resiliency that is Precious.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A bit more of Coco becoming Chanel was what I expected, and what would have elevated this film beyond the typical period-piece love story fare.
Joe says in a voice-over that "life is a journey to be traveled no matter how bad the road." And The Boys Are Back is a highly satisfying ride.
A slightly incomplete, though mostly rewarding, education.
By the end, I finally cared about Henry and Clare. But I wish the filmmakers had pulled me in about an hour and a half sooner.
A quirky, mostly endearing commentary on love in a postmodern age.
A feast of winning characters, sumptuous food, loving marriages, and strong women who stumble, laugh, cry, write and, of course, cook their way into our hearts.
Seeing this kind of injustice makes me feel challenged by Proverbs 31:8, 'Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves; ensure justice for those who are perishing.'
There are good intentions here, and good ingredients. But the sum total feels less like a passionate lover and more like a passing crush.
We want the characters to help us sigh dreamily while the credits roll. Harvey provides that plus relatable emotion, endearing comedy, and stellar acting.
A fun, cinematic Currier and Ives experience for the whole family that will leave you hugging on Dad and Grandma%u2014and eager to return home to hug on your own Marley or Rover or Rex.
With meaty themes and compelling characters, Bees is a rich, emotional exploration of the redeeming power of love and the transforming comfort of home.
Typical Sparks formula: difficult circumstances, unlikely love, delirious joy, gut-wrenching tragedy, and redemptive moral. Unfortunately, this film doesn't deliver the goods.
SATC offers well-developed characters, smart dialogue, interesting plots and sub-plots, and a ton of heart.
An impressive directorial debut for Helen Hunt that takes an intelligent look at the ways we survive unspeakable grief and play hide and seek with love.
The group is a testament to the healing capabilities of music. The choir itself deserves four stars; if the film had delivered the same grit and poignancy, it would have too.
The Artist is an absurdly anachronistic film in our age of 3-D cinematic assault. It's silent. It's black and white. And it's delightful.
This is a fluff film you rent on a rainy day when you want some cute, mindless entertainment. If that's all you're looking for, this is right on the money.
There's not as much ingenuity, originality and spark as there was in a single thirty-minute episode of The Office.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie that will be enjoyed heartily and repeatedly. Oh, and you'll be surprised at just how funny watching Batman wait on his microwave is.
It gets the "Losers Club" right, and this eclectic little group more than compensates for the movie's shortcomings.

A marvel of tightly controlled pacing, off-kilter visuals, and rich atmosphere, Peele's film owes a good deal of its exquisite shocks to the claustrophobic terrors of Rosemary's Baby and the manicured dread of Bryan Forbes's The Stepford Wives.
In No Place on Earth, director Janet Tobias explores this profound discovery, shedding light on a incredible story of endurance.
Emotionally moving but messy, it survives thanks to its superb songs, great cinematography and insightful anecdotes - in spite of its lack of a satisfactory conclusion.

Writer-director Ron Judkins' movie is so tone deaf, badly paced, poorly scored and amateurishly acted that the only thing you'll be finding is the door when you walk out early from this clunker of a dramedy.
This is one part of traditional farming that needs to die, but the doc rarely editorializes, and it deserves credit for that.
I overheard fellow critics describe Yellow as a vastly entertaining train wreck. Well, this is one train I'd like to be on - just give me a seat belt.
In typical Wes Anderson fashion, its impeccable design and je ne sais quoi will win you over.
A mysterious, sensual prism through which to view our own shortcomings and longings.
There's no cat, and the roof may not be made of tin, but it's plenty hot thanks to Meryl Streep and Julia Roberts.
It's a beautiful and melancholy tale told in a deliberate, intelligent style but, regrettably, lacking in urgency and passion thanks to writing and performances that often keep us at arm's length.
The sweetest and most magical film of the year.
Likeable and engaging despite its overly long running time, sloppy screenplay and rambling structure.
Months of Frances' life pass in minutes, yet those minutes feel like an eternity, thanks to non-action and uninspired editing.
Payne just doesn't make bad movies. Until now.
Pilate predicts that, following his death, Jesus will be forgotten in a week. Though those words proved preposterously untrue, they somehow seem fitting for this film.
Instead of fully exploring the vulnerability and fragility of the characters, Forev offers too many ridiculous, unfunny scenarios on the way to a somewhat honest and effective ending.

Eddie Redmayne is so convincing as famous physicist Stephen Hawking that you will likely be unable to separate the two men in your mind once this genuinely moving, if slightly maudlin, film flickers to a finish.
Pray's film, though not as weighty or groundbreaking - no pun intended - as its subject, nevertheless does a good job of presenting both art and artist ...
movie_title: Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Lunchbox is honest and touching, and features a pitch-perfect performance by Khan, whom American audiences might remember from Life of Pi and Slumdog Millionaire.
The Railway Man is uneven, choppy and unimpactful at times, but the slow pacing and melodrama work fairly well and build to an interesting, competent climax.

"How awful that everything has to be so trivial," Joe says. Maybe life has to be trivial, but movies don't, unless you're a certain Danish director who wants to force his psychosis on the viewing public.

"How awful that everything has to be so trivial," Joe says. Maybe life has to be trivial, but movies don't, unless you're a certain Danish director who wants to force his psychosis on the viewing public.
Only Lovers is on par with Jarmusch's Down by Law, which also failed to capitalize on its considerable strengths.
A Most Wanted Man is a smart, gripping thriller that carefully navigates its way through subtle twists and delicious ambiguity.
Despite the wrinkles in Linklater's time tapestry, he has given us one of the most memorable movies of the year, and probably his own masterpiece.

All I'm left with from Them are the memories of a great-but-squandered premise and a film so uninspired in its editing and rambling in its presentation that it, like its title character, almost disappears.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly touching, if not particularly original, dramedy ...
Dear white people (and members of all other races), avoid this movie, as it doesn't do much more for race relations than Lars von Trier's Nymphomaniac did for the issue of sexual addiction.
Even if you don't like Birdman, you will be unable to forget its unique ability to disguise meticulous, well-rehearsed craftsmanship as irresistible improvisation.

Rodriguez's film would be nothing without Sorvino, as the veteran actor seems born to play this part.

movie_review_blurb: Not everyone will view it as an informational feast, but Beatle fans will eat it up like jam butties.
Becomes the last thing you would expect from a film with this title or indeed from any Plympton film: boring.
It's just humanity at its most basic.

Though director Anne Fontaine's French-language production is essentially a one-note conceit, it's able to coast on its charm, overcoming its almost total lack of a second act and other story deficiencies.
Spends so much time being cleverly hip and spoofing all things Disney that it struggles to find its own identity.
Perhaps Reitman was so desperate to create the next Ghostbusters and to take advantage of Duchovny's X-Files appeal that he forgot to read the embarrassingly awful script.
To get any enjoyment out of the original, you had to leave your brains at home. With the sequel, remember to leave your stomachs, too.
Works because it takes a great idea and combines it with inventive imagery and the oddball charm of Bill Murray.
Woody Allen's latest film does involve a curse, but it's less the curse of a scorpion than one of awkward acting and heavy-handed one-liners.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The only positive aspect of Jay and Bob's idiocy is our knowledge that this is apparently their last hurrah.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A laughable gorefest and a leading contender for the title Worst Film of the Year.
Though its creepy, well-filmed first half fuels this psychological process, Jeepers Creepers degenerates from a realistic and frightening story into silly supernatural shenanigans.
For all its dramatic and historical gaffes, From Hell rarely fails to entertain.
Dazzles with humor and spectacular visuals that are worlds apart from Shrek and Atlantis.
Moodysson creates a topsy-turvy, sexually charged environment but ultimately can't fuse together the separate characters' lives into a captivating tale.
The whole macabre piece comes across as uneven.
Gone are many of the story's complexities and its spiritual overtones, replaced by an odd mix of drama, music and comedy designed to entertain the kids and distract the adults from the mediocrity.

Despite being a bit flat at times and not taking us through all the highs and lows Drake experienced, the film succeeds by bringing us close to its subject, leaving us wanting more and not being afraid to be subtle.
movie_title: A Skin Too Few: The Days of Nick Drake (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An insightful, touching and amusing three-generational study that is anything but sophomoric.
I've always wondered whether Tarantino would finally grow up. But after seeing his latest spectacular, bloody mess of a movie, frankly, I don't give a damn.
Hyde Park on Hudson succeeds not in spite of, but largely because of, Murray's endearing, if slightly unbelievable, performance as President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
A clever concept squandered on a mediocre screenplay and an inexperienced director.
Dorothy was right: There's no place like home. And that's exactly where you should see this film: on TV, for free, instead of paying for it in a theater.
See the movie for what it is: an exciting, visual celebration of love, life and longing.

One of the most powerful and socially relevant movies of the year.
The film falls flat on its face as many times as its murdered characters and ends up as a barbaric waste of time, lacking any genuine scares or unique qualities.

Simply runs out of good ideas and, like a nominee behind in the polls, starts throwing anything and everything at the voters/audience to see what sticks. Not much does.

Monsters University is the leading contender for best movie of the summer and top animated film of the year.

The smart, surreal premise slowly, slowly unravels into schlock.

Lacking the novelty of the 1933 original and the style and wonder of the 2005 Peter Jackson remake, this Kong is just plain unnecessary.

Though the screenplay, direction and performances never reach a level of intelligence one would hope for, the film hits enough right notes to recommend a viewing, especially for those with a soft spot for animals and an interest in military stories.

Introducing intrigue to the film's structural simplicity are the dreamy visual flourishes of cinematographer Wyatt Garfield. Thanks also goes to editor Jay Deuby for keeping Dinner's courses to a minimum.
Having not seen all of Elliott's performances over his 50-year career, I can't say definitively that this is his best. But it sure feels like it.
Go ahead and engrave the Oscar now, for this is the best film of the year and one of the 10 greatest of the century.

Just when we thought the stale "coming-of-age" film was on a precipitous slide, along comes the most unlikely of lifelines.
What really sets the film apart from the recent slate of abysmal holiday fare is its sweetness, good intentions and solid supporting performances.
Lands awkwardly somewhere between comedy and drama, and nowhere near the poignancy toward which it was striving.
A visual symphony of performance, pacing, editing, cinematography and music that only Wright and perhaps three or four other directors are capable of conducting.
An impressive and sometimes mesmerizing directorial debut.

Aforementioned imperfections notwithstanding, Condon and his team have breathed new life into a "tale as old as time."

movie_review_blurb: Admittedly, this can be viewed as simply another rehash of old stories and themes, but hash is rarely this tasty.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Most movie creatures are better left alone. But this is one monster call you should answer.

A unique, subtle, almost uncomfortably intimate look at the way we perceive ourselves and others.

Clunky, contrived and embarrassingly overwritten - a philosophical exercise rather than an engaging motion picture.
A touching, dramatic imagining of the final, feeble days of the super sleuth.
A quirky yet moving meditation on the life we discover during death.

Strangely entertaining and revealing documentary about a culture obsessed with money and people aspiring to a life they can't afford. Greed is good once again if you can borrow enough money to consume all you desire. Mind the debt gap.
A film that expertly paddles through the complicated subconscious and repressed feelings of a faltering comedian

Remarkable and engaging piece of filmmaking considering the outcome of the story is well known. A sign of the times we live in and the processes put in place to wrangle the people that choose to live outside the realm of civility

A bittersweet pill that's a mixture of an endearing family drama and modern romance that's an absolute delight.

The murder mystery has been given a stylish medical makeover

Powerful piece of cinema that forces us to confront death and something even worse; the prospect of outliving the love of one's life

Obsessed with how clever it thinks it is that it completely sinks the romantic comedy pirate ship it sets forth to be

Insightful and explosive examination of humanity

A reminder that the journey has been a murmur rather than a saga, and the final plod is no exception

A wild and visually stunning quest through a fantasy world all done with the noble spirit of courage and goodwill.

Breaks a record for climbing to the apex of movie musicals. Unfortunately, it's done within the first hour of proceedings and the slide back to the bottom is a laborious walk through the famous stage musical's song book.
A genuine one of a kind film. Courageous filmmaking that proves cinema can still provoke wonderment and reflection.
Life of Pi is director Ang Lee's artistic expression of faith on film that's close to his very own version of the Sistine Chapel, minus the neck pain.

Humbling experience and despite whatever generation you hark from there is the common ground of having lived through those teenage years and this film revels in those magic moments and the people that help form who we are.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Pushes the series deep into the trash heap

movie_review_blurb: Fearless and fabulous
One of the most despicable displays in the collision between consumerism and filmmaking
A refreshing amount of buoyancy to dance and charm its way through Quarter-Life Crisis territory. One of the best performances of Greta Gerwig's career to date
The humour is ace and it has a strong emotional backbone that moves you from laughing at the characters to laughing with them. Subtle and beautiful execution.
A little sleepy but still manages to dig in an emotional hook
Love is a battlefield, but it's a war worth fighting for in this fantastic doco
A visceral fever dream that's both entrancing and horrifying
A superhero boom crash opera

For a film that deals in different forms of agony it's rather pleasant. A portrait of family that's refreshing with the right emotional punch.

movie_review_blurb: A sumptuous enigma that's intricately constructed and beautifully shot, a film that would make Terrence Malick blush

As dysfunctional as its family of scribblers despite tiny bites of charm from the cast
An effective thriller that does an ace job of maintaining your elevated heart rate

The importance of this doco cannot be overstated in exposing a corrupt regime, highlighting the dangers of propaganda and holding a warped mirror to the monsters that walk the Earth as free men
The ideals of freedom, paradise and the American dream pulse in a neon coloured, bubble-gum scented descent into darkness
A common sense nightmare that's frustrating to endure but the reality of the situation may be spot on
Tries to present itself as a comedy with some elements of satire, but it's a complete misfire dragged down by a strange blend of Grindhouse cinema that takes itself too seriously.
Gripping crime drama strained by forced politics
If you enjoy a good mystery that's as grimy as a stomped on cigarette on the pavement then this film will have you hooked. Fans of the books should be pleased.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you've become a little cynical about going to movies due to inflated ticket prices, Michael Bay films and chatty audiences, Hugo may restore your faith in the wonder of cinema.
No doubt the awards hype around the film will get people into cinemas but it doesn't warrant the attention considering Payne's previous work and Clooney has put in much better performances.

Warrants multiple viewings. I am currently considering raising my children on this film. If you don't come out feeling complete joy, you might want to check with your parents that they didn't find you in a crashed spaceship in a cornfield.
If this film is an indicator of the quality of films in 2012 I'll be praying that the Mayans were right about this little blue planet going boom.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Johnny Depp gets lost in paradise and a film with no plot.

like watching a large candle burn down to nothing and then wondering why there weren't any fireworks. Maybe I was expecting too much? Considering the cast and the subject matter it may be a case of too much of a good thing

Beyond the action there isn't much going on. It has a dud plot that attempts to reboot the story of the character. Cage revels in his own insanity and you have to wonder if the guy gives a crap anymore.
Writer/director Gareth Evans single handily atones for the crimes of every lame action film pumped out of the studio system and crafts one of the greatest martial arts films of all time.
Attempts to make the world a better place through the virtues of fishing and does it in a funny and heartwarming way.
There is not much new in the sequel and [director] Jonathan Liebesman never ties enough emotion to the main characters for you to care about their peril.
A light-hearted take on the fairytale material with a few slight adjustments. Might keep kids entertained but adults might be praying for the tainted apple.

Despite being blatant enviro-tainment, it's a win for the world if the stories of Dr Seuss are still being told. The film has its heart in the right place and might get children into the garden for some manual labour.
For the sake of your own mental health A Dangerous Method should be avoided, but the Cronenberg curious might want to endure it to prevent any onset of mania.
A clever film that manages to combine Orwellian themes with light adolescent drama and stabby teenagers.

Unfunny and relies too heavily on lame gross out gags and vulgar dialogue. Big gimmick is seeing the original cast all back together, but the last time we checked, no one was signing petitions to get them all in the same room.
So bad that Russian and American relations may break down and reignite the Cold War.
Will really test what you consider to be funny. Director Stephan Elliott puts a serious dent in his resume and may have his Australian citizenship revoked as a result.

Like watching a storm; yes there are flashes of lightning but most of the time you're just staring at boring grey clouds. After enduring the 132 minutes of John Carter tug-of-war it's not a complete win for team terrible but pretty damn close.

4:30pm 1 March 2012, the time a I saw the film industry and possibly humankind, hit a brand new low with Project X. A film so bad it doesn't deserve to be called a film or be allowed a release anywhere inside our solar system - including Pluto.
Parents and married couples, especially, will get a lot out of the biting commentary in Carnage. Not a cinematic triumph but a good way to flex the frontal lobe of your brain for a bit.
Not a film for everyone and it's not the best pick for Grandma's Sunday afternoon out. It's a challenging film but worth seeing for the combo of Fassbender and McQueen.
Despite indulgences it works well because there is a really nice message that lies at the heart of the film. When our energies are all directed towards good, amazing things can happen.
The film puts the word 'con' in Contraband because its primary goal is to rob you of your money. If you plan on seeing it, please locate your nearest emergency exits before the lights go down.

Cody and Reitman were once two of the most promising talents in the filmmaking business, but Young Adult erases any of their past success from memory. I truly hope for a return to form soon because YA is a real downer.
a charming look at a small sequence of Monroe's life and the subtle impact she had on those around her. A wonderful film that goes beyond the story you already know.

Olsen delivers an amazing performance and it's tragic seeing her go from a gorgeous young woman to a beautiful basket case. A must see. I've never seen a film that generates such a high level of anxiety by doing so little.
If you're craving a bit of action or just want to clear a few internal blockages in your circulatory system, 'Safe House' will suffice.
It's a film made for the 1% who question their sweet life while sitting on a gold plated toilet.

Takes itself too seriously and by the end it was hard not to laugh at the Carrie in a cape concept. The problem is that the found footage/hand cam concept does not service the story and the film would have benefitted without it.

A wonderful experience but if your mind isn't open to the idea of a silent film you might want to give it a miss. There are big rewards for those willing to investigate. You might have a new appreciation for the art of filmmaking.
A decent take on one of America's most prolific political figures and people with an interest in American history will get a lot out of it

a wild ride and will answer the question of how long you can hold your breath, and then quickly knock it out of you. Cinema seats will be torn apart, popcorn will fly and there might even be a few tears
A reminder of the power of good in a world where most people get too caught up in superficial matters. A wonderful documentary that will point life's purpose in the right direction.
Peter Berg and Co have milked those little plastic game pieces for all their worth in a film that's ridiculous but sometimes fun
A brilliant Australian film that examines Australians abroad, relationships and the consequences of having a bulletproof attitude when travelling.
Combines breezy political jabs with mainstream comic sensibilities successfully. The duo makes a great comedic pairing and the Ferrell/Galifinakis era of films may have just begun.
The redemptive path is paved with laughter and charm, mixes mirth with tears beautifully
A Tour de Wank
Provides nothing but unhappy memories
A hit of nostalgia in 50 shades of brown
A light puzzler that's not as complex as a rubix cube but more akin to a simple cryptic crossword

An unnerving experience and a brilliant piece of documentary filmmaking that peels back the layers on one of the most perplexing stories

A bloody open love letter to the horror genre that's funny, scary, and thought provoking. One of the best films of 2012.
Visually dazzling but the rest is poisoned by mediocrity

Graceful when it's not being a 'Spielberg film'.

A simmering, shimmering thriller set on the hot, dusty Italian island of Pantelleria.
A wild, scatological slalom from the grimmer parts of northeast England to the plains of South Africa.

movie_review_blurb: Charming and inventive.
It has a delicious cast, a great story, the moody backdrop of the back roads of Texas and the lingering, swampy reeds of north Louisiana.
A trenchant, if slow and careful, retelling of one of The Boston Globe's greatest scoops.

I find Solondz's films oddly soothing.
This new version of Arthur Ransome's 1930 kindling and pemmican epic is perfectly pretty.

movie_review_blurb: [War Dogs invites] us to marvel at the exploits of two utterly stupid accidental arms dealers from Miami.
A sad tale of loneliness.

[McCarthy is] deliciously dry, harsh, funny, a fine physical comedian. She excels as weird supporting characters... Since her early films, however, she's tried to push herself as an improbable leading woman.
A gripping war thriller.
Tom Hardy does not so much act in films as wildly devour them, drawing every last ounce of energy and audience love his way. In Legend... he sucks an entire dressing-up box towards him as well.
It is impossible to say how exhausting this film is -- by the fourth battle, I was gibbering.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Woody Allen, Wes Anderson, Noah Baumbach and Lena Dunham rolled into one -- and if that sounds like too much, well, it is! Jason Schwartzman stars as a pretentious writer.
I did wonder if I could stomach a further two hours of pulsating thighs and thrashing jockstraps after the last one, but, oddly, it turns out I absolutely could.
The results are slick and accomplished, but fail to present any real answers.
I am afraid I laughed from start to finish.

A strangely unconventional story chopped and uneasily lopped into a deeply conventional Hollywood format, right down to the trophy blonde with too many teeth. It has been squeezed -- just as Wilson was. And nothing quite hangs together.
By the sweet hammer of Thor, Marvel Comics has really, really run out of ideas this time.
Southpaw is... a deeply predictable film, more a courtly quadrille than a dance of doom towards the ropes.

It strains, it scuffles, it barely keeps the ball in the air. Like a desperate, ageing clown, the studio that made Toy Story, Monsters, Inc and Wall-E seems painfully aware that it must come up with something ever more dazzling.
This is not a film about big people or grand issues. It is delicately, oddly, insistently trivial.

It is mostly a fascinating film because Minnie is so unpredictable at the crossroads of rampant sexual desire and curiosity; Powley is deliciously insolent.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I left feeling I'd only had half the story, half the show, watched a giant spangly trailer for another, possibly better, film. It hasn't actively stopped me from wanting to see the next one, though.
This is a great romp with some groundbreaking stuff.
How desperately, crashingly bored and short of ideas Ritchie must be to write an entire scene about Paco Rabanne. The results are curiously sexless.

How weird and riveting and creepily fantastic a new documentary about an eccentric and lavishly haired family living in New York is.
It has the emotional content of a three-minute dance track.

movie_review_blurb: None of this really hangs together. It is almost horrifying to watch someone as statuesque and strident as Streep cringing and mugging her way through a role this pathetic.

Flaws aside, it is powerful, fascinating and honestly made.

For all its pomp and bombast, the only thing I can think of is cheese. The final film stretches out in front of me like a sea of Dairylea: an endless, formless, highly processed mass of nothingness, smelling slightly of prosthetics and hairy feet.

Aniston isn't brilliant because she managed not to wear make-up or not to wash her hair. She is brilliant because with every inch of her body she conveys pain. She's creepy, rigid, a plotline -- as a recovering invalid -- in her own right.
This is about as awful as films get.
What an awful last film for most of its audience to see, a grim, tinkling, multicoloured Typhoid Mary of cinema.

movie_review_blurb: If the director intended to elicit truths about the terrors of marriage, or the difficulties of a mother-daughter relationship, he has failed comprehensively.

While We're Young has the golden feel of a lifetime's obsession, the sense that Baumbach has spent so long observing the ghastliness of hipsters in Brooklyn that he now simply has to get it all down in one long, dramatic evacuation.

Thinking that a movie directed by Russell Crowe is good may be the film reviewer's equivalent of crying: "Look at the dog! It walks!" But everything fits together, and it's well shot and satisfyingly pacy.

This is a well-made Sunday-night drama, complete with sumptuous costumes and full use of a beautiful English landscape.

movie_review_blurb: An elegant but intellectually timid film.

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You might be forgiven for not realising that, far from being a mystical, swirling Dark Ages saga, the story was in fact classic Ritchie fodder, a heartwarming tale of the rise of a tiny Cockney ruffian, just waiting to be adapted by him.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

An astonishing erotic melodrama.

All fine detail and no fun.

A concert film by technicality, a cinematic trance in practicality.

[A] phenomenal rockumentary.
A phenomenal documentary.

The picture is a seemingly impossible success: a beautiful, entertaining, tragic, well-paced, and perhaps most shockingly, reverent adaptation of what any sane person might well have labeled an unfilmable story.

the film is so gripping, so mounting in its suspense that even as you struggle to keep together all its intertwining stories, you can't look away.
