... it was entertaining, but quite long.
The movie is a road trip that takes a bad turn to hell. Check it out.
It's an interesting story, based on actual events.
I have been blown away by this movie...and not in a good way.
This is one of those movies that kicks off with a slow engine and picks up at full speed in the second half.
Nights humanized these actors and made them live beyond their reputations.
The story was okay, but I think there was an underlying mammy factor that rubbed me the wrong way.
Unfortunately the movie isn't about Madea going to jail at all. That would have been a funny movie.
... I was pleasantly surprised.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Don't miss it.
Angelina's performance was powerful and at times agonizing.
The cast is really good, the story is interesting but it was kind of a let down at the end.
It just touched on so many different issues like love, the sanctity of marriage, forgiveness, rage, entrapment, loneliness and helplessness.
The movie was awesome and definitely a must see.
I enjoyed it all the way through the last second.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ... it was entertaining and it addressed all the normal relationships troubles people face each day.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Penelope's performance is a little sterotypoical, but fantastic...
Though it runs slow at times, Down To The Bone showed more the emotional dehabilitation rather than the obvious physical ware drugs took on a small town mom...
I've Gotta Be Me is as idyllic as it is heartbreaking.
movie_title: Sammy Davis, Jr.: I've Gotta Be Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Darren] Aronofsky confronts the brutality of fame and fandom and the conflict they present in our growing society of individuals whose social reflexes have evaporated and whose self-worth is dependent on external forces.
It's a deeply personal narrative but hopefully one that spark further discourse.
It seems more casually curious and at times even exploitative in its attempt to center the narrative of a poor, marginalized single mother and her precocious young daughter.
The Rape of Recy Taylor puts our voices back into the conversation and reminds audiences of our value in the movement.
Compelling, heartbreaking, and bold, Mudbound is an absolute must-see.
The film is fine, romantically lit and beautifully shot (like many Allen films), but isn't nearly effective as, say, Allen's last great film--Blue Jasmine.
Chalamet, however, is mesmerizing in the film. He carries the weight of the emotional layers so beautifully and effortlessly.
It's white male mediocrity hard at work. It might have its moments, but mostly Suburbicon is an ill-advised, messy, and problematic film that flagrantly misses its own mark.
But with all its grandeur and charm, the fact that this is a love story between a woman and a monster is too ridiculous to ignore.
Celeste and Jesse Forever is that much needed refreshing take on the modern romantic comedy that's become worn down by repeated tries and mediocre duplicates.
At times disturbing and always intense, this flick offers its own acid trip for viewers and is a first-hand look at four people who become trapped by their own hell.
Even with the brief cameos by Robert Duvall and Guy Pearce, The Road doesn't meet expectations.
It's beautifully told, passionate and sensitive to the true story and the victims that lived it.
... the movie was truly gratifying and fed our SATC appetite, at least until the sequel coming up (can't wait!).
Overall, the movie was touching, funny at times, and really conveyed an imperfect couple's search for the perfect parenthood.
Though I couldn't really make heads or tails of this 1999 movie, I found it interesting.
What is this movie about? I had to keep asking myself this question while suffering through not one, but two hours of The International.
Overall a good movie, good performances, got your adrenaline going.
It's a great whodunit.
Quite frankly, it was a waste of two talented actors.
... I went in to The Hangover with low expectations but ended up laughing more times than I thought I would.
... the movie goes on a nail biting tear...
A stunning performance by [Catalina Sandino] Moreno is the hallmark of the film...
It was good, but not great.
Beautiful performances, a refreshing story, and spot-on comedic timing make this a wonderful movie.
... it's interesting to see the story from the viewpoint of a female journalist--one whose capabilities as a mother, a wife and a law-abiding citizen are constantly questioned...
If you are one of the many out of work right now, try this movie for a good laugh.
It was a series of randomness that don't really offer much information or contribute to the overall point.
... it's one of the few romantic movies that center around an interracial relationship and keeps it real.
This movie was like watching a car crash in slow motion. You knew there was going to be a crash, but I just wished it would just happen already, and not have spent two hours getting to the impact.
This film was well worth the wait.
There's nothing like a good 'ole revenge heist (complete with a hit list) to make this film one of Tarantino's best.
Also starring Carrie Fisher, 'Burbs is a hilarious look at suburban mischief pre-Desperate Housewives. Check it out.
At times funny and clever, Moonstruck asks the questions: what does it mean to be in love? and is it ever okay to settle?
... the ending just raised another question: what the hell was that?
The film captures the strife tearing the city apart, and how one man fought against the system and won in his own way, on his terms.
This is one of the few drug movies where you actually feel a little sorry for the drug-dealing coke-infested lead character.
... Seth Rogen and Katherine Heigl have great chemistry onscreen and they are hysterical together.
It's a great mystery, filled suspense and doesn't fail to highlight the relationship between cops and Black folks, especially men, during this era.
It's an amazing story.
If you're in any way a Spike Lee fan, check this out.
... I thought the performances were good, but I just thought it could have done more.
The A-Team certainly explodes onto the big screen in a major way.

The Princess and the Frog will certainly be remembered years later as not only a pioneer Disney movie, but also one that allowed audiences to never let go of their dreams and that with love anything is possible, no matter your age or color.

What's good about Mulligan's performance is that it's subtle, and seemingly very natural. What's underwhelming about An Education is that all the drama that naturally occurs in a situation like Jenny's was missing.
Aside from a generic plot twist and a little clever banter between the two fellas, From Paris With Love fails to deliver the excitement to which the trailer alludes.
But, all in all, the movie is quite good and deserves more than one viewing just to keep up with the enthralling consecutive dialogues and often profound one-liners...
... it's too bad what could have been a beautifully crushing family drama was usurped by a massive amount of unnecessary special effects clouding the real story.
Not only is Attack the Block wickedly entertaining, but it's also well-written, suspenseful, whip-smart and moves rocket fast.
Let's just get this off our chests right now: Tower Heist is not a great movie.
It gets increasingly worse as it progresses, heightened by terrible acting all around and a poor script.
... Texas Killing Fields is a must-see.
Real shame about the ending, but the rest of the movie is just marvelous.
Each character is so real, like someone you may know, which makes Pariah a real comfort.
... Drive is a riveting watch.

A bit of a mixed bag at times, its overall well developed character sketches and good performances will certainly keep the attention of moviegoers and no doubt increase DVD sales (as well as, perhaps, sales of Purell).
Midnight in Paris is a very unselfish and lovely approach to inspiration, love, and the written word. A must watch.

Acclaimed writer Luc Besson (The Professional, Taken, The Fifth Element) co-writes another action-packed movie that even with a few outrageous moments is still a smart, sexy thriller with a good story that propels Saldana's star power.
It's a surprisingly provocative film that really stretches the definition of summer blockbuster.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Final Destination 5 won't be known for any stellar performances, but first-time feature director Steven Qualye can rest assured he scared the daylights out his audiences.
Although the lack of originality of the concept really brings down its appeal, audiences will enjoy watching this recycled story unfold with the two newest performances.
From the cool special effects, to its top-notch acting and wickedly fun concept, Cowboys and Aliens is just that film that you may in fact hate to love. But it is really enjoyable.
Captain America is a truly humble story that fortifies the character both physically and morally.
These types of movies are going to keep coming out and there's just nothing we can do do about it.
So, of course, a comedy of errors ensues since these everyday guys are the last you'd think could pull of such a dirty task. And man is it fun to watch it unfold.
Never mind the ridiculous subtitle. It's really just a precursor for what is to come from the rest of the movie. And Transformers: Dark of the Moon doesn't even try to play down its idiocy.
Green Lantern is not a perfect movie, but it's fun to watch.
Disappointing overall, though entertaining at times, True Grit isn't exactly the Coen brothers best movie but they get an A for effort.
Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to Biutiful.
If you didn't see the previous movies, you may not be able to appreciate some of the subtle references, but that won't make you enjoy the movie any less. Check it out.

The wickedly entertaining characters and actors each leave audiences in stitches as they go through the motions of an equally entertaining--albeit redone--plot that will thrill die-hard fans of the original.
Slickly written and finely acted, Last Night is at its core a character study.
... The Muppets not only restore their name in the movie, but they prove to the audience that they're back and they're still as cute and entertaining as ever before.

Sure, it neatly avoids a lot of the fluff found in many chick flicks and replaces it with crass shenanigans, but it adds touching moments when they're needed most, providing for a smart, less clichéd comedy.
Cleverly written and beautifully portrayed, Shame is a sensitive look at sex and addiction we've rarely seen before in film.

With all the so-called well-intended chick flicks with squeaky clean endings, is it any wonder that we're starved to see a heroine who's not redeemed and holding hands with her frenemy by the end of a movie?
Savages may come off choppy in the very beginning, but it does springboards to a really fantastical second half.
It has the talent, the already endearing subject, but fails to deliver on the promise it had before.
It will not only stir your soul, but also open your mind to the possibility of a real-life Promised Land.
The Birdcage is a little film with knee-slapping scenes coupled with thoughtfully acute moments as well.
Really, it's like a longer, louder version of Glee or American Idol, but with actors who can't sing rather than singers who can't act. Plus, it rocks you like a hurricane.

Prometheus recaptures the essence of not only a beloved franchise, but also an admired yet complicated genre many filmmakers attempt but few successfully. In short, it shows the amateurs how it's really done.

Not a perfect movie by any stretch of the imagination, Snow White and the Huntsman can boast truly magnificent performances--minus Stewart, of course--an interesting take on a beloved tale, and gorgeous scenes. Too bad about some of that plot though.
At its core, Girl in Progress is an endearing mother-daughter portrait reminiscent of Cristina and Flor in Spanglish that is a little bit Gilmore Girls, mixed with a dash of Mermaids.
Effective acting and Tanya Wexler's direction of a taboo topic (especially given the era in which it's set) cannot save the unbearably choppy and uneven writing of the movie.
The comedic timing, coupled with his ability to maintain the authenticity of the characters, is worthy of praise. The Avengers delivers a popcorn feast that's the perfect summer kickoff.
Mother and Child isn't a hard-hitting drama, but rather a precious, soulful look at family, love, and loss.
While the movie tries to cultivate Thatcher's life, it's not perfect. But the chemistry between Broadbent and Streep to elevate an untold romance beautifully elevates the flawed movie.
Screenwriter Rebecca Frayn's full feature debut is alluring, fascinating to watch and, most importantly, makes you care about Suu Kyi.
Mirror, Mirror won't change your life, but it's a fun homage to a timeless classic that lets you escape into a fairy tale world, that actually doesn't seem to far away from here.

Complete with the rock star wigs, superhero body and slightly timid but ever so deliberate snarl in her speech, Bassett embodied the icon during her slow and steady rise to fame, and her tumultuous marriage...
movie_title: What's Love Got To Do With It? (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A gripping drama, Detachment offers a gut-wrenching look at the school system, as told by the unsung heroes--the teachers.
A disastrous comedy at times, with a few unexpected touching moments sprinkled throughout, A Thousand Words fails to come together like it should, and becomes a forgettable mess.

It's been too long since we've seen a film so luscious that it practically whisks you away to another time, another place. The animated film (and Oscar nominee for best animated feature), Chico & Rita does just that.
Though it's not a premise we haven't seen played out before on the silver screen, Safe House is a movie that sucks you in, guts you, and spits you out at the end.
Except for its disappointingly tapered ending, Miss Bala... is an impressive, anxiety-ridden crime drama that can join the ranks of some of the best in its genre, from two of Mexico's best talents.
The Artist is simply a pleasure to watch, if only for just two hours in time.
Like a long, boring game of chess, where hopeful baseball players are discarded as effortlessly as a pawn and a knight, Moneyball fails to provide the sentiment it needs to inspire audiences.
It rather presents a quaint coming-of-faith tale that's not especially captivating to watch.
... at its core, Beginners is about finding happiness, even at the end.
Another Earth is quite a gem in a lot of ways, but wrapped in an enigma. It's a very sophisticated approach to a familiar theme.
Although it lacks some of its original slickness and more surprising twists, Ghost Protocol really breathes new life into the franchise.
overall the movie does take allegiances with both the book and original movie, but it comes into its own to unravel a truly alluring story.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: But aside from its substantial performances, The Help's completely uninteresting script caused the whole movie to be dead on arrival.
Witty, charming and very current, the big screen adaptation of Thor is sure to catapult its star Chris Hemsworth (whose wife, Elsa Pataky, ironically stars in Fast Five) to leading man status.
Overall, Immortals is a pretty decent popcorn flick. Will it stand the test of time? Probably not, but the provocative special effects will leave a lasting impression on the audience.
Its gimmicks haven't grown up, although its older fan base has.
Perhaps this was a video game or a straight action flick this would have been a better movie.
Together the performances mark the perfect recipe in a beautifully written story is both funny in the most surprising parts and touching when it needs to be.
Packed with stunts that would make even Tom Cruise grimace, Unstoppable is an adrenaline-fueled action flick that leaves you at the edge of your seat until the very end.
An engaging but deliberate chick flick at times, Eat, Pray, Love has the quintessential chick flick star at the helm with Roberts, who played the role beautifully...
No over-the-top acting, not a really compelling plotline, but entertaining yet.
Oscar-nominated actor Robert Downey Jr. usually has a knack for picking good movies. But Due Date is not one of them.

Writer/director Tyler Perry is probably used to taking heat from the critics for his films, but he can rest knowing that his latest movie For Colored Girls... is his best film yet. Even though that might not be attributed to his direction or writing.
Franco... delivers a solid performance as the strapping climber who shows his vulnerability when he reflects back on his life--the mistakes he's made and the moments he may miss.
Though it's slow in the beginning, the ending will leave you terrified and foaming at the mouth for a sequel.
Funny at times, Please Give is a surprisingly heartwarming coming-of-age film for six adults all passing through different stages of heir life.
Either way, it--and the movie--is annoying.
It's cliched, boring, and anticlimactic.
The Social Network, just like its subject, is the pop culture phenomenon of the new generation.
The Town is a definite must-see.
Skip it.

The Expendables is more than just your average action movie; it is the action movie of the year uniting the grittiness and soul of the old genre with the special effects and coolness of the new genre. See it.

Greenberg is self-indulgent, boring and very cynical (and not in a good way). The anticlimactic ending doesn't sum up the movie but rather leaves you further frustrated at Greenberg for being a miserable, unlikeable person for no apparent reason.
Mediocre acting and a tired plotline ruins what's left of the movie.
Check out Takers for end of the summer fun. Leave your brain at home.
... Date Night is the fun, lighthearted comedy that the two TV heroes needed to reclaim their box office status.
If you're looking for a mindless, fun summer flick, check this one out. Otherwise, it's okay to pass this one by in the video store.
The Book Of Eli is just one hot mess with choppy biblical undertones... The filmmakers just tried to get too deep with something that was not fully developed.
Awesome doesn't even begin to describe the sleek, clever, mind-blowing madness that is director Christopher Nolan's aptly titled psychological (read: trippy) thriller Inception.
Charming, touching, and surprisingly funny, Despicable Me showed one man's journey to being the most hated to finally finding love--thanks to three little girls.
Sure, it's more sinister and gory (ridiculously so at times), but Del Toro's acting is a standout.
Check your brain at the door.
Though visually stunning, Alice In Wonderland is more funny than anything else (thanks mostly to Depp's Mad Hatter).
The result just falls flat.
Audiences won't know who to trust and what is real in this terrifyingly great film that will grab hold of you until the final act.
f you're one of the many nerdy high school boys plagued with unpopularity and pimples, you'll adore the underdog story of Kick-Ass. But if you're one of the rest of us, you probably won't.
Though it plateaus emotionally for much of the time, Rabbit Hole is an engaging and heartfelt drama.
Overall The Fighter is a touching, soulful knockout of a movie.

Tron: Legacy is a fun popcorn flick if you had the opportunity to catch it on the big screen, but with the digital effects downsized on a DVD format what's good about the movie doesn't emit as much of an effect.
Hanna is not just a sleek action movie (with a heart-pounding soundtrack), but it also has a soul that you don't want to part with.
Morning Glory is a lackluster knockoff to Devil Wears Prada, minus the heart, cleverness and fashion. It's just not a good time, as it claims to be.
Fair Game was in no way a terrible movie, but with a scattered storyline and somewhat caricature-like performances by both leads, it failed to connect as it should have.
It would have been far more compelling with a stronger actress but, truth be told, the ending started off anti-climactic then concluded very predictable.

The masterful storytelling of the eight women in The Joy Luck Club, illuminated by each actress's elegant portrayal, make the film as resonating today as it did when it first hit theaters nearly eighteen years ago.
It was a decent concept (at best) that was not supported with a good screenplay, and grew sillier by the minute. It just didn't work.
Together they make up for decent movie, with occasionally good action scenes.
While Easy A might not be remembered ten years from now like such films as Pretty in Pink, Pretty Woman, and Boomerang, but it's still a refreshing addition to today's genre.
Although it would be interesting to see a stunt like this get pulled off in real life, I Spit on Your Grave needs major plot fixes and a redo.
With fashion and a passionate love story as a backdrop to a wonderfully acted narrative, Mahogany is simply fabulous.
For the big screen, it didn't hold up as strong but did manage to hash out a good story led by strong performances regardless.
The script could have done better to translate the concept. It works as a big picture concept, but doesn't get the treatment it deserves here.
Williams's beautiful performance is played nicely off Gosling's remarkably vulnerable performance yielding a timeless portrayal of love, romance, agony and despair.
A Piece of Work is a refreshing look at a reluctant legend, one who's still using all her might to break barriers for the rest of us to get a real kick out of.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Exploring the world of good and evil is a common theme in cinema, but few have been able to create such a fine line between the two as cleverly done in Let Me In.
Devil isn't really scary, the acting stinks, and it's not that clever, but you can rest knowing that the culprit isn't a hand puppet.
Knight and Day is a bit too long (one too many plot twists that made you just not care by the end) but it's fun though predictable thrill ride.

Night Catches Us shouldn't be confused for something as blanket as "that black panther movie" or even a political movie, but more like a story about what it really takes to move on when you're so stuck on here.
Overall, Vanishing on 7th Street was just randomly ridiculous and utterly asinine.
Recommendation--skip this one and revisit the previous movies.
It all makes for interesting, and even terrifying, viewing at times. But it's not very smart and far too predictable.
Almost identical to 2009's Orphan, Case 39 does little keep your attention as its riddled with cliches--menacing music, domino casualties, and predictable horror plotline.
Wild, gritty, and sharp, Animal Kingdom has a ticking bomb for a heartbeat that pulsates through every scene.
... you will be so caught up in the movie that its surprisingly abrupt ending will leave you with your mouth agape.
Unfortunately, Going the Distance doesn't take audiences far enough.
Occasionally crude and tasteless, Ruthless People is a comedy with a vitriolic twist. It`s a comedy about people who love to hate, with actors who make it worth seeing.
If director Scott intended to picture a growing sense of female triumph, he failed miserably.

Midnight Run is an inside-out, upside-down buddy film and comedic cross- country caper. It also is the entertaining excuse for Robert De Niro, the Method actor of his generation, to cut loose and play things light for a change.
If you have a thirst for hard action and suspense of a high order, Speed satisfies big-time.
As played winningly by Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan, there is a quirky chemistry created in their offbeat pairing.

Just when you thought the movies had been given over to special effects departments and the high-tech fantasies that sustain them, along comes The Fugitive -- a good, old-fashioned drama with unsettling shivers of suspense.
What`s Love Got to Do With It is sizzling film fare.
movie_title: What's Love Got To Do With It? (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Sex, violence and secrecy can make a volatile on-screen combination, but not this time.
The Hand That Rocks the Cradle is that rare thing, a realistic thriller wise enough not to sell short any of its characters. Just be prepared to become very, very scared when you see it.
movie_title: The Hand that Rocks the Cradle (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Within the narrow framework of the hard-action genre, Die Hard is almost as good as it gets.
Wondrously imaginative, The Lion King is superior family entertainment, charming in every way.

Feverish suspense is at work in In the Line of Fire, a film of surprising depth for an action thriller. The felicitous interweaving of humor and high drama is another hallmark of this tense story of wits.
The man, who only has been superficially shown, gets lost for a while in the sweep of events. Yet in spite of these reservations, this lush film merits attention.
Embalmed in good intentions, Driving Miss Daisy is a creaky adaptation of a Pulitzer Prize-winning play.
A thudding disappointment.
Dangerfield proves once again why he's one of the funniest men on screen.
Realistic and thoughtful, Unforgiven has the pictorial sweep we've come to expect from the genre and the intelligence too long missing from it.
Despite the familiar echoes, the film works more often than it should. Without the charming Kevin Kline in two roles, plot problems would yawn like sinkholes.
Director John Carpenter's They Live is an undistinguished sci-fi thriller.
A drama of vivid intensity, it has all the marks of a well-made, thoughtful film that does not exploit violence for its own sake or make killing a source of entertainment.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Newman clearly owns the part of Sully, but there is nary a false or uncertain note struck by anyone in this ensemble cast.
It is a wondrous love story unsparing in its sentiment.
What a lot of fun is The Witches. A few days before Labor Day, it is safe to say that it`s the most enjoyable movie of the summer.
Pure enchantment, Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas creates a unique and wondrous world. This awesome movie is in a class by itself for its use of stop-action animation.
The Ref is a powerfully funny adult comedy. It skewers marriage, suburban values and the trendy belief that everyone is a victim of something.
Out of Africa has the sheen of artsiness and the gloss of two big-name actors. Unfortunately, that`s not quite enough in the absence of a story with vigor and passion.
Dying Young belongs to the luminous Roberts. She is becoming one of the screen's finer actresses.
As Parenthood reveals within its charming, two-hour running time, the pitfalls and quandaries of child-rearing are universal -- and the joys and the heartaches remain lifelong concerns.
Flatliners is moderately entertaining hocum at times, when it doesn't reach too far. Roberts is the best of the adequate bunch -- only her fans should make this a must-see.

Bull Durham is a jaunty, refreshing comedy that mixes sex The ambling pace and inventiveness of Bull Durham are the doing of Shelton, a filmmaker worth watching. This film is a tidy summing-up of one aspect of America`s favorite sport.
A superb character study of tough guys turning on each other, it is also an edgy drama about the dissolution of trust.
It's a cinematic home run, certain to please filmgoers who don't know a catcher's mitt from an oven mitt.
As played to perfection by recent Oscar winner Tom Hanks, who is fast proving that he has no acting limits, this film is a social comedy that reaches heights of wit and cleverness.
[A] special experience, sort of an It's a Wonderful Life for the late '80s.
This thoughtful film is real in every respect, right down to the plaintive sound of a country woman`s ballad.
You are likely to leave Dirty Dancing feeling good about what happens to the characters and longing to dance as they do.
A cautionary tale about scientists and schemers messing with Mother Nature, the film makes its point. But it takes at least 30 minutes to get going.
As Robin might have said of this semi-boondoggle: "Holy overkill!"
DeVito and Pfeiffer make formidable foes and formidable fun.
A stylized revenge fantasy of dark beauty.

Surprise, surprise -- Addams Family Values is more wicked, more warped and more tightly wound than The Addams Family. It's a dark comedy on the edge, way on the edge, and perhaps twice as funny as the original.
Carrey, the star of the surprising hit Ace Ventura: Pet Detective and a regular on TV's In Living Color, acquits himself well in a part of sublime goofiness.
In this film ably directed by Carl Franklin, who has spent most of his adulthood as an actor, there are more than a few tense scenes.
Fonda and Bancroft are interesting to watch together, in spite of their insufficient performances. But their meaty dialogues don`t amount to much.

In spirit The Princess Bride recalls The Neverending Story, which also was about a contemporary boy`s fantastic adventure. Reiner's film is likely to please adults more than kids and to last in memory more than most films this fall.
Call it a hindsight view of British history, an unnecessarily controversial film about the uses of sex, or a perverse love story -- any of the descriptions will fit Scandal.
The artfully superficial relationship between Bill and Rose works to the plot's advantage.
There`s a boyish exuberance about Newsies that is hard to resist.
Artfully directed and acted, For Queen & Country errs by overstating its case.
Solve this show business mystery: How is it that the greatly gifted Bill Cosby, a comedy guru with few peers, makes bad movies? The latest entry on his depressing film resume is Ghost Dad.
Smart beginning, witless ending.
One hopes that more inspiration comes to the creation of Nerds III, which already is being planned. The essence of the nerds needs to be resurrected.
movie_title: Revenge of the Nerds II: Nerds in Paradise (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Swank and Morita make a personable pair, enough so that we don't miss Macchio. The monks exude a benevolent presence in a film less trivial than it could have been.
In this meant-to-be-charming saga of youthful adventure set in 1962, Priestley is the dead weight.
It can't decide whether to be a mushy valentine to the dad-son relationship, masculine style, or a not-very-clever comedy.
You know a movie is in trouble when the special effects forces at Industrial Light and Magic are employed to jazz up games of golf.
The plot becomes repetitive and tiresome, though the movies-within-the-movie (created by the filmmakers, rather than pulled from the film vaults) are funny.
It's enough to make you wonder: Doesn't anybody know how to write an old- fashioned romance any more?
Gracefully blending raucous comedy with intense drama, the film is about the loss of innocence as well as the getting of wisdom.
There isn't a performance in this film that is less than excellent.
When the great screen performances of 1988 are considered for Oscar nomination, expect Hoffman's name on the list.
Clever and daring, this high-pitched film never falters. Pulp Fiction is simply masterful. It's also one of the few films this year that bears seeing twice for maximum pleasure.
As directed with a light touch by Mike Newell, there's little doubt as to where it is going or how it will be resolved. That's all right, since getting there is so much fun.
Any comedy with Jack Nicholson has automatically got to be great, right? Think again.
This is a case where the actors are only as good as the script, which isn`t saying much. It`s not long into Club Paradise when you may feel the urge to get out.

These fighting-intensive movies, a glorification of hurtful action, are strictly for children. While the corpse count is low, the mimicking turtles stand for nothing more important than the employment of physical force.

Goldman and director Richard Donner don't know when to stop mining a gag and to move on. That the film runs in excess of two hours is indicative of the filmmakers' love affair with scenes that don't work.
It`s a pretty good little movie, not so insignificantly for the performance of Willem Dafoe as the drug delivery man with a desire for a different life.
It is straightforward and riveting, with an unexpected emotional power.
Cry-Baby takes digs at Jailhouse Rock in a musical number that Elvis would have loved to do.
If you see only one movie in this season of blockbusters, make it Do the Right Thing.
See this film with a group of friends, and you may stay up late talking about it.
Erratic but forcefully acted.

Food, glorious food -- its life-giving, sensual, aromatic and filling properties are celebrated in the wacky Tampopo. This Japanese film is without precedent, no matter what country you are talking about.
Unlike anything onscreen this month or this year, Orlando is serious, provocative and sometimes funny fare. Novelist Virginia Woolf might well be pleased.
Even in the action genre, there is such a thing as overkill. Die Hard 2: Die Harder pleads guilty to the charge but has enough redeeming plot twists to compensate for the excess.
It's rigorous and quite depressing fare.
Jungle Fever is confidently acted, brilliantly written and thoroughly provocative. Lee has succeeded again.
Outrageously sinister, unblinkingly violent, Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome is everything that fans of the futurist road warrior could hope for and more.

The Land Before Time works by evoking the simple virtues of this art aimed at children, as it was in the beginning when Disney animated Mickey Mouse. This film deserves a place next to the often-revived animated classics.
A rush job from filmmakers who should have left well enough alone.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: With the exception of an elaborate fantasy sequence straight out of a Disney movie and a running gag about a Cadillac without brakes, Fletch Lives should have been called Fletch Staggers.
The tough-minded A Dry White Season is the best film yet about the struggle for justice in South Africa.

Dispossession and despair are seldom portrayed with such force on-screen. Director Mira Nair has done a masterful job of underscoring a social problem that has repercussions far beyond the Third World.

Colorful, vibrant, exotic, The Living Daylights more than delivers an eyeful of entertainment. At a running length just over two hours, the most thrill- seeking Bond fans will get their money`s worth.
The music is great, the direction fast-paced, the whole film a lot of fun.
Sid and Nancy is a brilliantly acted surprise from newcomers Gary Oldman and Chloe Webb.
Movies don`t come more superficial than Everybody`s All-American.
A perfectly dreadful film.
Once in a long time, a movie speaks to the truths of U.S. history and causes the filmgoer to see past events in a new light. Dances With Wolves is such a movie.
What this one lacks is broad-barreled fun, which is the essential element in a spoof.
My Boyfriend`s Back is the lamest of the lame so far.
The outcome of the film is predetermined by the formulaic scripts of Rocky II and Rocky III. Stallone boxed himself into a corner with this one.
The sad fact is that the duck gets lost in what becomes a special effects film suspiciously reminiscent of Ghostbusters.
Good, solid entertainment -- that`s what Navy SEALs provides in a winning package worth the price of admission.
About Last Night... is occasionally wonderful, but inevitably disappointing.
The utter chaos of war in Vietnam is brilliantly portrayed. No one can deny this film the power of its images and the weight of all-pervasive terror it creates.
In the Name of the Father is a deeply stirring film that lessens the moral authority of the I.R.A., English soldiers in Ireland, the British police and the British government.
movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Flight of the Navigator, in spite of a rough beginning, soars as it should, taking a child on the journey of his life.
Bloated as a TV miniseries two nights too long, Legends of the Fall is stiff and uninteresting.
For a better time, however, rent Serreau`s original film at the video store.
movie_title: Three Men and a Baby (3 Men and a Baby) (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Ferris Bueller`s Day Off goes through the motions of enjoyable experiences without communicating much joy.

The premise is cute, the characters are endearing, and the wackiness of their predicament in the desert is almost enough to carry the film past dry spells of laughlessness. But the dry spells are frequent.
With a strange mix of varying English and American accents and the weight of a film with too many subplots, Robin Hood strains credibility. It also feels long.
It soars because of the sizzling chemistry of Douglas and Demi Moore.
The screenplay by Dale Launer has all the sophomoric qualities of a C- grade TV movie.
Allen`s ear for the strained marital conversation, the fury of a breakup and the tentativeness of starting a romance is impeccable.
More than competent are Moore, spared from what would have been a phony romantic involvement with Cruise, Kevin Bacon as a prosecutor and Kiefer Sutherland as a by-the-book Marine.
Dry as an outdated textbook, scintillating as the droning of your worst schoolteacher, Christopher Columbus: The Discovery is a colossal disaster.
A charmless, irritating psychological fantasy that can`t decide whether to aim at kids or adults.
It`s hard to summon much wonder when Superman goes mano-a-mano with Nuclear Man, a Lex Luthor creation with a static electricity problem.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially, American Anthem is an idea in search of a screenplay,

To watch Tommy Lee Jones re-create the persona of the Hall of Famer in Cobb is to encounter the greatest SOB ever to come down the pike -- in or out of the domain of sports. The trek is hardly entertaining.
In this well-crafted movie, a strong cohesive ensemble makes the team likable. Guiry as Scotty is especially good.
Days of Thunder lives up to its title in one respect. It`s big-time noisy. It`s also as empty as the stands at the Daytona 500 an hour after the race.
Licence to Kill gets better as it unfolds for more than two hours. It just takes an insufferably long while to find the right pace.
The fine performances and worthy themes are sold short. There are two films here, neither one of which is as fully developed as it could be.
Van Sant proves again that he is masterful at charting the hearts and minds of young people adrift.
Lanzmann`s monumental film bears significant witness to the Holocaust. Those who see it will never forget it.
Pretty in Pink is an engaging movie about youthful concerns that never go out of fashion.
The much-anticipated film is a psychedelic circus that turns into the worst nightmare of a bad trip. It`s an experience.
From the first moments of Once Upon a Forest, there is evidence of high artistic standards. The backgrounds are beautifully detailed, right down to the shading and contours of a tree trunk.
There's a pervasive romanticism in I Love Trouble that depends on the chemistry generated by Roberts and Nolte.
Bernie Mac is the best way to close out the show. He lunges straight into the audience's face, politically incorrect and proud of it.
The jokes fly so quickly and hard that you may find yourself laughing through many of the punch lines.
Two incredibly talented stars, at different ends of their careers, somehow brought together by the lowest points on their CVs.
A bitingly funny, fascinating and moving portrait of Pinochet's fall that's smartly shot and superbly performed.
A truly strange and original creation, based on a true story, which doesn't judge its curious characters.
Layered with smarts, charm and originality, but also packing a hefty emotional punch, this has all the hallmarks of an indie classic.
Taking its stylistic cues from its wild leading lady, this daring and darkly-hued comedy matches its subversive laughs with genuine heart.
A polished and inspired documentary which deftly attempts to understand Paul Kelly through his words and music.
This adaptation may not "burn, burn, burn" with quite the same intensity as the novel, but it kicks and thrusts with a joy and yearning of its own.
And while it occasionally feels a little wobbly, it grows more sure of itself and richer as it goes along.
It's in the completely natural interactions between this gifted cast that the film really hits its groove.
The charismatic cast (particularly Banks and Lopez) manage to find the humanity in their clichéd roles but they can't transcend all the surface-level schmaltz on display here.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Are you a romantic or a realist? Like Crazy is the rare romantic drama made for both."
Falling victim to his source material, Hicks fails to invest it with any sort of edge, rendering the cinematic version as mawkish and saccharine as Sparks' bloated prose.
...this is packed with all the warmth, heart and humanity that one has come to expect from a Cameron Crowe film.
And like Spurlock's other works, among all the laughs and gimmicks, he occasionally scores a moment that floors you.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: ...it's the film's fearless go-for broke style which makes I Love You Phillip Morris such a success.
"It may be wrapped in the pretence of a comedy, but scratch beneath the shiny facade and sharp one-liners, and there's a dense and dark core."
This is unshakeable storytelling, which is fitting for a film that reveals how certain damage can never be undone.
...paints a piercing and poignant portrait of a visionary talent, and the complex forces that drive him.
Delpy seems fascinated by the way that time and life experience change people's perceptions and attitudes, but not their cores.
A stellar adaptation and a beautifully crafted coming-of-age tale that comes wrapped in all the promise and possibility of adolescence.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sassy and charming romantic comedy where the loosely scripted laughs play authentically and sometimes painfully.
It's formulaic, but it conjures up its own offbeat vibe and the musical numbers are gold.
...a nail-biting thriller of the first order, but also a confronting gut-wrencher which - though never driven by ideology or politics - inevitably pulls the audience into ambiguous moral territory.
A sprawling but smart and generous-hearted comedy whose knockout laughs come steeped in brutal honesty.
While all the emotionally manipulative factors are at play here, how does this end up one of Sparks' better screen adaptations?
It may be a Hollywood comedy, but it's one that feels beautifully alive.
But what does it have going for it? It has an undeniable pulse.
Its premise is an original and audacious one, but it ultimately gives way to all the cliches of the genre it is attempting to subvert.
War Witch is remarkable for the fact that it never strays into sentimentality or sensationalism.
...simmering just beneath its quiet, beautiful surface are endless questions to do with relationships and trust, and how they're tied to our expectations regarding masculinity.
...infectious, celebratory storytelling...
...just like the most memorable stand-up routines, there's a twinge of tragedy and pathos in the mix that make the laughs linger and the story stick.
...ends on a surprising and admirably audacious note, given the more routine closer that may have been anticipated.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A crass and shallow exploration of a potentially interesting topic, which makes for one downer of a cinematic trip.
For the most part, McPherson manages to pull off an unusual mix of sombre character drama and ghostly scares.
Deftly compiled and packed with revealing footage, this is a beautiful tribute to its subject, and also an eye-opening look into the emotional power of art.
Spread's strength lies in its dark, comic undertones but alas, its third act collapses into sentimentality.
By the numbers romantic plotline? Sappy tearjerker? Must be another Nicholas Sparks adaptation.
In many ways, this trashy, dazzling but enigmatic film belongs to Franco's Alien, a wannabe gangsta who just doesn't have the guts or heart to be a cold-hearted thug.

Shrek Forever After feels tired, but is lifted by the usual slew of wisecracks and pop culture references. The use of 3-D, while not revelatory, is apt, and adds another layer of appeal to the film's action.
While packed to the margins with witty jokes and visual gags, the charming third instalment never loses sight of its emotional core.
This franchise wasn't made for critics. Team Edward or Team Jacob? If you don't have an answer to that question, then who really cares what you think anyway?
While conventionally told, this thought-provoking film features deeply moving performances and compels audiences to consider the issues it raises.
An impressive and ambitious achievement, one that manages to feel both meticulous in all its hilarious detail and at the same time, rambunctious and heartfelt.
As expected, Tomorrow, When The War Began leaves the story wide open for a follow-up but this is one of those rare films which will leave audiences actually rooting for a sequel.
While occasionally opting for cheap laughs, this romantic comedy is entertaining, warm and feels surprisingly rooted in real life.
Skillfully told and featuring two remarkable lead performances, this painfully honest portrait of young love is both devastating and mesmerising.
A thrilling and life-affirming journey driven by James Franco's gut-wrenching performance and Danny Boyle's exuberant direction.
Fittingly unconventional in narrative and driven by James Franco's inspired performance, this is a fascinating and thought-provoking tribute to an epic work.
Driven by terrific lead performances, moody cinematography and an insider's feel for details, this is a bruising exploration of a timely subject.
Brimming with imagination and driven by disarming lead performances, this ends up warm, funny and surprisingly deeply touching.
Brighton Rock marks the directorial debut of Joffe (the screenwriter behind The American), and while not flawless, it's a solid affair.
While this had the potential to be a stirring cinematic experience, director Julie Taymor's trademark innovation and visual flair never soars.
With its undeniably preposterous premise, there's a silliness that underlies close to every scene of Battleship.
Tense, impressively shot and free of any showy heroics, this is an incisive and affecting look at the way war and politics tragically intersect.
Fittingly, the laughs this time round are more generated by nostalgia and affection than raunch or risk.
Led by a superb cast and deftly directed, this is a compelling and thrilling trip, which unsettlingly pulls you into the mix.
Surrounded by caricatures and a bit of schmaltz, this comedy is bolstered by a charismatic lead performance from Paul Rudd.

The best and richest parts of this documentary are the various interviews with Howard himself, which unmistakably reveal a musician whose artistic integrity remained untarnished, and whose passion for music burned white hot to the very end.
A touch more quirky than the average coming-of-age tale, there's a bit of schmaltz here, but this also brims with humour, heart and honesty.
It's intermittently fascinating, but this strictly fly-on-the-wall doco sometimes feels tedious and soulless.
It doesn't quite deliver on its promise, but this remains a witty, touching and largely enjoyable adaptation.
Employing laborious black-and-white flashbacks in the formulaic second half, Love Crime begins to feel strained, and while there are a handful of thrills, they're too few and far between.
Eye-opening and often devastating, this documentary challenges audiences to confront and question their own biases and assumptions.

Somehow, surprisingly, without things ever turning schmaltzy, we end up caring about this selfish, foul-mouthed teacher, even if it's just a smidgen. And in hindsight, that's a pretty impressive feat.
Exciting, gripping and touching, the action-packed final instalment sees this tremendously successful franchise end on a high.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While packed with hilarity, the laughs are always grounded in Kristen Wiig's heartfelt and utterly relatable performance.
Tweaking the Hollywood rom-com formula enough to seem fresh, this is smart, funny and heartfelt entertainment boosted by the charm of its terrific cast.
Luhrmann understands Fitzgerald's book and brings the writer's classic prose to life on cinematic terms that feel thrilling, visceral and immediate.
Once it all clicks into place and viewers are left to engage with the characters, the heavy misery and self-importance of the piece becomes overwhelming.
While bewildering for those unfamiliar with the Judd Apatow clan, for fans, this raunchy, daring and gleeful comedy comes up trumps.
Top Five plays like a great stand-up routine: shambling, honest and packed with laughs - and laughs that stick.
"It's disappointing that the script doesn't match the spectacular special effects on display, but it's still a compelling ride."
Wrapped in a comic playfulness, some may accuse Forbes of trivialising the realities of living with a mentally ill individual, but the storytelling always feels rooted in honesty.
While one never expects this experiment to turn out well, the results are still alarming.
It's admittedly a gorgeous crowd-pleaser, but one that could have set its sights higher.
Despite its urgent and topical subject matter, this story comes cloaked in charm and humour.
While Stiller's Josh may be worried about losing his edge, Baumbach should have no such fears.
...sticks pretty close to the formula of its predecessor, but it's saved by its sly humour, with digs flying thick and fast.

Pitting Binoche against Stewart is a smart move, as we're literally watching the push and pull of two generations of talent... It's a fascinating relationship that lingers in the mind -- just like this film.
A provocative and powerful look at grief and the strange ways we can react in times of crisis.
It's a fitting tribute to a true cinematic trailblazer, and an often under-appreciated artform.
It's an entertaining trip, but one that's also thought provoking and appropriately sobering.
Like Mike and his posse of men when they hit the stage, Magic Mike XXL is a film all too eager to please.

Writer/director David Oelhoffen has crafted a soulful, slow-burning western with Far From Men, which is as morally rich as one would expect given its source material, but also considerably more compassionate.
It may be easy to scoff at Unity on paper, but it's a daring, stirring piece of cinema that isn't afraid to tackle the big questions head-on.
The storytelling may come wrapped in Allen's biting wit, but the performances ensure that there's more than satire and irony on display here.
It's a flawed but touching tribute to female friendship and the fierce love that can exist between women -- and that's a rare thing on screen.
Just like its lead character, this film is packed to the brim with sadness, swagger and soul.
It's not exactly subversive, but How To Be Single is still an admirable step forward for the genre.
While he's a delight to watch, there's also something exhausting in watching Hart exert himself for a film offering him very little in return. He deserves better, as does the audience.
Like its predecessor, the best bits of this sequel are in the isolated moments...
An offbeat, challenging little gem that you'll be turning over in your head for days.
Tom Hooper transforms this story into the most gorgeous and accessible film that you could make given the subject.
Reichardt has crafted a mesmerising, unsettling film about the ripple effects of our decisions and how we live with them.
It's an entertaining romp and one of the funniest Christmas comedies we've seen for years.
Now Add Honey is the best kind of feel-good film: one that's genuinely uplifting, but also has something worth saying.
There's a wickedly deranged streak running through this film, but it's also a deeply humane piece of storytelling.
It seems that Gerwig, Baumbach's real-life partner, has brought a welcome warmth to the director's work, but his wry humour and observations remain just as sharp.
Cooper never makes his character likeable, but he makes him something better than that: raw and compelling.
The storytelling feels a little wholesome, but this is ultimately big-hearted fun.
Whimsically told, the story has the feel of a modern fairytale, and it's clearly an affectionate tribute to the daredevil artist at its centre.
Despite all the pros, Freeheld can't help but feel underwhelming.
While Rogen and Goldberg's stance is clearly anti-North Korean government, the duo don't exactly wave the American flag high either, with the film throwing some hits the way of its own country.
For all the absurdity at play, the genius of The Lobster is its depiction of a society and world view that's unsettlingly not all that unfamiliar.
Any self-pity is outweighed by a healthy dose of self-deprecating humour.
When Walter's fantasies cease, and he bravely ventures into the world, the film quietly soars.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Director Adam McKay and co. up the ante with this side-splitting sequel, which plays, bigger, funnier and more absurd. You'll be impressed.
Macdonald commendably refuses to soften the blow in a couple of unforgettable scenes - setting this teen epic bravely apart from its peers.
Make no mistake: there's a rage and wrenching sadness here, but Ryan Coogler has filtered it via a story packed with lingering grace notes.
...a bold, brave and unforgettable slice of filmmaking that pulls you deep into the mix and doesn't let go.
It's not so much the well-worn template that's the problem here, it's the superficiality with which the story unspools.
Incisive, irresistible and often very funny, Inside Llewyn Davis also proves itself to be a poignant and quietly profound meditation on what it means to be an artist.
Perhaps the nicest surprise of the doco is that, despite emerging from the manufactured pop machine, these boys feel refreshingly grounded and they're not taking their success for granted.
An occasionally illuminating doco about the infamously reclusive author, but one that feels almost inevitably over-hyped.
a smart, wry and surprisingly tender film about standing at the crossroads of adulthood.

an admittedly slight but resonant and lingering look at two truly singular talents - their flaws presented alongside their musical gifts - who were haunted by the presence of each other throughout their careers.
It's ultimately a story about the power imbalances in relationships, and the quietly devastating way that couples can build one another up, only to tear each other down.
What's troubling and somewhat dangerous is that underneath the twisted sex, this story contains the same template of every aspirational romance.
It's a brave, challenging and essential installment in what is one of modern cinema's finest trilogies.

Some may find Meadow's lack of journalistic rigour frustrating, but the filmmaker has ultimately created something different - a heartfelt tribute to one of Britain's most important bands, as seen through the eyes of its fans.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A bruised and beautifully layered piece of storytelling, which zeroes in on our desire for connection.

It admittedly feels like something of a missed opportunity, with director, Joshua Michael Stern, often more concerned with checking off bullet points than digging into the complexities of its leading man.
Mistaken For Strangers is a documentary about the documentary process itself, as well as a scruffy, but resonant portrait of a younger sibling breaking from the shadow of his older brother.

Middle-age restlessness and marital infidelity are hardly untapped topics, especially when it comes to French cinema, but in Marc Fitoussi's gently comedic Folies Bergere, these subjects are explored with a deft, bittersweet touch.
A rich, imaginative, big-hearted adventure.
It proves surprisingly effective material for the filmmaker, who reveals that he also possesses a deft hand when it comes to relaying big, earnest emotions.
It's a rich, fascinating and provocative film that never takes sides or opts for easy answers.

In another actor's hands, Hector -- a self-absorbed psychologist with a superficial understanding of the world around him -- could be a disaster. But Pegg invests his larger-than-life character with genuine heart and soul.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than exploiting its raunchy premise to offer up something honest, this evolves into a pretty textbook comedy.
"The question of why Frank's wearing a giant mask becomes deftly overshadowed by a host of potentially richer questions that turn the mirror on the audience."
Underneath its mawkish layers -- and there's a few to unpack -- Wish I Was Here is an honest, funny, and touching attempt by Braff to tackle serious and relatable themes.
If one can push past the fact that its world feels a little too familiar, this is a deftly executed slice of teen sci-fi.
Often lazily and unfairly accused of crafting works that trump style over substance, Anderson's painstaking attention to detail here beautifully serves the story.

At its core, The Lego Movie is an ode to imagination, creativity and busting outside the status quo, so it's wholly fitting that the film itself - from its storytelling through to its superb animation - embodies these qualities beautifully.
A slick, smug film about three guys, who we slowly, slowly watch get their act together.
Yes, this plays as sentimental and inoffensive as a winner's first record, but it's also packed with genuine heart.
This handsomely made adaptation plays to its YA audience, but while simple, it's a stirring look at WW2 from the perspective of normal German families.
It's a set-up that's the stuff of sensationalist headlines, but under Kore-eda's measured watch, it becomes a tender, thoughtful and moving look at the complex bonds that underpin families
The final twist does more to unravel what's come before than to tie it all together, making what's come before feel like a cosmopolitan goose chase.
A joy from start to finish. If this one doesn't inspire a rush on bookstores, nothing will.
Shopgirl is a wistful account of the yearlong love affair between a 50-year-old millionaire and a lonely, debt-saddled service sector serf in her 20s.
Something about the way it ends feels like a cop-out, and the opportunities for humor aren't exploited quite as well as they could be.

It's a sincere, well-put-together movie about the modern human condition. Hopefully, this will be enough to attract curiosity. After all, it's nice to get into someone else's head for a while, even if the head is being used for target practice.
Chicken Little, though it has its moments, mostly just feels anxious and overreaching. It tries to be all things to all people and fails to be anything to anyone.
Derailed is a silly, lurid, pulpy thriller that's not nearly lurid and pulpy enough to be much fun, but more than silly enough to be ludicrous.
She makes fun of bigotry by pretending to be a bigot; hypocrisy by pretending to be a hypocrite; and stupidity by pretending to be dumb.
An impassioned and occasionally mesmerizing first effort that's at once messier, more complex and more ambitious than many recent suburban dystopias.
... a low-key weepy about loneliness and (possibly) learning to conform one's romantic expectations to reality.
Rent is commodified faux bohemia on a platter, eliciting the same kind of numbing soul-sadness as children's beauty pageants, tiny dogs in expensive boots, Mahatma Gandhi in Apple ads.
You hate to call a ghost movie haunting, but there it is. It sticks around and rattles.

The very characteristics that keep him alive and kicking are the ones that keep you at arm's length. No surprise, then, that even the satisfying and semi-satisfying conclusions to various narrative threads don't quite satisfy.
The movie remains faithful to the book in both tone and imagery.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Spanning two decades and a momentous war, Memoirs of a Geisha displays all the pomp and grandeur of an epic, but you wouldn't call it sweeping.

A travelogue through popular movie genres, it passes from socially conscious drama to comedy, romance, horror, adventure, science-fiction fantasy and doomed love story, cleverly quoting the styles and tropes to which we've become accustomed along the way.
It throws them together early on but keeps their relationship at bay until the end -- when I, for one, was way past giving a kumquat.
The low-key charm of its setting underscores the easygoing performances of a relaxed, well-matched cast.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The New World is a work of breathtaking imagination, less a movie than a mode of transport, and in every sense a masterpiece.

The movie is less an uncharted journey than a 2 p.m. bus tour of a music industry legend. But like an expert guide, Mangold shepherds the story with enough grace, energy and skill to make it worthwhile.
Sex, drugs, intrigue, murder, extortion, betrayal -- it's all in there, every which way.
Too flip to be serious and too smug to be rousing.
Two for the Money takes its cues from classic rise/demise stories of fresh-faced young men and their amoral mentors, but it stops short of making a point.
Watching Match Point, you could almost conclude that Allen is shedding some of his more calcified habits, that he's molting.

It takes Lane, John Cusack, Dermot Mulroney, Elizabeth Perkins, Stockard Channing and Christopher Plummer and forces them to reenact the entire unabridged Encyclopedia of Treasured Romantic Comedy Clichés and Chestnuts, Revised Second Edition.
There's something about professional comedians breaking down what's funny for civilians that gets annoying after a while.
A sweet, funny and gripping romantic adventure, it's about the limitations of political activism in this day and age, and what happens when your girlfriend and your best friend fall in love.
A deceptively simple, deeply resonant story about the inherent loneliness of family, the odds against assimilation and the enormous distances that can divide two people.
A gorgeous, fevered dream of a movie that blends recollection, imagination and temporal dislocation to create an emotional portrait of chaos in the aftermath of heartbreak.
It's too cold and too uninterested in talk in general and the stories people tell themselves about their romantic lives in particular to do its premise justice.
Divided three ways among the rangers, the prisoners and the resistance fighters in Manila, the movie feels unfocused, schematic and overpopulated.
Tightly plotted and suspenseful enough to keep you guessing.
A surprisingly sweet and funny ode to male friendship and middle-aged love.

An unconscionably dreary and amateurish-looking thing, and the rote plot and annoyingly predictable script -- a compendium of bird puns, mostly -- don't work nearly hard enough to make up for the hammy awfulness of the images.
The transformation of the Little Seamstress is ambiguous and bittersweet and leaves you with the feeling that, like a character out of Balzac, her story will be one of loss of innocence.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A tender love story and a dead-on lampoon of the genre, but its main drawback is that Showalter is egregiously miscast in the title role.
As exciting for its beautifully specific and honest portrayal of teenage girls and their friendships as it is for its dazzling visual and narrative style.
Schreiber takes Foer's sprawling, multilayered, multigenerational beast and hones it into a post-Glasnost buddy picture.
The movie loses some of its initial atmospheric tension as paranoid thrills give way to Rambo high jinks.

That Polanski chose this as the movie he wanted to make for his own children feels motivated by more than a septuagenarian dad's desire to take a $60-million stab at a bedtime story. It feels inspired by a need to tell them who he is.
Hoffman captures what is presented as an astonishing capacity for insinuation and connects it to a deep personal understanding of the basic human need for connection.
Leaves a bitter little aftertaste.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: To watch the film is to marvel at the cast's virtuosity at fleshing out the shallowest people in England.
In Her Shoes treats love like a pretty accessory to be stored in a plastic box and shoved in the back of a closet when it proves impractical.
It's the opposite of the quick commute of the average commercial movie. It's a meandering road trip instead.
Suffers from a malady common to tiny indies of the let's-put-on-a-show variety -- it strains for irrepressibly nutty, but lands squarely in annoying.

One of those movies that's slightly off the mark in ways that are hard to put a finger on, but it is shot so soulfully and features such beautiful performances that it's easy to forgive the occasional false note.

Despite its refreshingly straightforward style and compelling performers, the movie feels encased in an invisible, filmy membrane of its own. Soderbergh keeps his characters on one side of the wall and his audience on the other.
This is social documentary at its best.

... Zahedi tries to construct a narrative from his epic bad behavior, presumably for the purpose of shedding light on something. What this is remains mysterious after a single viewing, but not so mysterious as to inspire a second.
Surprisingly, The Beauty Academy of Kabul provides equal insight into both cultures, showing how excessive, self-obsessed disconnect can shape a culture as strongly as a hideously intruding reality.
In a sense, it's a movie about looking past surfaces to see what's in front of you. It takes the time to look around and discovers majesty, beauty and pathos everywhere it turns.

A confoundingly mercurial figure, Fujimori is a fascinating subject. But in her focus on the man, Perry fails to paint a broader picture of a racially diverse and extremely complex country marked by sharp class and socioeconomic contrasts.
It's Das Perfect Boot -- with the characters compressed to wafers. And I mean that both ways.
A straightforward, surprisingly faithful and definitely loving adaptation of the original.
The early 30s crisis certainly looks more tenable if it's unfolding among several European capitals, but the movie lacks the specificity and focus of the first.
Action- and issue-packed.

Director Peyton Reed doesn't quite bring the sharpness, litheness and attention to detail he brought to Bring It On and Down With Love to The Break-Up, which is nonetheless alternately funny and painful.
The Omen retains the aura of ceremonious kitsch of the first movie, favoring a well-lighted, upscale Goth aesthetic punctuated with flashes of well-timed, cymbal-crashing shockers and giggly camp.
Without Keillor's monologue and the show's collective inclusion on the joke, the movie falls into a strange nostalgia for something that hardly anyone remembers, if it ever really existed at all.
A dark and deeply unsettling movie with its roots in classical tragedy.
A chronological brain-teaser confounding enough to keep you busy trying to figure out whether those holes are in the story or in your logic.
What's rare to see, and what ultimately makes Nacho Libre so enjoyable, is the story of an underdog who's allowed to remain a humble clown all the way to becoming a hero.
A grim little story, but it's leavened unexpectedly with humor and energy.
Although its methodology raises some questions, The Road to Guantanamo provides a riveting glimpse into a heavily shrouded political and moral quagmire that deepens by the day.
A sharp, surprisingly funny excursion into the catty realm of women's magazines.
Like Jack's heart, Dead Man's Chest is unsure of what it wants, so it takes the omnivorous approach, and all of the story lines suffer for it.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The brilliance of A Scanner Darkly is how it suggests, without bombast or fanfare, the ways in which the real world has come to resemble the dark world of comic books.
The tone of You, Me and Dupree is smarmy in that institutional way that doesn't seem to know what the tongue is doing in the cheek, exactly, but keeps it there just in case.
A frank and visceral film that at the same time exudes an unexpected innocence.
Even-handed but quietly devastating.
The experience is at times taxing, but the imagery ... is undeniably arresting and sticky.
For a movie about an inter-family dalliance, it's far more pragmatic than you might expect, and far more humane.
Martin's Clouseau is as clumsy and hapless as his predecessor and probably more innocent.
For a movie about movies, it's surprisingly humanistic, cheerful and true to life.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As simple, friendly, kid-appropriate and nontoxic as any major motion picmerchtainment franchise could ever hope to be.
It gently sheds light on the ways in which people seek new terrain in love when their familiar surroundings let them down.

Freedomland, written by Richard Price from his novel of the same name, directed by Joe Roth and produced by Scott Rudin, purports to be a social study of racial tensions straining under the weight of a highly publicized, hot-button tragedy.
A portrait of grieving artists, trying to get back to the quotidian business of suffering.
Dudes, does a spoof count as a spoof if it's dumber and more obvious than the thing it's spoofing?
Whatever its weaknesses, Tsotsi is redeemed by its excellent performances.
As the movie becomes more howlingly ludicrous by the second, it's tempting -- and not in a cynical way, either -- to start reading it as a parody of pornographic video game violence.
The movie deftly and subtly limns the precarious line between basic human goodwill and institutionalized hatred.
The movie casts around wildly for comic set-pieces, coming up with things like aggressive chipmunks, hostile dolphins and a dad who longs to be naked at all times.
V for Vendetta is not a movie of ideas so much as it is an idea mall. By the time you've gotten through it, you feel spent, loaded down and more than a little disoriented.
There's a sweetness about it that wins you over.
It's a taxing bit of exploitation, which, although you're glad to know it's a work of fiction, doesn't exactly make a case for itself as art.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Dead serious and stone idiotic, the only basic instinct in evidence here is desperation.

Brick is as difficult to categorize as its hard-boiled, made-up lingo is hard to understand -- neither of which should deter anyone from seeing it. It's rare to see a debut as witty and assured as this.
A meditation on American theater and the Great American Pastime that hovers above the surface of reality but never quite takes off, either.

A self-consciously zany dysfunctional family comedy, When Do We Eat? strains so hard to be outrageous that it sacrifices characters for caricatures. They might have had something if they'd let everybody relax, be themselves and enjoy dinner.
Sweet-natured, if somewhat familiar, On a Clear Day features fine performances by Mullan, Blethyn and Sives. Dellal and cinematographer David Johnson paint an inviting picture of Glasgow.
A humanist parable about how to be a good person, live a good life and make gallons of lemonade when life suddenly hands you lemons, it's predictably delightful and delightfully predictable.
A pompous, overwrought and itchingly claustrophobic psychodrama.

American Dreamz, Paul Weitz's good-natured satire of pop, politics and our bloated sense of entitlement (arguably our biggest export) lampoons the great American disconnect from reality by locating the place where all these things intersect.
Lyrical and unaccountably mesmerizing.
A squarely suburban movie with a distinctly bourgeois-shaped window on the world, but it's genuine and exceptionally well observed.
John and Jeremy may be damaged, manipulative, emotionally stunted frat boys with mouths like truckers, but they have a sentimental streak a mile wide.
All this off-the-wall detachment from reality might be OK if the characters didn't also feel detached from one another.
Crudup and Danes display a palpable chemistry.
Incredibly confusing but oddly compelling.
Deliciously perverse and nutty throughout.
The film is more of a portrait than a story, and as such it is finely wrought and compelling, but the airbrush is overkill.
Saw carelessly underscores its own shaky narrative at every turn with its mid-budget hokiness.
We're conditioned as romantics to hear the first word as an adjective; but for most of the movie, it's strictly a harrowing verb.
The story floats along in a philosophical swamp of empowerment mythology, theraspeak and materialism-as-personality that's as contemporary as Oprah's self-esteem empire.
In a world with so many problems, it's hard to drum up any sympathy for these characters' profligate self-destruction.
An ill-advised combination of tragedy and satire, it generally plays like the coffee-break fantasy of a temp who messed up a lunch order and paid for it with his dignity.
We know she's ridiculous. She knows she's ridiculous. It's just too bad she can't wear it more proudly.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Breillat's first foray into comedy is playful, whip-smart and far breezier in both tone and look than the stylized gender polemics she's known for.
Has all the soul, wit and originality of a major co-branding campaign.
A flat parable.
All in all, Jeunet makes a pretty case for the idea that life is ruled by chaos and chance, but made meaningful and worthwhile by love.
An exquisitely evocative movie that elevates rueful melancholia to a superpower.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Almodóvar is at his most breathtakingly complex and mature, and at his most pessimistic.
One of the most profound and uplifting dramas of the year.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What the movie lacks, alarmingly, is a shriveled black heart, or a big, red tell-tale one pulsing beneath the floorboards.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Spacey doesn't shy away from portraying Darin as a self-aggrandizing, self-mythologizing megalomaniac, but not only does he withhold judgment, he also withholds analysis.
Finding Neverland is gently seductive, genuinely tender and often moving without being maudlin.
Gentlemen, it's a male chick flick -- 'The Dirty Secrets of the Ya-Ya Brotherhood.'
Full of car chases, weak jokes and scenes so meandering they make Saturday Night Live look like a paragon of brevity and wit.
It's more likely you'll wind up suffering from compassion fatigue than be drawn in to the story.
For a movie about an unstable superhero who dresses like Carrie Bradshaw after a gamma zap, Ex-Girlfriend is cleverly attuned to the real-life nadirs of big-city psychosexual dynamics.
As instantly gratifying and devoid of surprises as a Club Med vacation.
Affecting and sincere.
The movie had an opportunity to raise some broader philosophical questions about the nature of evil. Does it coil deep within us or come at us with a retractable spear? Anyway, it passed on that.
Despite some agreeably idiotic moments, Without a Paddle is also mostly without a rudder.
Mostly it's Marcos' mysterious sway over those who stood to lose the most from her power, coupled with her amazing inability to face that fact, that makes Imelda maddeningly fascinating.
Appealing combination of mordant humor and cheerful pessimism.

In trying to qualify as mordant satire, charming rom-com, uplifting buddy movie about underdogs trying to stick it to the man and the most meta story ever told, L.A. Twister sprains itself badly.
A never-ending Western story that benefits from Nair's philosophically Eastern point of view.

A refreshing reminder that learning how to navigate danger is a big part of being a teenager, and that no kind of upbringing -- or nifty home furnishings -- can or should shield a young adult from life outside her doors.
We know someone is pulling something, and someone is going to get away with something, and someone is going to be left holding the bag of cheese, but Jacobs keeps us on our toes.
As faithful to the spirit of the novel, and the era that inspired it, as a movie could be yet still feel as fresh as Paris Hilton dish on Page Six.
With its improvisatory tone and loose, rambling structure, which often approaches a total breakdown of coherence, the story takes about half an hour to emerge.
The Bjorn Borg of romantic comedies: precise, good-looking, dependable and serviceable, if predictable.
It creditably re-creates the hesitation, creeping doubt and fear that attend life-shaping decision, especially in love.
While First Daughter is nowhere near as airheaded or disingenuous as Chasing Liberty, it's far more confused.

Schwartzman and Law are pitch-perfect in their roles as dueling poster boys for a transcendent existence versus a materially rich life.
The movie, which was seven years in the making, plays like a mid-'90s "Amadeus."

It's a slow-moving orgy of lowbrow grandiosity that's as tedious as it is overblown and pretentious. Songs, scenes, dance numbers, lyrics and set pieces all blend together into an indistinct, ludicrously self-serious mush.
One of those relatively rare comedies that's at once puerile, charming and very funny throughout.
If there's something a little bit moldy about the setup, the movie is no less charming or involving for it, and it's no less pleasant to succumb to its wayward allure and wastrel lyricism.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Dark and eerily resonant, Niels Mueller's The Assassination of Richard Nixon crawls under your skin and amps up the agitation until you want to jump out of it.
Kutcher is surprisingly well cast as the awkward, somewhat dorky Oliver, and Peet is charming and charismatic without being cloying or artificial.
A grim, histrionic experiment in vehicular metaphor slaughter.
