Modigliani may have been noted for his drunken volatility and arrogance, but once you get a dozen years or so of Behind the Musics and E! True Hollywood Stories behind you, it's hard to get worked up about that sort of thing anymore.
This one's strictly for the dogs.

Category-defying film that's as smart and emotionally resonant as it is entertaining.
Alice Wu's debut film is so deft, natural and exquisitely specific, it feels fresh.
If you're thinking of seeing it, and you're old enough to drive (or even read this), do yourself a favor and rent the original instead.

movie_review_blurb: By simply re-creating what he has observed, Bujalski has created a tender, funny and stealthily affecting portrait of youthful powerlessness and frustration.
Immensely entertaining.
Bizarre and (if you can endure the glasses) visually interesting.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

Seriously, the perfect man would call social services.
Based on a play by Amy Fox, Heights is beautifully shot on location in New York and consistently well-acted, but it sticks a little too closely to the surface to be very compelling.
[Seems] less like scenes from a marriage than highlights from a gay man's fevered nightmare of what it would be like to be a straight married couple.
The show, no matter how fantastical, was about something real. The movie is about Hollywood.
Gorgeously loopy.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: As depressing as it is hard to watch, Palindromes is also consistently, horrifyingly funny and sharp-witted.
As bawdy, self-conscious, jaded and still sweetly optimistic as its double-entendre of a title suggests.
A lively, action-packed and witty piece of globalist entertainment.

If you've spent a week with CBS' prime-time lineup, you've heard this tune a million times.
The movie's pace is appropriate to its mood, which is crisp, melancholy and gently cruel.

How does Kat feel about falling in love with a high-priced escort? What prompts Nick's lightning-bolt conversion to unpaid monogamy? What kind of work can a former comp lit major expect to find in the world? These and other questions are left unanswered.
Plays like a giddy prance through the minefield of the last three decades of American sex and politics.

Its sophisticated world-view is a gentle rebuke to provincial views of the world in American cinema.

Hrebejk and his screenwriter, Petr Jarchovsky, understand their characters too well to judge them.

movie_review_blurb: Lacking in charisma, sexiness and decent jokes.
Dear Frankie's surprises are few and low-key, but the story wraps up nicely.
Rio's own Miss Marple? Sort of.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: There's something especially frustrating about small, personal independent movies that adhere to the stodgy conventions of small, personal, independent movies as if compelled by a cadre of militant MFA candidates.
Cute, clangy, hyperactive, really shiny, completely inorganic (except for the flatulence jokes) and totally hermetic.
It takes a rugged survivalist mentality to sit through 108 minutes of Off the Map.
The movie is as side-splitting as it is creepy.

It becomes increasingly clear that Allen's idea of otherness is frozen in another era. The dividing line between the in-crowd and the out-crowd is as clear as ever, he just can't see it from where he stands.
Unexpectedly fresh, thanks mostly to the sweetly exuberant love story at its center.

It says something when you come out of a film as weird and fantastical as Oldboy and feel that you've experienced something truly authentic. I just don't know what. I can't think of anything to compare it to.
The movie feels like a reductive exercise. Rodriguez might have accomplished what he set out to do, but I'm not sure he's done anyone any favors.
Arranged in order of descending success.

The women are meant to level the emotional playing field and add depth to what is, at heart, a story about the exploitation of poor nations by rich and powerful ones. But they wind up being too bitter and unstable to elicit much sympathy.

The whole thing feels fusty and forced.

Ultimately, Youth Without Youth is more intriguing than it is satisfying. It hooks you, then lets you flounder.
Yu's film may be challenging to synopsize, but it's thoroughly engrossing and wildly surprising.
Tim Burton's scaled-down adaptation chooses style over substance. The result, however, is still a pretty enjoyable film.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You could go see P.S. I Love You, or you could hit yourself on the head with a meat mallet.
How weird is John Turturro's Romance & Cigarettes? Almost indescribably weird, though also strangely involving.
A reminder that even the most complex situations, identities and stories are heartbreakingly simple.
Eerie, atmospheric...an unexpectedly poignant ghost story.
Juno is hilarious and sweet-tempered, perceptive and surprisingly grounded. It's also a gust of fresh air, perspective-wise.

A beautiful, evocative collage composed of concert footage, photographs, interviews and film clips, as well as interviews with people who knew him, the film is a rigorously thorough biography and an impassioned accolade.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The big problem with Mad Money is not that the situation is implausible -- this is a caper; it's supposed to be over the top -- it's that it doesn't do the work necessary to con us into believing it.

Campy, shameless and sophisticated, Lichtenstein's debut is gutsy and original.

A stew of cheap irony, ponderous but meaningless allegory, violence and pretension, the movie is all borrowed style and calculated pandering. It does, however, get more ludicrous by the minute. So in that sense, it's good for an occasional laugh.
What lingers after watching Alice's House are not the moments of conflict but the inexorable rhythms of daily life.
Anything can happen -- anything except anything remotely entertaining.
Billy's resilience, though, is nothing short of amazing. Not to mention part of growing up.
In Bruges manages to toy with cliche while avoiding it entirely.
Note to the writers: Just because a movie is a mystery doesn't mean everything in it has to be.

Let's Get Lost, Bruce Weber's haunting documentary about legendary jazz musician Chet Baker, first came out in 1989 and hasn't been easy to catch since. Now reissued in 35 millimeter, the film looks like a pristine time-capsule.
One of the best movies of the year so far.
August Rush feels like the cinematic equivalent of being stuffed with fruitcake and doused with a gallon of egg nog.
A challenging film, one that I suspect can only benefit from multiple viewings. The success of its approaches varies, but its intent is unfailingly interesting.
A remarkably assured and elegant debut, Blame It on Fidel is the kind of smart, sophisticated and fiercely humanistic film that all movies should aspire to be, but seldom do.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Swicord has a playful sense of humor and a good ear for dialogue, and the movie pleasantly accomplishes what it set out to accomplish.

[It] accomplishes with a modest budget and a talented cast what bigger, slicker, gorier contemporary horror movies rarely do. It taps into a collective dread compounded by the guilt of our complicity.

The script weaves three interlocking stories in unlikely ways and relies on random acts of violence, fate and God for dramatic complications that the characters aren't fleshed-out enough to whip up on their own.
Perfectly encapsulates the slow-motion, frustrated feeling of early adulthood, when longing and inchoate desire easily outnumber actual transformative events and achievements.
A grim, shrill, deluded and incredibly depressing movie, so bewilderingly mean-spirited that the trademark Farrelly Brothers gross-out scenes feel like the sweetest.
The film about three brothers in the wake of their dad's death is a pleasurable journey to nowhere, but it's worth the ride.

A pat and generic, if serviceable, political thriller.

movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing about the movie resonates emotionally.
Martian Child would like to be About a Boy (Who Thinks He's a Martian), but, disappointingly, it doesn't even come close.
Fred Claus turns out to be not bad for a Santa movie, which I suppose could be interpreted as either faint or excessive praise, depending on your view.

movie_review_blurb: I kept wishing for another scene with Mulgarath in the form of Nolte, because, well, you can never have enough Nolte, and because his particular brand of kinetic insanity would have been just what the movie needed to shake up its clockwork smoothness.
[A] strange, funny and sad story.

The movie suffers from the same malaise Romero diagnoses in society. It's just too mediated to be scary, despite its zeal for gore. You can't feel the characters' fear, and they don't seem to feel it either.
Eminently likable. And there's something about Gondry's persistent nostalgia that feels contemporary, or opportune, at least.
The message -- believe in yourself even when all evidence suggests you shouldn't -- is annoyingly familiar and frankly overdue for a serious debunking, but it's not about to happen here.
There are moments of beauty here, but not enough to make up for the mannered dialogue and hamstrung performances.

For that particular someone, Savage Grace could be the perfect summer chiller.ca
Good Dick carries its messed-up, highly improbable premise so lightly and gracefully that it ultimately comes off as a sweet, plausible and curiously grounded love story.

What's being sold here is the movie equivalent of the honey-drenched sweet potato biscuits that are forever being passed around on-screen. Their nutritional value may be nil, but they sure look comforting.

Stilted, claustrophobic and more stylish than substantial.
Miss Conception isn't so much a movie as an extended sitcom -- it looks like one, it acts like one, it reduces everything to the lowest common denominator like one.

If you can get past the Eurocentric focus, there are worse ways to pass the time than to see The Children of Huang Shi, if only because the glimpse into the time and place are captivating and the images are gorgeous.

A plodding, formulaic police drama bathed in bluish light, Pride and Glory displays very little of either.
[A] sprawling, awe-inspiring, heartbreaking, frustrating, hard-to-follow and achingly, achingly sad movie.

If the film suggests that there's something bittersweet about a life dedicated to a single pursuit cultivated with an almost religious fervor, it also stands in awe of its subject's... capacity to remain attuned to the expression of others.

Sinister but gorgeous and compelling.
Little Miss Sunshine employs razor-sharp humor and a deceptively realistic style to satirize a corrupt society that heroes of low status must navigate by their wits alone.
Unexpectedly sharp, light and appealing; a testament to Hunt's skills behind the camera.
It's a beautiful, unexpectedly enrapturing story about a world in transition and both the closeness and unbridgeable divide between generations and cultures.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fascinating and unexpectedly profound and melancholy meditation on what we have become as a country and on the misguided obsessions that made us this way.
A vision of which doesn't require its characters being frozen in amber after a fairy tale ending and allows life to go on, happily and unconventionally.

For all its sad moments, Romulus, My Father is a love story between father and son kept aloft by unalloyed admiration.

It's hard not to like a movie in which Frances McDormand spends half her screen time staring longingly at leftover scraps of bread and half-eaten apples, as she does in the charmingly featherweight Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe it is about compromise, after all, because though Married Life has its moments, it's bewildering as a whole.

The sad thing is that this Horton doesn't stick by its central message -- that every voice counts -- the way Horton sticks to the Whos. It pretends to, but the sincerity is just too scary to commit to fully.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Youth and death meet again in Gus Van Sant's Paranoid Park, a gorgeously stark, mesmerizingly elliptical story told in the same lyrical-prosaic style that has characterized his latest films.
Snow Angels begins with a wink, but it ends with a sucker punch. And somehow this doesn't feel fair.

The perfect frothy fantasy for the obscene wealth gap era, Priceless (Hors de Prix) stars a gorgeous, cellophane-thin Audrey Tautou as Irène, a dedicated gold digger who finds herself accidentally mixed up with a penniless bartender.

If Forgetting Sarah Marshall lacks the heady mix of sheer exuberance and unexpected maturity of the granddaddy of the genre, Apatow's 40-Year-Old Virgin, it's more soulful than Knocked Up and more inclusive than Superbad.

For a film about falling in love with the movies, its insights on them are next to nil.

While it's full of arresting, indelible images, Mr. Lonely remains mostly on the level of abstraction. You get it but you don't always feel it.

[Director Joachim Trier] captures, in a way that's cool and romantic and heady, the moment in life when nothing matters more than ideas, influences and the possibility of shaping one's life into a work of art.
A well-acted, if not terribly well-crafted, character-driven drama without much in the way of a purpose.

Somehow, what starts as a series of cheap shots in a barrel develops into something more, thanks largely to warm, engaging performances by Cusack and Tomei. War, Inc. is both right-on and somehow off, but it gets points for trying.
An ambling narrative, but an atmospheric one that feels authentic despite its unlikely character pairings.

Expertly realized and gunmetal slick, Eastern Promises whirs along with perfect efficiency, but doesn't stir much in the way of visceral horror despite its penchant for treating the human body like a chicken carcass on a block.

Moody, mannered and supremely irritating.
A startlingly original and beautiful pop reverie that comes very close to being transcendent.
Eerie, tense and immediate as Death of a President looks and feels, it doesn't contribute much of anything new to the discourse.

The film explores the ways in which cultural assumptions and biases tend to obscure reality even when reality is plain, and the way our perceived differences keep us from finding a human connection to one other.

Like most homecomings (or at least most good ones), Pedro Almodóvar's Volver is warm, emotional and forever on the brink of tears -- peppered with bouts of pique, old resentments that flare up and moments of intense and lyrical longing.
As funny and cathartic as the word it celebrates, and nearly as perversely shock-happy.

... for a druggie movie, "Candy" is surprisingly dynamic and involving ...

Captures the weary mood of a generation that's crested its peak along with an era, quietly making a case for how well suited film can be to capturing the finer points of human interaction while preserving their mystery.

One of the few films I can think of that examines the baffling combination of smugness, self-abnegation, ceremonial deference and status anxiety that characterizes middle-class Gen X parenting, and find sheer, white-knuckled terror at its core.

Heartbreaking and strange, House of Sand is as original as it is lovely.

... an insightful look at a remarkable behind-the-scenes life and slice of American and Hollywood history.
An impassioned piece of activist filmmaking that's as persuasive and entertaining as it is disturbing.

movie_review_blurb: Judge has a gift for delivering brutal satire in the trappings of low comedy and for making heroes out of ordinary people whose humanity makes them suspect in a world where every inch of space, including mental, is mediated.

A well-photographed inside look at a fascinating culture and its people.
movie_title: Journey into Buddhism: Vajra Sky Over Tibet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some amusing distractions, watching the big picture coalesce is not unlike watching someone complete a jigsaw puzzle. It all comes together eventually, but you already saw the image on the box.

Offers fascinating historical context and two fine lead performances (by Anthony Mackie and Roger Robinson) along with some rather awkward storytelling.
Retains the 2-D charm of the hugely popular Nickelodeon cartoon but adds a few tricks -- a little 3-D here, a little David Hasselhoff there.
Were there an award for most bizarre and dispiriting comedy-horror hybrid featuring killer dolls, the latest installment in the Child's Play series would have it locked up.
[A] mostly terrible heist comedy.
Akin lays on too much nastiness and too many false endings, but the film succeeds anyway, fueled by the idea that love can restore a soul even if it can't always conquer all.
Rather enjoyable.
Too earnest for its own good.
Every shot is perfectly composed and compelling, with light and shadow manipulated to maximum effect.
movie_title: Days of Being Wild (A Fei zheng chuan) (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Though flawed, Episode III never betrays the Star Wars legacy.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If Fonda is partly suited to her role, Jennifer Lopez is not at all suited to hers.
As Phil starts to lose it, Ferrell commandeers the movie.
What we are left with are beautifully choreographed fight scenes of massive scale and moderate interest.
Clanks on nearly every level.

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy never reaches the whimsical brilliance of the late Douglas Adams' beloved sci-fi novel, but this long-awaited film adaptation splits the difference by bringing Adams' story to vivid visual life.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cat fanciers and adventure lovers will like Duma, an engaging story of a boy and his cheetah.
It's not as if Kidman is bad in the role. She's just not especially sympathetic.
Heads in predictable directions and illuminates little besides the process of crafting cars to compete in the Scouts' Pinewood Derby.
A pretty decent comedy of manners.
Cinematic flourishes intoxicate until the hangover of retrospect sets in, and you recognize the unhealthiness of the filial relationship this scene has celebrated.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Is it scarier than the original? No, despite souped-up visuals by commercial and music-video director Andrew Douglas, making his feature-film debut.
The picture about two motherless boys and their unexpected cash infusion is visually inventive, funny, fantastical, poignant and dark around the edges.
Offers action-adventure as enjoyable as it is preposterous.
Rarely approaches a fever pitch. Or even a minor frenzy.
Entertaining but uneven.
Whether via Jennifer Aniston's waitress character in Office Space or your own acne-aggravating teenage stint in front of a fryer, you've probably seen these situations, and these jokes, before.
It's like that fateful moment during a haircut when the scissors slip and that fun, rock 'n' roll shag suddenly becomes a mullet.
Guess what? The new film's social commentary is as tame as its comedy.
With great empathy for human foibles, filmmaker Jan Hrebejk shows that Czechs don't always keep pace with their evolving, post-Soviet society.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A formulaic Disney comedy.
The film, winsome and tragic at once and finely attuned to the rhythms of childhood, always seems quite close to real life.
A sometimes funny, largely heartbreaking look at how tragic events can resonate through generations.
Rent offers rambunctious rock 'n' roll moments not seen on-screen since Hair and Fame.
It's pretentious as well as sappy, despite some nice moments.
A filmmaker of great patience, Serrill chronicled Resler's teams for several years, demonstrating that if one sticks to a subject long enough, powerful things will emerge.

Grueling but ultimately uplifting, World Trade Center tells the true stories of Port Authority police officers John McLoughlin and Will Jimeno, who went into the World Trade Center to save people and ended up needing to be saved themselves.
Creadon's inventive visuals turn puzzle-solving into a spectator sport.
Engaging and then wearisome, Dead Man's Chest piles on the action scenes while displaying a striking lack of imagination.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Singer maintains a tone that's serious but inflected with enough comic touches so that the picture never grows too dark.
Directed by Pixar creative mastermind John Lasseter, Cars adds plenty of warmth and sweetness to its visual wizardry.
Like a pair of faux-fur-lined rubber boots on a Minnesota winter morning, A Prairie Home Companion is warm, charmingly contrived and easy to slip into.
Its story appears simple, but L'Enfant offers subtle insights into Bruno's behavior as it progresses.
In The Break-Up, men are slobs, women are passive-aggressive, and viewers opposed to broad brush strokes for either gender are sorely out of luck.
The rare current movie that keeps you thinking as you head for the exits, The Illusionist is a bit of cinematic magic that keeps on giving.
X-Men and X2 brought unusual complexity and depth to the comic-book movie genre. X-Men: The Last Stand, though a mile wide with mutants, is about an inch deep.

Mission: Impossible III, the most satisfying in the spy-film series, includes all the gadgetry, death-defying stunts and tuxedos one might expect, plus something missing from its predecessors: a soul.
While the Peter Pan figure is a staple of kids' literature and film, Hoot lacks the attendant sense of fantasy to pull this character off.
The character's lack of dimension rarely hampers the frisky retro fun.

During an extended scatological sequence early in RV, the previously unthinkable becomes undeniable: Robin Williams is actually too dignified for some material. What he's required to do in this movie is beneath him, not to mention all over him.
Reverent yet provocative ...

At its best, the film approximates eavesdropping on the talk that can follow the exit of one friend from a room full of good pals, all of them caring, concerned and eager to deflect attention from their own situations.
Much of the fun of Thank You for Smoking comes from its letter-perfect casting.
Lucky Number Slevin entertains but fails to make a lasting impact.
As it twirls and dips, Take the Lead leaves no cliché unturned.
Judging by her first grown-up romantic comedy, Lindsay Lohan won't usurp Julia Roberts or Reese Witherspoon's place in Hollywood any time soon. Just My Luck is just OK, when it isn't labored.
A heartwarming, hilarious movie about family.
All the King's Men doesn't reveal anything new about the ins and outs of politics, even as it insists, via showy visuals and James Horner's sledgehammer score, that it is revelatory.
Sweet when it should be tart, depressing when it should be devilish and flat when it should be funny.
Enlivens the classic premise of innocent-in- the-city by moving its archetypal characters in unexpected directions.

The outrageous comedy Borat holds a mirror up to the casual bigotry within American society. But it's a funhouse mirror, and a cracked one at that, making the film hilarious, fascinating and troubling all at once.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Animated films can take years to complete, and judging by some gags, Flushed Away was in the works for a while. A bit about French toads (kind of like frogs, wink, wink) being less than lionhearted plays as stale.
Given the complexity of Chamusso's own story, Catch a Fire might have benefited from a less-ambiguous villain.
Patrick Chamusso, the refinery foreman played by Derek Luke in Catch a Fire, brims with energy, whether he's dancing to a Donna Summer song or coaching the local youth soccer team.
The wrenching documentary Deliver Us From Evil explores the mind of a pedophile as it accuses the Catholic Church of failing to protect children.
Uneven. Haphazard. Spirit-deflating.
Shortbus strains at times with its acrobatic, real sex and search for bigger meanings. But beneath those elements lies a kind, open heart.
The Prestige plunges us into a world of deception as means, end and the whole point, really.
As the tortured, heavy-drinking Hayes, Beach (Smoke Signals) is an emotional open wound, and his performance gives the movie its soul.
Forgive the straw-grasping, but a film made with such care inspires a search for meaning.
The Last King of Scotland, and especially Whitaker's performance, provide insight into the troubled psyche of one of history's most terrifying leaders.
Man of the Year pretends to reach for a steak knife and draws a plastic spoon instead.
According to the movie, that crisis, which once beset people at midlife, now comes earlier because life moves so fast. Oh, so that's what they're calling immature male behavior these days.
The film's candid-camera skits are mostly unoriginal.
Though they take artistic liberties, Bernbaum and director Allen Coulter respect their subject.
The character might lose his grip at moments, but [Gosling] never does.
Just when you think you've got Confetti completely pegged, it offers a surprise or two.
Highly stylized and overburdened with plot yet always engaging.
Gondry fails to come up with a story to support his visual whimsy. But his flights of fancy are intriguing on their own, and his two lead actors captivate throughout.
It doesn't grow corny until two hours in, but it has already worn out its welcome by that time, thus heightening the hokey effect.
Ice Age: The Meltdown seems like one of those straight-to-DVD animation sequels the studios love to churn out, and not just because of the colon in its title.
Domino director Tony Scott tints his film green, edits at hyperspeed and layers image upon image until it resembles Natural Born Killers on too many Red Bulls.
Of all the things Basic Instinct 2 threatened to be -- titillating, cheeky, outrageous -- who would have thought it would turn out boring?
Lee lends tremendous energy to this tale of criminals who take over a New York City bank.

[The film] at times approximates the cozy hostility that can permeate real-life family gatherings. But then the movie's snap turns to sap, and edgy comedy becomes standard gazing-at-the-Christmas-tree warm fuzziness.
[The film] offers the most thrilling movie moments of 2005 and crafts a lovely relationship between its beauty and beast. But ultimately, this Kong is just too much.
He's got eight kids, she's got 10 and Yours, Mine & Ours is completely by the numbers.
[T]here's little to laugh at.
Two parts intriguing premise and three parts tiresome upper-middle-class ennui.
With Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, director Mike Newell offers a fine addition to the Harry Potter film franchise without presenting any truly spectacular elements.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon will likely be nominated for Oscars for their phenomenal performances as Johnny Cash and June Carter in Walk the Line.
Derailed is ugly and predictable when it should be sexy and sophisticated.
Soaringly romantic and painterly in its beauty, the film provides a lovely introduction to Austen to young fans of the movie's star, Keira Knightley. It might even lead them to read the book.
Noticing these echoes leads the viewer to consider -- and even at 85 minutes, the film allows the mind to wander -- what a comedy built around the talented Leoni might be like.
Starts on the surface and ends on the surface, with intriguing moments of depth in between. Claire Danes, however, is consistently wonderful.
Chicken Little doesn't contain an original bone in its animated body, but it combines its derivations well enough to entertain kids.

In a brilliant, transformative performance, Hoffman plumbs this paradox, showing every color of the famous author whose mix of sensitivity, selfishness and self-loathing led to his death from alcohol and drugs in 1984.
People worn out from their workweek should go to The Legend of Zorro to catch some z's.
Funny, heartfelt and flawed romantic comedy.
The main thing he seems to worry about, as he sits, despondent, in his luxury loft, is that he makes a lot of money for doing very little -- a problem everyone would like to have.
Stylish and insightful, Good Night, and Good Luck offers vital lessons from our nation's political and broadcast history.
Rewarding and sensitively rendered, the studio-produced North Country might revive a worthy subgenre last visited, in tarted-up fashion, by Erin Brockovich.
Forster's disjointed cuts and camera angles fail to spice things up as intended. Instead, he seems to be killing time until the film's trick ending.
Doom is a standard science-fiction/horror film that threatens to be substandard before perking up considerably in its final half.
Gorgeously shot and flawlessly acted, Jarhead readies the audience for a dramatic wallop it never delivers.
What saves the picture, apart from Spielberg's singular visual touch, derives from the personal instead of the political.
The movie is faithful to a fault.
What really sets the film apart from most movie romances is not its same-sex theme but its visual grandeur and exquisite powers of observation.
It's as if this movie about a girl posing as a boy was unsure of what to be, so it decided to be crass.
A cracking good comic-book tale.
Might be the least-sexy film about a hedonist ever made, unless bawdy and bewigged somehow add up to erotic.
Failure To Launch, a funny but overly busy romantic comedy.
Despite its epic framework, blaring rock music and record-breaking box office success in Russia, it's just another pedestrian vampire film.
When a 97-minute film seems protracted, there are script problems.
Heartfelt but clunky, the mermaid-out-of-water story Aquamarine offers enough female-positive messages to make it worthwhile viewing for 'tween' girls.

In true Peckinpah fashion, the harsh, involving Three Burials showcases lawlessness, heartlessness and gallows humor on the frontier. But this modern Western's prevailing themes are propriety and friendship.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For a moment, it appears as if Running Scared has developed into a different, better movie. But subsequent gratuitously violent scenes hint at a determination by Kramer to keep his film at low-grade exploitation level.
Haneke's political message, though thought-provoking, isn't enough to sustain a story that, once its central mystery is solved, lacks a heart.
Emotive, great-looking and physically nimble, the principal actors in Eight Below are born movie stars. The human actors are ok, too.
Alternately histrionic and muddled, the racially charged drama Freedomland never resonates as it should.
Firewall is steadfast in its determination to keep its hero one-dimensional.
Not just sappy and implausible, but unoriginal.
With so much resting on Martin, Pink Panther falls prey to the great equalizer of all star-over-substance comedies: the 45-minute mark.
Defies expectations on nearly every level.
The picture is humorous but straightforward, its mores seeming to reflect the mores of the time.
Lack of visual dazzle, combined with barely sympathetic child characters, keeps the film from enchanting as fully as it might have.
A film of uncommon naturalism that offers a rare cinematic glimpse -- at least outside of documentaries -- into the lives of the working poor.
[The film] forces the viewer to work too hard to buy its buddy pairing (Pierce Brosnan and Greg Kinnear), at times preventing the movie from being the goof it ought to be.
Last Holiday remake returns to the era of the original 56 years ago, when films made all sorts of leaps to sell their concepts.
Tongue-in-cheek yet seriously disgusting, this zombie film isn't perfect. But it is memorable, which can't be said for most of today's assembly-line horror films.
The Incredibles, the latest animated wonder from Emeryville's Pixar Animation Studios, will intrigue adults as well as 7-year-olds. In fact, the adults might be more intrigued.
Aggressively unfunny, with jokes about suicide attempts and fatal airplane crashes.
The movie was monkeyed with too much in postproduction.
Collinwood seems like a series of sketches, with caricatures instead of characters.
Why this film was made now is a puzzler, but here's a theory: It lets a couple of WB stars be naughty.
Lackluster.
An earnest, heartrending look at the divide between religious fundamentalists and their gay relatives. It's also heavy-handed and devotes too much time to bigoted views.
Takes every convention of the romantic comedy genre and turns it on its ear.
What should have been a guaranteed weepie is never truly moving.
More appropriate for hard-core gore fans than general audiences.

Nair and writer Laura Cahill dare to build a movie around some flawed but rather unexceptional women, emerging with a fine character study that's short on plot but rich in the tiny revelations of real life.
Secret Ballot is too contemplative to be really funny.
Sandler is quite winning, but he doesn't stretch so much as deepen the same character he always plays.
Keenly observed and refreshingly natural, Swimming gets the details right, from its promenade of barely clad bodies in Myrtle Beach, S.C., to the adrenaline jolt of a sudden lunch rush at the diner.
Attal mixes comedy with a serious exploration of ego and jealousy within a seemingly serene marriage.
The movie should be credited with remembering his victims.
Pulpy and mesmerizing.
Blessed with two fine, nuanced lead performances.
Foster and newcomer Hirsch are the best things in Dangerous Lives, a touching but odd mix of live action and animation.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Flat, misguided comedy.
Blessed with a searing lead performance by Ryan Gosling (Murder by Numbers), the movie is powerful and provocative. It's also built on a faulty premise, one it follows into melodrama and silliness.
Seeing the paint actually dry, however, would probably be more fun than most of this overly expository film.
Instead of avoiding the genre's conventions, the effervescent German film revels in them, resulting in a picture so infectious it almost seems original.
Goldbacher ... is most adept at visual storytelling, capturing intimate moments with breathtaking acuity.
A stupid, derivative horror film that substitutes extreme gore for suspense.
Needed a little less bling-bling and a lot more romance.
A warm, funny family story that defies popular notions about immigrant families.
Chen's tale of a violin prodigy and his devoted dad pulls the heartstrings on cue, but the movie's vivid, affecting performances save it from being maudlin.
Even during long moments without dialogue, we never tire of watching these actors' finely calibrated performances.
Director Jeff Blitz's riveting, inspiring documentary Spellbound resembles a Christopher Guest movie in that it follows obsessed, socially awkward folks on a seminal journey in their lives.
Ruined from the start by its insulting depiction of mental illness.
A worthy sequel.
A sexy, surprising romance... Idemoto and Kim make a gorgeous pair... their scenes brim with sexual possibility and emotional danger.
Akinshina, a gorgeous and extraordinarily poised young actress, can switch in a flash from wounded kid to jaded know-it-all.
A gritty but sweet look at young love and family dynamics.
A lot like a theme-park ride: occasionally exciting but carefully controlled.
Flouncing and preening, [Gooding] works hard to sell the movie's penile, puerile jokes, his strain so evident that it borders on sad.
The film isn't especially dynamic, but it brims with insightful, poignant memories from survivors.
The Recruit falters after it leaves the Farm, throwing in unbelievable plot devices and losing its high-wire tension.
Mistry and co-star Heather Graham lend a fetching naivete to their characters.
A cheesy monster movie.
A heartening tale of small victories and enduring hope.

Announcing her presence with a phlegmy wheeze, the Fairy strikes swiftly and sometimes even scarily, thanks to Stan Winston's ace special effects. But the movie's premise ... telegraphs her appearances and eliminates suspense.
Computer effects have reduced a magnificent animal to a cartoon comic foil with human expressions and a yen for red licorice.
A gorgeous and grotesque Korean film by director Kim Ki-Duk, who seems torn by his artistic and exploitive impulses.
Subtly powerful.
A loose, lighthearted romp that's a notch above the usual buddy comedies.
Involves two mysteries -- one it gives away and the other featuring such badly drawn characters that its outcome hardly matters.
Lame, haphazard teen comedy.
Garofalo, wary but indulgent as the director's estranged daughter, has great comic rapport with Stiller.
Dumb but also unrelentingly dark and ugly, thereby depriving the viewer of any camp value.
Frank, funny and true.
Often hilarious mockumentary.
A derivative mishmash of cinematic and real-life situations.
Numbingly dull and repetitive.
Queeny, corny and impossible to resist.
Survivors is a truly awful mix of bad direction, nonsensical story line and dialogue that appears to have been made up on the spot.

Writer-directors Michael and Mark Polish ... are going for something grittier in their follow-up, Jackpot. Unfortunately, this entails mixing country-kitsch cliches and excessive vulgarity with their narrative flourishes.
If you got a kick out of Crumb, this film will crack you up.
Trumps Moulin Rouge and even The Rocky Horror Picture Show in infectious pop force.
A big, warm embrace of a picture.
The biggest misstep, though, is running the movie's best sight gag into the ground.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Zips along at a laugh-a-minute pace and fully involves the viewer in Bridget's little slice of life.
Offers only tired jokes, grimace-worthy physical comedy and bad, bad acting.
Part beautifully shot European travelogue and part moving exploration of the darker side of the hippie era's rabid idealism.
Suffers from disparate elements.
A lustrously shot, well-acted and immensely moving romantic drama.
Just One Time is a bedroom farce with little sex or humor, a weak premise and spotty acting. But it's mildly enjoyable anyway, thanks to a sneaky charm.
While it's beautifully shot, it's way too slow. And it isn't one bit scary.
Loser is just as it sounds.
In terms of dramatic tension, Best in Show is more compelling than a lot of formulaic sports movies.
Quote not available.
It's simply a quiet and heartbreaking look at the dynamics of one family. That's the beauty of it.
A coming-of-age story that gets it all wrong.
The key to movies like this is what goes unsaid, but too much gets left out here, at the expense of character.
A B-grade horror picture seems to be a B-grade horror picture no matter how many studio bucks and digital effects you throw at it.
Though a bit indulgent of its star power at times, Monsters is funny and sweet enough to delight kids and inventive enough to satisfy adults.
Admirably ambitious but self-indulgent.
This comic gem is as delightful as it is derivative.
Things really get ridiculous, and not in a funny way.
Charming and witty, it's also somewhat clumsy.
Nair ... in crafting an enchanting movie about a modern Indian family, fills the screen with blooming marigolds, blossoming romances and sizzling dance scenes thrown in just for the heck of it.
The result is more depressing than liberating, but it's never boring.
The slapdash and vulgar second half ... saps the good will engendered by some funny gags and heartthrob Josh Hartnett's ... heart-tuggingly earnest performance.
There's a neat twist, subtly rendered, that could have wrapped things up at 80 minutes, but Kang tacks on three or four more endings.
The dirty jokes provide the funniest moments in this oddly sweet comedy about jokester highway patrolmen.
Scotland, Pa. succeeds because of the cast's communal vibe of arrogant stupidity.
Hart's War contains a fatal structural flaw. A racially charged court-martial that takes up half the picture turns out to be a just a cover.
Scherfig, the writer-director, has made a film so unabashedly hopeful that it actually makes the heart soar. Yes, soar.
The movie's more abstract scare tactics ... are so restrained that viewers may start to yearn for a bogeyman to burst from the closet.
While never truly funny or insightful, the movie works intermittently by digging a little deeper than you might expect.
Robert Altman and a ridiculously talented group of English actors have crafted an upstairs-downstairs comedy of true originality -- a British costume film that's funny but not at all fusty.
It's as if the actress agreed to take another America's-sweetheart role but her spirit didn't.
Exposes the less sexy things that lust can awaken, like viciousness, deceit and amoral longing.
When Lee Majors can steal every scene he's in, your movie's in trouble.
Though it has some lovely moments, Code refuses to be cracked.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Halfhearted and badly edited, the picture itself seems stoned.
An effective love triangle has to involve real conflict. This one doesn't.
Like the designer suits Driver wears despite her character's meager earnings, High Heels and Low Lifes isn't about reality; it's playing dress- up.
With four fine films under his belt, Payne should be regarded as an American treasure.
Whether through manipulation or skilled filmmaking, Swimming Pool mesmerizes long after the movie is over.
A delightful coming-of-age movie that teeters on contrivance but never topples.
An awkward and aggressively unfunny film.
Has enough laughs and misadventures to satisfy its built-in audience, but it won't win any converts.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Hyper-violent yet emotionally powerful, The Blind Swordsman: Zatoichi is the rare exploitation film that values relationships over bloodshed. But the bloodshed is still pretty awesome.
The back-and-forth approach can be confusing, but it doesn't obscure the picture's chief ideas.
Giants offers a thrilling, informative history of a sport-subculture.
It's not a terrible movie, just a disappointingly pleasant one.
Mood and portent can conceal any number of flaws in movies about the thug life.
A good-hearted 'tween comedy hampered by uneven direction and a misguided plot twist.
A story bent on melodrama and borderline sadism.
Fascinating.
The kind of film that might play on a loop at a county fair's Americana exhibit.
Men learning about the female experience by dressing as women is a nice sentiment, but Tootsie had that covered two decades ago. White Chicks should have tried for more.
There's no cohesive story, just a series of opportunities for the title character to strut his gawky stuff.
Most entertaining is Alan Rosenberg's wicked spoof of actorly neuroses.
A moving family drama.
A daring and acutely observed satirical comedy that's laugh-out-loud funny.
The concept is high, the humor lowbrow and the joy of experimentation evident in every frame of this wonderful picture.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A film at once heavy-handed, scattered and heartfelt.
Presents its own, somewhat revisionist samurai legend as a thoughtful and moving domestic drama.
A sly and insightful fable about a religious pilgrimage derailed.
Poignant and carefully observed.
The nagging desire to help these people underscores the involvement of the audience in this superbly told story. You can almost taste the saltwater, and the fear.
Offers enough glossy good cheer to appeal to everyone.
Updates a classic premise -- the struggle for personal freedom -- by pairing it with ethical and moral quandaries.
Terrifying at some moments and insinuatingly creepy at many others.
There are several notable actors in it, most of them quite good, but it's the glorious Annette Bening who hoists this flawed production on her mink-wrapped shoulders and makes it work.
Goes disappointingly soft despite two dynamite lead performances.
Stage Beauty captures the tensions and electricity of backstage dramas.

Like Moore's Fahrenheit 9/11 and Spurlock's Super Size Me, McElwee's Bright Leaves takes on a sizable foe -- in this case, big tobacco -- but with such grace and wit that his message never seems medicinal.
Revisits Guevara's 8,000-mile tour of South America -- and the origins of his personal revolution -- with humor, exquisite compassion and visual grace.
This documentary by Jim de Seve succeeds anyway, by putting a poignant human face on the struggle for equal rights.
A funny hybrid of Hollywood satire and mob comedy.
First Daughter falters from the start in assuming an audience fascination with political progeny.
Transforms the unintentional camp of the zombie subgenre into full-on, hilarious comedy.
Never comes out from under the weight of its dreariness, despite fine acting, foot chases and conspiracy theories galore.
Slumps under the weight of product endorsements and a misguided romantic subplot.
There's no hiding a hokey love story that undercuts the picture's compelling tennis scenes.
Witty, energetic adaptation.
The problems lie not with the actors but with a glib approach that exposes the flaws of the original story.
The jokes are not just stale; they can also be labor-intensive.
Dumb, suspense- free and undersexed stalker drama.
Bursting with luscious color and stunning visual effects.
Merely adequate.
The sequel might have the formula down, but it lacks everything that made Anaconda fun.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The first half of the film is enjoyable but hit and miss. After that, it's just miss.
Writer and director Daniel Taplitz piles on the convolutions in an overripe comedy of sitcom stock characters and bad jokes.
[Swinton's] rich, compelling performance is reason enough to see this uneven picture.
A beautifully shot and compelling blend of thriller and coming-of-age drama.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A masterful portrait of the seasons of a life.
It starts with implausible characters and descends into potty jokes (not just involving babies), racial stereotypes and a criminal lack of originality.
Heavier, with bad teeth and blotchy skin, Theron is nearly unrecognizable in the role. She's also astonishingly good.
A dazzling retelling of the J.M. Barrie tale.
Baldwin bites into his role as if it were a 3 a.m. cheeseburger after a night of blackjack and booze.
Surprisingly lighthearted.
Clocking in at 105 minutes, Love Don't Cost a Thing drags for stretches.
Inarritu and Arriaga's first English-language film doesn't approach the brilliance of Amores Perros, but it succeeds on a more modest scale.
The direction by Richard Donner ... is usually a beat or two off, and the dialogue seems clumsily ad-libbed.
Pleasant but unoriginal.

Love Actually , Curtis' holiday-themed directing debut, abandons any pretext of sophistication for gloppy sentimentality, sugary pop songs and bawdy humor -- an approach that works about half the time.
If only filmmakers Larry and Andy Wachowski could have saved themselves from their own machines. Their computer-generated imagery goes from dazzling to deadening.
Avoids sentimentality at every turn and truly earns both its laughs and its tears.
At nearly 2 1/2 hours, Mystic River proves that a mystery need not be taut to be riveting.
A musical comedy that's mirthless and barely musical.
Funny despite rickety gags.
Like Greek Wedding, Mambo has enough funny moments to save it.
[A] charming family story.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Alcazar makes a deft transition from idiot to maniac, serving as an anchor for the broad performances around him.
Tries screwball and gross-out comedy and fails on both counts.

Lucia, a writer of children's books, dips in and out of fiction in her own life, the line blurring so often that it's hard to tell what's real and what's fantasy in Lucia, Lucia. It's even harder to care.
Powerful and surprisingly timely.
A gorgeous animated film that's as avid a tribute to the Japanese capital as Lost in Translation.
A picture that's all over the map.
Veering from throwback innocence to modern cynicism, the movie is neither a compelling underdog story nor an especially funny romantic comedy.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A street-dance film that's lively and silly and about as 'street' as a Britney Spears video.
An entertaining, if silly, film adaptation of the Marvel comic.
Slap-happy and slapdash, Ten Yards lacks the clever twists and turns that made the original such fun.
A valiant but losing effort.
A delightful blend of comedy, kung fu, soccer and special effects.
A tense, expertly acted Russian film clouded by its intentional ambiguity.
Renders its gay and religious characters so stereotypical that neither lifestyle appears attractive.

To buy this picture, you have to buy Jolie's character, and the actress succeeds much of the time. But once her contained, job-obsessed agent gets involved with a man close to her case, much of what came before is negated.
Celebrates the craft of acting both in its story and in fine performances by Paul Bettany, Willem Dafoe and Brian Cox.
What might have been a commentary on the objectification of women becomes an unrestrained forum for twisted ideas of sexuality.
Think of The Code as an episode of The Sopranos stripped of humor or much insight.
A picture that's lovely to look at but lacking in dramatic impact.
Shou creates an ambitious framework ... This layering detracts from the documentary footage, with nonaction narrative scenes thrown in for no apparent reason.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The murder-plot angle is never completely plausible, but filmmaker Li Yang overcomes it with a searing depiction of economic desperation and moral alienation.
Jansen might not be the best storyteller, but she's a wonderful choreographer, adapting the styles of her stars (both nondancers before the movie) to complement each other beautifully.
Pays off eventually with a lovely story of friendship between two lonely men.
The horrors of Osama are pervasive, not acute, so they take longer to sink in. But once in, they stay there.
[A] pedestrian teen-sex travelogue.
Armed with enough cliches to make Ed Wood proud.

Survival stories tied to extreme activities always come with caveats ... All cynicism vanishes once Touching the Void, a docudrama by Oscar- winning director Kevin Macdonald, charts climber Joe Simpson's excruciating descent.
Warmhearted and surprisingly ambitious.
Her intense denial is fascinating, and extremely sad, to watch.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Intimate, quietly illuminating documentary.
Hanging on a high concept never fully supported by its story, Stranger Than Fiction stays aloft thanks to an exceptionally appealing cast.
Great it ain't, but it entertains for stretches.
Awkward when delivering lighthearted dialogue, Crowe seems profoundly uncomfortable with physical comedy, approaching it with an intense earnestness that smothers potential chuckles.
The film never lags. It is too gorgeous, too expertly acted, and above all, too well directed and written. Nearly devoid of exposition, "The Master" unfolds seamlessly and naturally.

The bigger standouts are scenes of character transformation. these moments alone are worth the price of admission. They are the reason to keep seeing summer blockbusters on a big screen. There are few new ideas, but still plenty of new thrills.
Gloom never looked as good as it does in the mesmerizing "The Dark Knight Rises."

The filmmakers' devotion to Collins' page-turner will please the book's fans and anyone who likes action, sci-fi, social commentary or a female protagonist with smarts, compassion and survival skills.
"Place Beyond the Pines" will not lift spirits. Yet there are hints of hope attached to the film's view that change is possible -- if people can just get out of their own way.
The movie's thoughtful depiction of the mother-daughter bond is female-forward enough to mark "Brave" as special.
Given how much better the movie's calmer, more emotional scenes play than the hyper-kinetic ones, Luhrmann's visual fervor suggests less of a style than a crisis of confidence.
Often entertaining yet exhausting.

The Proposal often lies flat where it should spark, with director Fletcher failing to maximize her talented cast's potential. The timing is off in several scenes, and a would-be outrageous character inspires more eye rolls than laughs.
It is not the breath of fresh air that was 2006's "Casino Royale," but it is nearly as satisfying.
Pelham 1 2 3 ultimately plays as too old-school and low- tech to compete with the summer's other big action films.

It distinguishes itself from other what-happens-in-Vegas comedies (practically a subgenre at this point) by setting an especially vivid scene and telling an actual story instead of pasting together random shenanigans the way many modern comedies do.
Rarely allowing substance to interfere with style, filmmaker Rian Johnson occasionally amuses but mostly frustrates with his con-job fantasia The Brothers Bloom.
With Ratatouille, WALL-E and now Up, Pixar Animation Studios has graduated from moviedom's finest animation house to its most consistent producer of great cinematic art, period.
Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian throws everything -- history, high jinks, lots of famous faces in supporting roles -- at the museum walls to see what sticks. Happily, much of it does.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Christian Bale should have taken a vacation instead.

The lead characters might flirt with spiritual and emotional ruin, but Cuarón's filming style is so lively, and Luna and García Bernal's performances so full of energy, that the picture is fun even when it probably shouldn't be.
Angels & Demons might cause controversy among viewers who like their Tom Hanks films to be of some substance.
Abrams' Star Trek strikes a beautiful balance, with enough allusions to Trek mythology to please longtime fans and enough 21st century verve to wow even those viewers who know nothing of Star Trek.
Another action film that doesn't fulfill its potential.
Steven Soderbergh's study of a high-priced Manhattan call girl through the prism of the economic crisis, is meta enough to intrigue yet too removed to truly engage.
The fear, anger and betrayal in Jackson's eyes, when Stephen feels his place is threatened, says more about the cruelties of slavery than the ultra- violent, sickening passages of "Django Unchained."

"Unexpected Journey" runs nearly three hours. That gives Jackson plenty of time to revive its magic [which he does] by triggering our good will toward the "Rings" trilogy. He evokes the trilogy's tone and its rhythms.
Teenage acting newcomer Suraj Sharma, discovered through a casting call in India, gives Pi an earnestness and toughness that ground this elaborate story.

Greengrass has used his hand-held cameras to lend Phillips great senses of immediacy and place, making us privy to the thought processes and interpersonal conflicts among the pirates and the ship's captain and crew.
The year's great cinematic visual achievement.
Never before has Gordon-Levitt disappeared into character as he does here.
Austenland needs lessons on how a proper spoof should behave.
For parents who must accompany them to the film, there's good news as well: It's far from the worst movie ever, and it lasts only 95 minutes.
Oprah Winfrey is great at everything. This is no news flash, but it's as apparent as ever when watching Lee Daniels' The Butler.
Teller and director Ponsoldt have crafted a character who only grows more sympathetic as the complications below his sunny exterior are revealed.
Jasmine is unlikable, but Blanchett makes you feel her pain, anyway, because she's so subtly yet devastatingly good at showing that pain.
The violence in Elysium is stark and cruel, befitting a film about a divided society.
Fruitvale Station's arrival in theaters corresponds with the outcry over the Trayvon Martin case. But Fruitvale did not need added relevancy to be remarkable.
You ride along with inconsistencies because Ranger is building toward a final showdown. When that showdown disappoints, you feel every minute of the film's 2 1/2-hour length.

Pitt has hidden his inner John Wayne-Bruce Willis for too long. In the highly engaging World War Z, he proves to be a capable, winning and -- in the great American film tradition -- exceptionally hard-to-kill action hero.
Man of Steel contains little fun apart from the visceral thrill of seeing objects smashed in one of its endless action sequences.
The great conceit of Polley's theories of perspective and truth is that she, as director, ultimately controlled everyone's memories because she arranged them on film.
A celebration of cinema, New York City and the distinctive charms of actress Greta Gerwig, Frances Ha was co-written by Gerwig and its director, Noah Baumbach, and it's the best film either has made.
The tone and story lack such solidity. Opportunities for moments between Portia and Jeremiah go wasted.

"Spring Breakers" might engender multiple viewings and a cult status à la "Scarface." Korine, unfortunately, jumps the gun by frequently repeating lines of Franco's dialogue in voiceover, as if "Spring Breakers" already is on repeat.

The movie broadens from Spector's legal case into larger explorations of prejudices people can harbor about celebrities and eccentrics. The result is a thoughtful, sometimes fascinating, purposefully inconclusive character study.
The funny, warm-hearted "Wizard of Oz" prequel "Oz the Great and Powerful" veers far enough from the Yellow Brick Road paved by the original film to avoid dangerous direct comparisons.
"Zero Dark Thirty" shows guts in taking on loaded subject matter and filmmaking confidence and skill in not telling us how we should feel about it.

Spielberg and Kushner lend the House scenes so much vigor that "Lincoln" comes fully alive for about half an hour. Then Spielberg tacks on three addenda, and thus dissipates the good will that has developed on both sides of the movie-theater aisle.
Downey, Foxx and director Joe Wright ultimately pierce the more artificial elements to deliver an unusually perceptive film.
Peirce's Carrie is not as accomplished but still feels more substantial than most contemporary teen horror films. It's well-acted, insidiously creepy and sufficiently bloody, if you're into that.
A very southern modern Western, the Spanish-language Sin Nombre offers a treacherous frontier, a conflicted outlaw and fine performances by actors with whom the camera clearly is besotted.
A sophisticated comedy about an unhinged doofus, Observe and Report falters under the weight of its ambitions.
Frank Langella doesn't impersonate Richard M. Nixon in Frost/Nixon. He goes one better. He makes him a sympathetic movie character.

Slumdog Millionaire bursts with life, delighting, shocking and constantly engaging through lively visuals and the rags-to-maybe-riches adventures of a young man who travels from the slums to the hot seat of the Indian Who Wants To Be a Millionaire.
The umpteenth holiday-family-gathering film to hit theaters in the past few years, Nothing Like the Holidays distinguishes itself from the pack with fine acting.

Who goes to a sci-fi film to be reminded about conservation? I get enough of that from my recycling bin, which, by the way, is far more visually exciting than The Day the Earth Stood Still, as well as more pleasing to the ear.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Gus Van Sant's storytelling approach, expansive yet always intimate, works in tandem with Sean Penn's masterful performance to create a loving, humanistic tribute to a San Francisco icon.
With this cast doing its own singing, and history this rich, it's close enough for rock 'n' roll.
For much of its more than 2 1/2- hour length, this sweeping film from Aussie director Baz Luhrmann provides old-fashioned thrills and entertainment.
Delightful apart but deadly together, Reese Witherspoon and Vince Vaughn look, throughout Four Christmases, as if they just want to get this thing over with.
The Boy in the Striped Pajamas fails to illuminate history. Instead, it raises questions about the project itself. As in, who thought this was a good idea?
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This PG-13 rated film is perfectly appropriate for any 13-year-old who has served time in an adult prison.
From the sometimes-silly glower-fest known as Twilight, Robert Pattinson emerges a movie star.
That smile is so winning it's almost transcendent (kind of like Julia Roberts' smile, back when she used to smile). But it's Hawkins' depth that ultimately sells the film's premise.
Boasting talented voice actors and characters already beloved by the audience, Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa still only adds up to middling.

Entourage and Ricky Gervais' Extras have thoroughly mined Hollywood excess, lampooned "visionary," unhygienic directors and showcased big stars spoofing themselves. So when a film does the same things, it can seem like old hat.
Hathaway's thin-skinned performance, full of hurt, anger and desire for acceptance, transfixes throughout.
Director and choreographer Kenny Ortega takes full advantage of the big screen with brightly colored set pieces brought to life by a talented group of young actors.
When historians do assess Bush's presidency, they probably won't consult a film offering more cheap jabs than insight.
This tale of compassion and love crossing the racial divide of the civil rights-era South remains powerful even when not fully plausible.
Though sumptuous and well-acted -- especially by Fiennes -- the picture fails to establish Georgiana as a figure just crying out for a film treatment.
City of Ember starts out promising and ends up ho-hum.
Quantum of Solace always looks and sounds terrific, with top-notch production values and a superb score by David Arnold that always sounds fresh while evoking Bond scores past.
Aiming for profound, Seven Pounds stalls at maddeningly coy.

The Spirit starts out flat and stays that way, offering unimpressive special effects and fight scenes that mostly lie there. The people part of the effects-actor equation is faulty as well, with iffy-to-bad performances among the supporting ranks.
Marley & Me allows its human as well as its canine characters flaws while delivering a nice message that dogs, like children and marriages, require commitment and work.
As superfluous sequels go, Fast & Furious makes Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo seem vital.
Filled with likable actors and 1980s pop songs, Adventureland ambles, entertains and ... ends ... without ever trying to be more than a tribute to odd jobs, unlikely friends and hanging out.
Sunshine Cleaning is a small film with small storytelling problems that eventually add up.

Overall, Monsters vs. Aliens is pleasing without being especially hilarious. Some lines fall flat, and a few bits involving B.O.B. are overused. But a lack of zingers is forgivable in a movie of such visual accomplishment.
Duplicity probably improves on second viewing, when one is better acquainted with the basic story. Yet the film is not good enough to see twice â" the Catch-22 of all entertaining but muddled movies.
A bang-up comedy for about 40 minutes that hits, misses and meanders after that.
The head-cracking, explosions and gunplay eventually get out of hand, considering that, revamp or no revamp, Witch Mountain is still a Disney film aimed squarely at kids.
The current economic crisis has turned this fictional story of one woman's string of bad luck into a tale that seems real and relatable.
This adaptation of the acclaimed 1980s graphic novel never fully satisfies, despite powerful fight scenes and one superb performance.

In Un Secret, French filmmaker Claude Miller expertly weaves together a family history, merging the personal and political, the celebratory and the tragic, while incorporating three distinct time periods.
Claudel has made a very special kind of star vehicle -- the kind that's also a very good movie overall.
A stylish but standard thriller centered on an international bank's malfeasance, The International fails to resonate even on a bank-hating level.
That a star-filled romantic comedy based on a pop best-seller adheres to convention doesn't surprise, but the filmmakers go too far by forcing two of the most pathological characters together.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This PG-rated film, though visually splendid and thoroughly engaging, is also too eerie for most kids.
Whereas Bridget stands as the best Hollywood romantic comedy of the past decade, New in Town hovers somewhere near the middle of the subpar pack.
A few of the creatures, as well as one startling moment, might unsettle little ones in the audience. But the greater danger is that they'll fall asleep.
The film might have been just another middling musical biopic had the lead role not been so perfectly cast.
Revolutionary Road, an essay on the emptiness of 1950s suburban life, leaves one with an empty feeling.

Gran Torino gives us an opportunity -- growing rarer each year -- to watch a national treasure for two hours. Make that a national treasure who continues, as a filmmaker, to challenge ideas about what it means to be an American.

The face-offs between these two form the foundation of Doubt, a close- quartered but psychologically expansive film directed and written for the screen by John Patrick Shanley, based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning stage play.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button does what technically masterful films so rarely do, inspiring a tremendous sense of warmth as well as admiration.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A serviceable thriller -- one that's tensely paced and enjoyable before the script betrays audience trust.
The Counselor shows that some authors should write directly for the screen and others are better off adapted.
The extraordinary 12 Years a Slave thrusts its lead character (Chiwetel Ejiofor) and the audience into slavery's moral and psychological morass more fully and directly than any movie before it.
Blue is a coming-of-age story that's only partly a coming-out story.

The ramrod-serious Diesel and Statham sell the dialogue, anyway. So do the more lighthearted Johnson and Tyrese Gibson. Johnson and Gibson wring laughs from obvious jokes. The acting champ of 7, though, is Michelle Rodriguez.
It succeeds as a thriller, with performances that strike a grave, quiet tone suited to the film's wide shots, long takes and carefully cultivated mood of foreboding.
The distasteful, often flat Get Hard succeeds only as a testament to the resilience of talent.
Long and violent but lacking narrative momentum, Insurgent is an inferior sequel to the already mediocre Divergent.

Even with Blanchett playing her, the stepmother remains the same uncomplicated villain she was in the 1950 Disney animated film. This is even more disappointing than the Cinderella character lacking gumption, since she's always been bland.
Robbie brings such genuine feeling to heavier scenes and such joy to light ones that her acting fools us into thinking Jess is a more developed character than she is.
The lovely McFarland, USA hits the expected mile markers on the inspirational-sports-movie path while slowing down enough to craft a rich portrait of a place and its inhabitants.
Attempting to describe the level of tragedy contained in Moore's performance in the film's third act brings to mind the limits within Alice's chosen field of study. Because no words do it justice.

Gigli exists. Therefore no other Jennifer Lopez movie can be the worst Jennifer Lopez movie ever made. The silly, clichéd, visually irritating The Boy Next Door gives it the ol' high school try, anyhow.
When "Young" is good, it is delicious, playing on 40-somethings' resistance to being considered "middle-aged."
Though his past as a punk-challenging, on-screen enforcer suggests a guy who thinks he has the answers, Eastwood the director always asks the big questions.
DuVernay shows visual assurance and a way with actors and especially words.
Knightley here gives a mature performance that matches Cumberbatch's in commitment.
Foxcatcher does not invoke ideas beyond the real-life story of du Pont and the Schultzes, thus depressing its audience without offering any compensating lessons.
Wild captures the quality of real-life thinking and walking, of the physical rhythm of movement sometimes dislodging random memories.
Top Five entertains more than any previous film in which Rock was top-billed primarily because its content as well plays like an extension of Rock's stand-up act.
Unless some hidden straight-to-video gem exists, Horrible Bosses 2 stands alone as a raunchy-comedy sequel that's superior to its predecessor.

Highlighted by an extraordinary performance by Eddie Redmayne, The Theory of Everything offers an easy introduction to Stephen Hawking for people curious about the brilliant astrophysicist but intimidated by the whole "astrophysicist" thing.
The film ultimately rests on Lawrence, and though she never disappoints, a single actress -- even one as lovely and lovable as she -- cannot save a blockbuster film.
Voice actor Potter, still a teenager himself, lends Hiro an authentic youthfulness and likability. But Tadashi and Baymax are the standout characters.
Vice will be remembered as minor Anderson. But even greats can use a romp or two in their oeuvres.
Ultron is too full, of action and CGI, while also being nearly empty of genuine thrills. A talented cast impresses throughout, but the action ultimately overwhelms it.

Real people and organic settings always capture the eye more fully, and imply higher stakes, than CGI imagery. Miller ups the ante by ensuring all characters and vehicles are visually striking, either in their good looks or their hideousness.
The film never lapses into hagiography, partly because Solomon is too authentic a presence.
movie_title: All Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's in the more natural-seeming spurts of joy, rather in the less organic moments of crisis, that Babel makes its best argument for a universal experience.
Athough Eastwood deserves credit for not going the cheesy route by drawing out the attack unnaturally, the rest of "15:17" is so drawn out, you almost wish he would have given into cheese.
[Kruger's] performance sustains interest in the movie when director and co-writer Fatih Akin ("Head-On"), after a highly promising start, takes it into C-grade Liam Neeson territory.
These actors all yield the floor to Hugh Grant's delightful performance as Phoenix Buchanan, a vain thespian who lives near the Browns in London.

Comedian Katt Williams, in a small role as a chipper hitchhiker, injects about 15 minutes worth of fun into Father Figures, an otherwise mostly dreadful road comedy in which Ed Helms and Owen Wilson play twins searching for a man to call dad.
Johnson is good at suggesting a timid teen beneath his wall of muscle. Gillan seems believably unsure of herself as the nerd Martha, while also making exposed abs look classy.
Which came first, bullies or dead animals in jars? "Friend" does not say, nor is there a clear link between the discord in Jeff's home and his behavior.
The story's eventual move into brutality is all the more devastating because of well-observed intimacy that preceded it.

Full of vivid greens and sun-backlit wildlife imagery, Van Lawick's shots are beautifully composed yet not too formal looking, thanks to the warm, grainy quality of 16-millimeter film. "Jane" looks like an old home movie directed by David Lean.
This brand of eccentricity does not suit Cusack.
Sandler lends Danny an open-heartedness that grounds the film.
If you have or had a mother, or a daughter, or a father, or a son, you are likely to blubber through Bright Lights ... But don't. You will miss part of the show, and Reynolds would not want that.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Other People [is] a highly affecting Sacramento-set tragi-comedy .
The powerful new documentary "Amanda Knox" emphasizes the spike in awareness of sexism just since 2007.
The five stories' most striking commonality is placing its characters in conflict with the American ideal of being able to forge one's own destiny.
The retirees' embrace of India, and a resulting lack of transformative experiences, diminish the dramatic possibilities in Second.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unbroken is a triumph-of-the-spirit film that devotes too much time to attempts at squashing that spirit.
It creates a less-believable ancient world and contains fewer compelling action scenes than Scott's previous sun-and-sandals epic Gladiator -- nor conviction.
It is Cotillard's emotional accessibility that turns this drama and character study into a quiet thriller.
J.C. Chandor is becoming American cinema's foremost chronicler of men in crisis.

[The Force Awakens] rarely stops moving, yet its action never seems excessive. That's because combatants and targets always remain clear instead of fuzzed up by the hyper-speed visuals hack action directors use.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You never know what's coming in Interstellar. It stokes and maintains a sense of anticipation often missing in Hollywood blockbusters intent on being formulaic and thus global audience-friendly.

Visually urgent, inflected by humor and enriched by savvy performances, the film succeeds on a surface storytelling level and as a deeper exploration of culture -- high, low and whatever sub-floor Twitter fame occupies.
Ayer can match Tarantino's brutality but lacks his humor and finesse.
When the judge finally softens up a bit, Duvall generates genuine audience waterworks.
There's self-awareness all around in Other Woman until it flies out the window in favor of high jinks.
If only we knew the movie's title character a little better. But maybe being left wondering is another victory for Cage. When was the last time you were intrigued by a Cage character?
Holy heck, Oculus is scary. It's also well-crafted and highly confident.
Among comic-book films, it's up there with Batman Begins and Spider-Man 2 (the first).

In its enumeration of victories and setbacks within that time frame, Chavez fails to create a full or even full-ish picture of the man whose bold but nonviolent tactics led to better working conditions in the fields.
The performances in Noah are uniformly fine, meaning Aronofsky must be credited as well.
Budapest Hotel, a vibrant, cheeky throwback to 1930s caper comedies, contains the same high degree of craftsmanship as [Anderson's] other films. There's just more of it.

Lots of stories are derivative yet still exciting to watch. Divergent, though, contains a middle stretch, during which Tris undergoes her training and falls for Four, that does not generate enough audience interest.
There should be a sequel to further explore this intriguing concept. Gather your pennies, Marshmallows.
Were it not for the Sept. 11 allusion, Non-Stop could be a guilty pleasure. But that allusion -- so destructive to the film's quality, so unnecessary to its plot -- squashes much of the pleasure.
The makers of the raucous remake clearly recognized those sidekicks' value.

Building a plausible love story between an escaped convict and a lonely, depressed single mother at whose house he hides would seem to require delicate, nuanced storytelling. Labor Day hits us with a rolling pin.
Fiennes, who also directed, crafts a vividly human and likable character impossible to dismiss as an old, whiskered perv.
Is it awards-worthy? No. But it's often exciting, the kind of strenuously acted movie that blows the cobwebs off the viewing experience after all those more carefully modulated awards-season dramas.
Overlong by an hour and overindulgent by infinity, Martin Scorsese's The Wolf of Wall Street entertains at times but mostly numbs.

Imbued with a surly magnetism by Isaac, Llewyn is quick witted and shows a way with a song. The film surrounding him ably mixes dark humor, period authenticity and polished yet heartfelt musical performances.
Lie emerges as less an indictment of our celebrity-obsessed culture (Armstrong's case is too specific) than a portrait of an incredibly demanding sport.
Bursting with humor, great acting and David O. Russell's abundant filmmaking talent, American Hustle is a joy to watch.
Also impressive is all the beauty on display in Smaug, from the stunning New Zealand landscapes to the actors.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Payne delivers a portrait of small-town America as observant as Picture Show, and a poignant/fun road movie that serves as a companion to the similarly toned Sideways.

Fire maintains such a consistent dystopian vision by other means -- from fine performances to its accomplished production design -- that the stakes of Katniss' increasingly complex journey are evident even when its violence is obscured.
Well-acted and executed, The Amazing Spider-Man 2 does little wrong besides exist.
Though Body of Lies hews a bit too closely to convention, it still engages throughout thanks to DiCaprio and director Scott.
Neighbors contains some hilarious sight gags. But other moments get lost in director Nicholas Stoller's inundation of retaliatory scenes punctuated by shaky camera work and frat-house strobe lights.
We came to see things get smashed. Godzilla delivers.

Though well-acted and at moments thrilling, "Messenger" fails to satisfy as a story of the little guy taking on government corruption -- because the little guy is crushed and there is no bigger narrative payoff.
Gone Girl lives up to its promise as the year's "event" movie for fanboys and fangirls who prefer book clubs to comic-book stores.
It unfolds gradually, and with intimacy and immediacy, as it chronicles the first blush of romance between Eleanor and Conor and their relationship's worst days.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)
